PREFACE 
    The Tucumcari, New Mexico Municipal Code, originally published by Book Publishing Company in 1999, has been kept current by regular supplementation by Matthew Bender & Company, Inc., its successor in interest. 
    Beginning with Supplement No. 18, Municipal Code Corporation will be keeping this Code current by regular supplementation. 
    During original codification, the ordinances were compiled, edited and indexed by the editorial staff of Book Publishing Company under the direction of Jeannette Maddaford, city clerk. 
    The code is organized by subject matter under an expandable three-factor decimal numbering system which is designed to facilitate supplementation without disturbing the numbering of existing provisions. Each section number designates, in sequence, the numbers of the Title, chapter, and section. Thus, Section 2.12.040 is Section .040, located in Chapter 2.12 of Title 2. In most instances, sections are numbered by tens (.010, .020, .030, etc.), leaving nine vacant positions between original sections to accommodate future provisions. Similarly, chapters and titles are numbered to provide for internal expansion. 
    In parentheses following each section is a legislative history identifying the specific sources for the provisions of that section. This legislative history is complemented by an ordinance disposition table, following the text of the code, listing by number all ordinances, their subjects, and where they appear in the codification; and beginning with Supplement No. 18, legislation can be tracked using the "Code Comparative Table and Disposition List." 
    A subject-matter index, with complete cross-referencing, locates specific code provisions by individual section numbers. 
    This supplement brings the Code up to date through Ordinance 1131, passed December 3, 2015. 
Municipal Code Corporation
1700 Capital Circle SW
Tallahassee, FL 32310
800-262-2633 
HOW TO USE YOUR CODE 
    This code is organized to make the laws of the city as accessible as possible to city officials, city employees and private citizens. Please take a moment to familiarize yourself with some of the important elements of this code. 
Numbering System. 
    The numbering system is the backbone of a Code of Ordinances; Municipal Code Corporation uses a unique and versatile numbering structure that allows for easy expansion and amendment of this Code. It is based on three tiers, beginning with title, then chapter, and ending with section. Each part is represented in the code section number. For example, Section 2.04.010 is Section .010, in Chapter 2.04 of Title 2. 
Title. 
    A title is a broad category under which ordinances on a related subject are compiled. This code contains about 15 to 20 titles. For example, the first title is Title 1, General Provisions, which may contain ordinances about the general penalty, code adoption and definitions. The titles in this code are separated by tabbed divider pages for quick reference. Some titles are Reserved for later use. 
Chapter. 
    Chapters deal with more specific subjects, and are often derived from one ordinance. All of the chapters on a related subject are grouped in one title. The chapters are numbered so that new chapters which should logically be placed near certain existing chapters can be added at a later time without renumbering existing material. For example, Chapter 2.06, City Manager, can be added between 2.04, City Council, and Chapter 2.08, City Attorney. 
Section. 
    Each section of the code contains substantive ordinance material. The sections are numbered by "tens" to allow for expansion of the code without renumbering. 
Tables of Contents. 
    There are many tables of contents in this code to assist in locating specific information. At the beginning of the code is the main table of contents listing each title. In addition, each title and chapter has its own table of contents listing the chapters and sections, respectively. 
Ordinance History Note. 
    At the end of each code section, you will find an "ordinance history note," which lists the underlying ordinances for that section. The ordinances are listed by number, section (if applicable) and year. (Example: (Ord. 272 § 1, 1992).) 
    Beginning with Supplement No. 18, a secondary ordinance history note will be appended to affected sections. Ordinance history notes will be amended with the most recent ordinance added to the end. These history notes can be cross referenced to the code comparative table and disposition list appearing at the back of the volume preceding the index. 
Statutory References. 
    The statutory references direct the code user to those portions of the state statutes that are applicable to the laws of the municipality. As the statutes are revised, these references will be updated. 
Cross-Reference Table. 
    When a code is based on an earlier codification, the cross-reference table will help users find older or "prior" code references in the new code. The cross-reference table is located near the end of the code, under the tabbed divider "Tables." This table lists the prior code section in the column labeled "Prior Code Section" and the new code section in the column labeled "Herein." 
    As of Supplement No. 18, this table will no longer be updated. 
Ordinance List and Disposition Table. 
    To find a specific ordinance in the code, turn to the section called "Tables" for the Ordinance List and Disposition Table. This very useful table tells you the status of every ordinance reviewed for inclusion in the code. The table is organized by ordinance number and provides a brief description and the disposition of the ordinance. If the ordinance is codified, the chapter (or chapters) will be indicated. (Example: (2.04, 6.12, 9.04).) If the ordinance is of a temporary nature or deals with subjects not normally codified, such as budgets, taxes, annexations or rezones, the disposition will be "(Special)." If the ordinance is for some reason omitted from the code, usually at the direction of the municipality, the disposition will be "(Not codified)." Other dispositions sometimes used are "(Tabled)," "(Pending)," "(Number Not Used)" or "(Missing)." 
    Beginning with Supplement No. 18, this table will be replaced with the "Code Comparative Table and Disposition List." 
Code Comparative Table and Disposition List. 
    Beginning with Supplement No. 18, a Code Comparative Table and Disposition List has been added for use in tracking legislative history. Located in the back of this volume, this table is a chronological listing of each ordinance considered for codification. The Code Comparative Table and Disposition List specifies the ordinance number, adoption date, description of the ordinance and the disposition within the code of each ordinance. By use of the Code Comparative Table and Disposition List, the reader can locate any section of the code as supplemented, and any subsequent ordinance included herein. 
Index. 
    If you are not certain where to look for a particular subject in this code, start with the index. This is an alphabetical multi-tier subject index which uses section numbers as the reference, and cross-references where necessary. Look for the main heading of the subject you need, then the appropriate subheadings: 
BUSINESS LICENSE 
See also BUSINESS TAX
Fee 5.04.030 
Required when 5.04.010 
    The index will be updated as necessary when the code text is amended. 
Instruction Sheet. 
    Each supplement to the new code will be accompanied by an Instruction Sheet. The Instruction Sheet will tell the code user the date of the most recent supplement and the last ordinance contained in that supplement. It will then list the pages that must be pulled from the code and the new pages that must be inserted. Following these instructions carefully will assure that the code is kept accurate and current. Removed pages should be kept for future reference. 
Page Numbers. 
    When originally published, this code was numbered with consecutive page numbers. As of Supplement No. 18, when new pages are inserted with amendments, the pages will follow a "Point Numbering System". (Example: 32, 32.1, 32.2, 32.2.1, 32.2.2., 33). Backs of pages that are blank (in codes that are printed double-sided) will be left unnumbered but the number will be "reserved" for later use. 
Electronic Submission. 
    In the interests of accuracy and speed, we encourage you to submit your ordinances electronically if at all possible. We can accept most any file format, including Word, WordPerfect or text files. If you have a choice, we prefer Word, any version. You can send files to us as an e-mail attachment, by FTP, on a diskette or CD-ROM. Electronic files enable us not only to get you your code more quickly but also ensure that it is error-free. Our e-mail address is: ords@municode.com. 
For hard copy, send two copies of all ordinances passed to: 
Municipal Code Corporation 
P.O. Box 2235 
Tallahassee, FL 32316

    If you have any questions about this code or our services, please contact Municipal Code Corporation at 1-800-262-2633 or:

Title 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
Chapters: 
Chapter 1.01 - CODE ADOPTION 
Sections: 

1.01.010 - Adoption. 
    There is adopted the "Tucumcari Municipal Code" as compiled, edited and published by Book Publishing Company, Seattle, Washington. 
(Ord. 942 § 1, 1999)
1.01.020 - Title-Citation-Reference. 
    This code shall be known as the "Tucumcari Municipal Code" and it shall be sufficient to refer to such code as the "Tucumcari Municipal Code" in any prosecution for the violation of any provision thereof or in any proceeding at law or equity. It shall be sufficient to designate any ordinance adding to, amendment to, correction or repeal of the Tucumcari Municipal Code. References may be made to the titles, chapters, sections and subsections of the Tucumcari Municipal Code and such references shall apply to those titles, chapters, sections or subsections as they appear in the code. 
(Ord. 942 § 2, 1999)
1.01.030 - Reference applies to all amendments. 
    Whenever a reference is made to this code as "Tucumcari Municipal Code" or to any portion thereof, or to any ordinance of the city of Tucumcari, New Mexico, codified herein, the reference shall apply to all amendments, corrections and additions heretofore, now or hereafter made. 
(Ord. 942 § 3, 1999)
1.01.040 - Title, chapter and section headings. 
    Title, chapter and section headings contained herein shall not be deemed to govern, limit, modify or in any manner affect the scope, meaning or intent of the provisions of any title, chapter or section hereof. 
(Ord. 942 § 4, 1999)
1.01.050 - Reference to specific ordinances. 
    The provisions of this code shall not in any manner affect matters of record which refer to, or are otherwise connected with ordinances which are therein specifically designated by number or otherwise and which are included within the code, but such reference shall be construed to apply to the corresponding provisions contained within this code. 
(Ord. 942 § 5, 1999)
1.01.060 - Ordinances passed prior to adoption of the code. 
    The last ordinance included in this code was Ordinance 932, passed February 24, 1999. The following ordinances, passed subsequent to Ordinance 932, but prior to adoption of this code, are adopted and made a part of this code: Ordinances 933, 934, 935, 936, 937, 938, 939 and 940. 
(Ord. 942 § 6, 1999)
1.01.070 - Effect of code on past actions and obligations. 
    The adoption of this code does not affect prosecutions for ordinance violations committed prior to the effective date of this code, does not waive any fee or penalty due and unpaid on the effective date of this code, and does not affect the validity of any bond or cash deposit posted, filed or deposited pursuant to the requirements of any ordinance. 
(Ord. 942 § 7, 1999)
1.01.080 - Constitutionality. 
    If any section, subsection, sentence, clause or phrase of this code is for any reason held to be invalid or unconstitutional, such decision shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions of this code. 
(Ord. 942 § 8, 1999)
1.01.090 - References to prior code. 
    References in city forms, documents and regulations to the chapters and sections of the former city code shall be construed to apply to the corresponding provisions contained within this code. 
(Ord. 942 § 9, 1999)
Chapter 1.04 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
Sections: 

1.04.010 - Short title. 
    The ordinances embraced in this code constitute the "Tucumcari Municipal Code," and may be cited as the "Tucumcari Code." 
(Amended during 1999 codification; prior code § 1-1-1)
1.04.020 - Definitions and rules of construction. 
A.	In construing this code or any ordinance:
    "Agent" means a person acting on behalf of another. 
    "Business dealing with the public" means such solicitations and transactions regularly engaged in for monetary or other consideration, but does not mean isolated or casual business transactions in which the public is not invited or expected to participate and which are outside the scope of a person's regular business operation. 
    "The city" or "this city" means the city of Tucumcari. 
    "Code," "this code" or "Tucumcari Code" means the Tucumcari Municipal Code. 
    "Commission" means the governing body of the city of Tucumcari. 
    "County" means the county of Quay. 
    "Day" means the period of time between midnight and the midnight following. 
    "Daytime" means the period of time between sunrise and sunset. 
    "Discriminate" includes, but is not limited to separate or segregate. 
    "Employee" does not include any individual employed by his or her parent, spouse or child or in the domestic service of any person. 
    "Employer" means any person employing four or more employees in some kind of employment and any person acting in the interest of such employer, but does not include a social or fraternal club not organized for profit. 
    "Employment agency" means any person undertaking with or without compensation, to produce opportunities to work or to procure, recruit, refer or place persons for employment. 
    "Guardian" means a person having care, custody and control of another person and having the duty to manage and control the person and property of the other person. "Guardian" includes parent. 
    "Housing" includes any building, structure or portion thereof, used, occupied, intended, arranged or designed to be used or occupied as the home, residence or living quarters of one or more human beings, or any parcel of land or portion thereof, available for the construction of such building or structure. 
    "Labor organization" means any organization existing and constituted for the purposes, in whole or in part, of collective bargaining or of dealing with employers concerning grievances, terms or conditions of employment, or for other mutual aid or protection in relation to employment. 
    "Lending institution" includes any person regularly engaged in the business of lending money or guaranteeing loans. 
    "Minor" means any person under age eighteen (18) years. 
    "Month" means a calendar month. 
    "NMSA" means New Mexico Statutes Annotated. 
    "Nighttime" means the period of time between sunset and sunrise. 
    "Oath" includes an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the words "swear" or "sworn" shall be equivalent to the words "affirm" and "affirmed." 
    "Owner," when used in relation to real property, means any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership or joint tenant of the whole or of a part of such real property. 
    "Person" means any corporation, company partnership, association or society as well as a natural person. 
    "Personal property" means every species of property except real property, as herein defined. 
    "Private property" means all property not public property. 
    "Property" means real and personal, tangible and intangible property. 
    "Public property" means all property used for a public purpose or as a place of public gathering, owned or under the control of the United States, of the state or any political subdivision, or a religious, charitable, educational or recreational association. 
    "Real property" means land, tenements and hereditaments. 
    "Shall" is mandatory and "may" is permissive. 
    "State" means the state of New Mexico. 
    "Tenant" or "occupant," when applied to a building or land, includes any person who occupies the whole or a part of such building or land, whether alone or with others. 
    "Written" or "in writing" may include printing, engraving or any other mode of representing words and letters excepting those cases where the written signature or mark of any person is required. 
    "Year" means a calendar year. 
    Masculine includes the feminine. 
    Singular includes the plural. 
    Words used in the present tense include the future tense. 
    Unless otherwise provided in computing time, the first day shall be excluded and the last included unless the last falls on Sunday, in which case the time prescribed shall be extended to include the whole of the following month. 
B.	The above definitions and rules of construction apply unless otherwise provided or unless inconsistent with the intent of this code or any ordinance. 
(Ord. 932 § 3, 1999; prior code § 1-1-2)
1.04.030 - Amendments. 
    Any additions or amendments to this code shall be adopted as ordinances as required by state law, and when passed in such form as to indicate the intention to make the same a part of this code, shall be incorporated into this code so that reference to this code as the "Tucumcari Municipal Code" or "Tucumcari Code" shall be understood as including such additions or amendments. 
(Prior code § 1-1-3)
1.04.040 - Severability. 
    The provisions of this code are declared to be severable, unless otherwise stated in this code. If any section, provision, or part of this code shall be held unconstitutional or invalid, the remainder of this code shall continue in full force and effect, it being the legislative intent that this code would have been adopted even if such unconstitutional or invalid matter had not been included therein. It is further declared that if any provision or part of this code, or the application thereof to any person or circumstances, is held invalid, the remainder of this code and the application of this code to other persons shall not be affected thereby. 
(Prior code § 1-1-4)
1.04.050 - Effect of repealing ordinances. 
    The repeal of any provision of this code shall not affect any right which has accrued, any duty imposed, any penalty incurred, any action or proceedings as commended under or by virtue of the provision repealed, or the tenure of an office of any person holding office at the time when such repeal shall take effect. The repeal of any provision of this code shall not revive any provision or any ordinance theretofore repealed or superseded. 
(Prior code § 1-1-6)
1.04.060 - Violations-Prosecution. 
    Prosecution for violations of municipal ordinances prior to the effective date of this code shall be governed, prosecuted and punished under the ordinances existing at the time such crimes were committed. 
(Prior code § 1-1-9)
Chapter 1.08 - CORPORATE SEAL 
Sections: 

1.08.010 - Corporate seal. 
    The corporate seal of the municipality shall be as follows: 
    In the center, the word "Seal," around the outer edge, the words "The City of Tucumcari, New Mexico," shall be and is declared to be the official seal of the city. 
(Prior code § 1-1-7)
Chapter 1.12 - GENERAL PENALTY 
Sections: 

1.12.010 - Maximum penalty. 
    Unless a lesser maximum penalty or a specific penalty is established by ordinance for a particular offense, the maximum penalty for violation of any municipal ordinance shall be as follows: 
A.	Except for those violations of ordinances described in subsections B and C of this section, a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment for not more than ninety (90) days or both; 
B.	For violation of an ordinance prohibiting driving a motor vehicle while under the influence of intoxicating liquor or drugs, a fine of not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or imprisonment for not more than three hundred sixty-four (364) days or both; and 
C.	For violations of an industrial user wastewater pretreatment ordinance as required by the United States Environmental Protection Agency, a fine of not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) a day for each violation. 
(Ord. 932 § 4, 1999; Ord. 885 § 1, 1994)
1.12.020 - Mandatory fees collected upon conviction. 
    In addition to any fine or imprisonment described in Section 1.12.010, there is imposed upon any person convicted of violating any municipal ordinance the penalty for which carries a potential jail term or any ordinance relating to the operation of a motor vehicle the following mandatory fees: 
A.	A correction fee of twenty dollars ($20.00);
B.	A judicial education fee of two dollars ($2.00); and
C.	A court automation fee of six dollars ($6.00).
    As used in this section, "convicted" means the defendant has been found guilty of a criminal charge by the municipal judge, either after trial, a plea of guilty or a plea of nolo contendere, or has elected to pay a penalty assessment in lieu of trial. 
(Ord. 988 (part), 2003: Ord. 924 § 2, 1998; Ord. 885 § 2, 1994)
1.12.030 - Disposition and use of fees. 
A.	All money collected pursuant to Section 1.12.020(A) shall be deposited in a special fund in the municipal treasury and shall be used for: 
1.	Municipal jailer or juvenile detention officer training;
2.	The construction planning, construction, operation and maintenance of a municipal jail or juvenile detention facility; 
3.	Paying the cost of housing municipal prisoners in a county jail or detention facility or housing juveniles in a detention facility; 
4.	Complying with match or contribution requirements for the receipt of federal funds relating to jails or juvenile detention facilities; 
5.	Providing inpatient treatment or other substance abuse programs in conjunction with or as an alternative to jail sentencing; 
6.	Defraying the cost of transporting prisoners to jails or juveniles to juvenile detention facilities; or 
7.	Providing electronic monitoring system.
B.	A municipality may credit the interest collected from fees deposited in the special fund pursuant to subsection A of this section to the municipality's general fund. 
C.	All money collected pursuant to Section 1.12.020(B) shall be remitted monthly to the state treasurer for credit to the judicial education fund and shall be used for the education and training, including production of bench books and other written materials, of municipal judges and other municipal court employees. 
D.	All money collected pursuant to Section 1.12.020(C) shall be remitted monthly to the state treasurer for credit to the municipal court automation systems in the municipal courts. The court automation systems shall have the capability of providing, on a timely basis, electronic records in a format specified by the judicial information systems council. 
(Ord. 988 (part), 2003: Ord. 932 § 5, 1999; Ord. 924 § 3, 1998; Ord. 885 § 3, 1994)
1.12.050 - Citation in lieu of arrest allowed when. 
A.	The city commission finds that the adoption of procedures for issuance of citations for petty misdemeanor offenses in the city will increase the efficiency of processing violations of petty misdemeanors, reduce manpower and cost, and aid in the administration of justice. 
B.	A Tucumcari police department officer who arrests a person without a warrant for a petty misdemeanor committed in the city may, at the officer's discretion, offer the person arrested the option of accepting a citation to appear in lieu of incarceration. 
C.	A citation issued pursuant to this section shall contain the name and address of the cited person, the offense charged, and the time and place to appear. Unless the person requests an earlier date, the time specified in the citation shall be a minimum of three days after the issuance of the citation. The police officer shall explain the person's rights not to sign a citation, the effect of not signing the citation, the effect of signing the citation, and the effect of failing to appear at the time and place stated on the citation. 
D.	The person's signature on the citation constitutes a promise to appear at the time and place stated in the citation. One copy of the citation to appear shall be delivered to the person cited, and the police officer shall keep a duplicate copy which he shall file with the municipal court as soon as practicable. 
E.	A citation issued pursuant to this section is a valid complaint if the person receiving it appears in municipal court. 
F.	It is a petty misdemeanor for a person signing a citation not to appear at the time and place stated in the citation regardless of the disposition of the offense for which the citation was issued. The written promise to appear may be complied with by appearance of counsel. 
(Ord. 761 §§ 1-6, 1986)
1.12.060 - Suspension, probation and community service. 
A.	Upon a plea of guilty or a judgment of conviction for violation of a municipal ordinance, the municipal court may suspend in whole or in part the execution of sentence or place the defendant on probation for period not exceeding one year on terms and conditions the court deems best, or both. 
B.	Suspension of execution of the sentence or probation, or both, shall be granted only when the municipal judge is satisfied it will serve the ends of justice and of the public. 
C.	The defendant's liability for any fine or other punishment imposed shall be fully discharged upon successful completion of the terms of probation. 
D.	The municipal court may as a condition of probation require the defendant to serve a period of time in volunteer labor to be known as community service. The type of labor and period of service shall be at the sole discretion of the court; provided that any person receiving community service shall be immune from any civil liability other than gross negligence arising out of the community service, and any criminal diversion program shall not be entitled to any wages, shall not be considered an employee for any purpose and shall not be entitled to workmen's compensation, unemployment benefits or any other benefits otherwise provided by law. As used in this subsection, "community service" means any labor that benefits the public at large or any public, charitable or educational entity or institution. 
(Ord. 785 § 1, 1988)
1.12.070 - Restitution for damages and costs due to violation of criminal code and/or motor vehicle code. 
A.	1.	Policy and Definitions. It is the policy of this city that restitution be made by each violator of the criminal code and any article of the city relating to the operation of a motor vehicle within the activities or to the extent that the defendant is reasonably able to do so. It is the public policy of the city to: (1) make whole the victim of the crime to the extent possible; and (2) to remind the defendant of his or her wrongdoing and require him or her to repay the costs society has incurred as a result of his or her misconduct. This section shall be interpreted and administered to effectuate this policy. As used in this section unless the context otherwise requires: 
a.	"Victim" means any person or the city which represents its citizens, who has suffered actual damages as a result of the defendant's criminal activities. 
b.	"Actual damages" means all damages which a victim could recover against the defendant in a civil action arising out of the same facts or event, except punitive damages and damages for pain, suffering, mental anguish and loss of consortium. Without limitation, actual damages includes damages for the costs of incarceration including but not limited to the costs of medical care. 
c.	"Criminal activities" includes any crime for which there is a plea of guilty or verdict of guilty, upon which a judgment may be rendered and any other crime committed after August 1, 1994 which is admitted or not contested by the defendant. 
d.	"Restitution" means full or partial payment of actual damages to a victim or the city.
2.	If the municipal court exercises its sentencing options, the court may require as a condition of release or probation that the defendant, in cooperation with the court, promptly prepare a plan of restitution, including a specific amount of restitution to each victim and a schedule of restitution payments. If the defendant is presently unable to make any restitution but there is a reasonable possibility that the defendant may be able to do so at some time during his or her probation period, the plan of restitution shall also state the conditions under which or the event after which the defendant will make restitution. If the defendant believes that he or she will not be able to make any restitution, he or she shall so state and shall specify the reasons. If the defendant believes that no person suffered actual damages as a result of the defendant's activities, he or she shall so state. 
3.	The defendant's plan of restitution shall be submitted promptly to the court. The court shall promptly enter an order approving, disapproving or modifying the plan, taking into account the factors enumerated in subsection (A)(4) of this section. Compliance with the plan of restitution as approved by the court shall be a condition of the defendant's release or probation. Restitution payments shall be made to the city clerk unless otherwise directed by the court. The court thereafter may modify the plan at any time upon the defendant's request or upon the court's own motion. 
4.	The court when determining or reviewing the defendant's plan of restitution shall consider the physical and mental health and condition of the defendant his or her age, his or her education, his or her employment circumstances, his or her potential for employment and vocational training, his or her family circumstances, his or her financial condition, the number of victims, the actual damages of each victim, what plan of restitution will most effectively aid the rehabilitation of the defendant and such other factors as shall be appropriate. 
5.	The clerk of the court shall mail to each known victim a copy of the court's order approving or modifying the plan of restitution. 
6.	Failure of the defendant to comply with subsection (A)(2) of this section or to comply with the plan of restitution as approved may constitute violation of the conditions of release or probation. 
7.	This section and proceedings under this section shall not limit or impair the rights of victims to recover damages from the defendant in a civil action. However, any restitution payment by the defendant to a victim shall be set off against any judgment in favor of the victim in a civil action arising out of the same facts or event. 
B.	Disposition and Use of Fees Collected. All restitution collected shall be deposited in a special restitution fund in the municipal treasury and shall be used only for the payment of costs expended on behalf of the city or victim. 
C.	Lien and Foreclosure. The reasonable costs to the city in the direct and indirect enforcement of the law against the defendant shall constitute a lien against the real property owned by the defendant. The lien may be foreclosed in the manner provided in Sections 3-36-1 through 3-36-6 NMSA 1978. 
(Ord. 889 §§ 1-3, 1994)
1.12.080 - Incarceration. 
A.	Notwithstanding any other provision of this municipal code, any person upon whom any fine or penalty is imposed may, upon order of the court convicting him or her, be committed to the county jail, municipal jail, detention facility, or other place provided by the city of Tucumcari for the incarceration of offenders until the fine or penalty is paid in full. The period of incarceration shall not exceed sixty (60) days for any one offense except as authorized in subsection C of Section 3-17-1, NMSA, 1978. 
    Every person so committed shall work for the municipal corporation, and such labor as his or her strength will permit, within or without the jail or other place provided for the incarceration, not exceeding ten (10) hours each working day. Each offender shall be credited with eight times the federal minimum wage per day in reduction of any fine. 
    The municipal judge shall impose court costs and fees as provided in Section 35-14-11 for any conviction of person who violates municipal ordinances as provided herein. 
(Ord. 1030, 2006)
Title 2 - ADMINISTRATION AND PERSONNEL 
Chapters: 
Chapter 2.04 - CITY COMMISSION 
Sections: 

2.04.010 - Meetings-Time and place. 
    The commission shall meet in regular session at the city commission chambers on the second and fourth Thursday of every month at 6:00 p.m. If such meeting falls on a holiday, the meeting shall be held on an agreed upon date which is not a holiday. The commission will hold quarterly town hall meetings for public input. 
(Ord. 966 § 1 (part), 2002: Ord. 932 § 6, 1999: prior code § 2-1-1)
(Ord. No. 1101, § 1, 4-27-2012)
2.04.020 - Special meetings. 
    The commission may also hold special meetings at City Hall or at some other public place in the city specified in the call for said meetings. Special meetings may be called by the mayor or by any city commission member. 
(Ord. 943 § 1, 1999; prior code § 2-1-2)
2.04.030 - Recessed meetings. 
    The commission may also meet in recessed meetings at City Hall or at some other public place in the city at the time and place designated by the commission for said recessed meetings. 
(Prior code § 2-1-3)
2.04.040 - Meetings-Attendance. 
    The attendance at meetings by the mayor and other commissioners of the city may be compelled as provided by state law or by ordinances of the city, or may be compelled by order of the majority of the commission requiring the chief of police or any city policeman to require and compel the attendance at meetings by the mayor and other city commissioners. 
(Prior code § 2-1-4)
2.04.050 - Designation of liaison with board and commission. 
    Commissioners shall be designated as a liaison to the following city advisory boards: one commissioner shall be designated as a liaison to the recreation advisory board, one to the library advisory board, one to the planning and zoning board, one to the lodgers' tax advisory board, one to the museum advisory board, one to the economic development corporation, one to the senior advisory board, one to the golf course advisory board, and one to the cemetery advisory board. 
(Ord. 943 § 2, 1999: prior code § 2-1-6)
(Ord. No. 1101, § 2, 4-27-2012)
2.04.060 - Vacancies. 
A.	Except as provided in subsection B of this section, if a vacancy occurs in the commission, the remaining elected and appointed commissioners shall, by a majority vote, appoint a qualified elector to fill the vacancy until the next regular municipal election, or any special election called in accordance with subsection B of the section, at which time a qualified elector shall be elected to fill the remaining unexpired term, if any. 
B.	A special election, for the purpose of filling a vacancy on the governing body, may be called by the chairman, with the consent of the governing body or by the governing body. 
(Prior code § 2-1-7)
2.04.070 - Election districts. 
    The City of Tucumcari is hereby divided into five districts for the purpose of electing commissioners therein, as provided by Section 3-14-6 NMSA 1978. Said districts shall be bounded and described as follows: 
District No. 1: 
Starting at the intersection of South Ninth Street and West Hancock Avenue, along South Ninth Street to West Laughlin Avenue, then along West Laughlin Avenue to the midpoint of West Laughlin Avenue between South Sixth and Seventh Streets, then from the midpoint of West Laughlin Avenue between South Sixth and Seventh Streets to the midpoint of West McGee Avenue between South Sixth and Seventh Streets, then along West McGee Avenue to South First Street, then along South First Street to East Laughlin Avenue, then along East Laughlin Avenue to South Monroe Street, then along South Monroe Street to West Main Street, then along West Main Street to North College Street, then along North College Street to East Heman Avenue, then along East Heman Avenue to U.S. Highway 54, then along U.S. Highway 54 to the City Limits, then along City Limits to South Fifteenth Street, then along West Railroad Avenue to South Tenth Street, then along South Tenth Street to West Hancock Avenue ending at the intersection of West Hancock Avenue and South Ninth Street. 
District No. 2: 
Starting at the intersection of East Tucumcari Blvd. and South First Street, along South First Street North to East Laughlin Avenue, then along East Laughlin Avenue East to South Monroe Street, then along South Monroe Street to East Main Street, then along East Main Street to North College Street, then along North College Street to East Heman Avenue, then along East Heman Avenue East to U.S. Highway 54, then along U.S. Highway 54 to the City Limits, then along City Limits follow East Tucumcari Blvd., then along East Tucumcari Blvd. to South First Street ending at the intersection of First Street and East Tucumcari Blvd. 
District No. 3: 
Starting at the intersection of South Third Street and West Charles Avenue, along West Charles Avenue to South Fifth Street, then along South Fifth Street to West Crestview Drive, then along West Crestview Drive to South Sixth Street, then along South Sixth Street to South Seventh Street, then along South Seventh Street to the West Charles Avenue, then along West Charles Avenue to City Limits, the along City Limits follow West Railroad Avenue, then along West Railroad Avenue to South Tenth Street, then along South Tenth Street to West Hancock Avenue, then along West Hancock Avenue to South Ninth Street, then along South Ninth Street to West Laughlin Avenue, then along West Laughlin Avenue to the midpoint of West Laughlin Avenue between South Sixth and Seventh Streets, then from the midpoint of West Laughlin Avenue between South Sixth and Seventh Streets to the midpoint of West McGee Avenue between South Sixth and Seventh Streets, then along West McGee Avenue to South First Street, then along South First Street to West Barnes Avenue, then along West Barnes Avenue to South Third Street ending at the intersection of South Third Street and West Charles Avenue. 
District No. 4: 
Starting at the intersection of East Charles Avenue and South Third Street, along South Third Street North to West Barnes Avenue, then along West Barnes Avenue to East Barnes Avenue, then along East Barnes Avenue to South First Street, then along South First Street North to East Tucumcari Blvd., then along East Tucumcari Blvd. to City Limits, then along City Limits to East Charles Avenue ending at the intersection of South Third Street and East Charles Avenue. 
District No. 5: 
Starting at the intersection of West Charles Avenue and South Seventh Street, along West Charles Avenue to City Limits, then along City Limits to East Charles Avenue, then along East Charles Avenue to South Fifth Street, then along South Fifth Street to West Crestview Drive, then along West Crestview Drive to South Sixth Street, then along South Sixth Street to South Seventh Street ending at the intersection of West Charles Avenue and South Seventh Street. 
(Ord. 969 § 2 (part) 2002: Ord. 932 § 7, 1999: prior code § 2-1-8)
(Ord. No. 1101, § 3, 4-27-2012)
2.04.080 - Annual salary. 
    The municipal mayor shall receive an annual salary of five thousand eight hundred dollars ($5,800.00) per year. 
    The municipal commissioner shall receive an annual salary of four thousand six hundred dollars ($4,600.00) per year. 
(Ord. 1055 § 1, 2007)
(Ord. No. 1129, § 1, 12-3-2015)
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1129, adopted Dec. 3, 2015, shall become effective after the 2016 Municipal Election. 
Chapter 2.08 - CITY MANAGER 
Sections: 

2.08.010 - Appointment and qualifications. 
    The commission shall appoint by a majority vote of all members a city manager for an indefinite term of office and whose salary shall be fixed by the commission. The manager shall be appointed solely on the basis of administrative qualifications and his or her selection shall not be limited by reason of former residence. 
(Prior code § 2-2-1)
2.08.020 - Powers and duties. 
    The city manager shall be responsible to the governing body for the proper and efficient administration of the municipal government. 
    The city manager shall: 
A.	Be chief administrative officer of the city;
B.	Enforce and carry out all ordinances, rules and regulations enacted by the commission;
C.	Employ, promote, suspend and discharge (subject to the provisions of Chapter 2.64) all persons, including department heads, engaged in the administrative service of the city; 
D.	Prepare and submit to the commission an annual budget;
E.	Submit recommendations to the commission on all matters concerning the welfare of the city; and 
F.	Have a seat, but no vote, at every meeting of the commission.
    Except when clearly undesirable or unnecessary, the commission shall request the opinion of the city manager on any proposed measure considered by the commission. 
    The city manager may hold other nonelective offices of the city, including the offices of city clerk and treasurer. 
(Prior code § 2-2-2)
2.08.030 - Vacancy in office or absence from the city. 
    If a vacancy occurs in the office of city manager as a result of death, disability, resignation or removal of the city manager, the commission may appoint a person to serve as acting city manager for a period of time not to exceed ninety (90) days. If the city manager is to be absent from the municipality for a period of more than seventy-two (72) consecutive hours, he or she shall designate an employee of the administrative service to act in his or her stead. Such designation shall be in writing and shall be filed in the office of the city clerk. 
(Prior code § 2-2-3)
2.08.040 - Removal. 
    By a majority vote of all the members of the commission, the city manager may be removed from office. 
(Ord. 932 § 8, 1999: prior code § 2-2-4)
2.08.050 - Delivery of records. 
    Any city manager who resigns or is removed from office shall immediately deliver to the city clerk all money, records, property or other things in his or her charge and belonging to the city. 
(Prior code § 2-2-5)
Chapter 2.12 - CITY CLERK 
Sections: 

2.12.010 - Clerical officer of the commission. 
    The clerk shall: 
A.	Keep in custody all minutes, ordinances and resolutions approved by the commission;
B.	Attend all meetings of the commission;
C.	Record all proceedings, ordinances and resolutions of the commission;
D.	Furnish copies of municipal records upon request.
    The clerk may charge a reasonable fee for the cost of furnishing copies of municipal records. 
(Prior code § 2-3-1)
2.12.020 - Appointment. 
    The clerk shall be appointed by the manager for an indefinite term, and removable by the manager. 
(Prior code § 2-3-2)
Chapter 2.16 - CITY TREASURER 
Sections: 

2.16.010 - Appointment. 
    The treasurer is an officer of the city. He or she shall be appointed by the manager for an indefinite term, and is removable by the manager. The treasurer shall serve within the finance department and the same person may hold both the office of clerk and the office of treasurer. 
(Ord. 932 § 9, 1999; prior code § 2-4-1)
2.16.020 - Powers and duties. 
    The treasurer shall: 
A.	Deposit daily all funds coming into his or her hand in such depositories as the commission may designate; 
B.	Disburse such funds in the manner provided by applicable law or ordinance; and
C.	Have such other powers, duties and functions as may be prescribed by applicable law or ordinances. 
(Prior code § 2-4-2)
Chapter 2.20 - MUNICIPAL COURT AND JUDGE 
Sections: 

2.20.010 - Jurisdiction-Location-Presiding officer. 
    The municipal court as established by Section 35-14-1 NMSA, 1978, as amended, has exclusive original jurisdiction over all offenses and complaints under the code or ordinances of the city and may issue subpoenas and warrants and punish for contempt. The court shall be located in quarters provided by the commission and shall be presided over by the municipal judge. 
(Amended during 1999 codification; prior code § 2-5-1)
2.20.020 - Municipal judge-Election. 
    The municipal judge shall be elected as provided by law. Any vacancy shall be filled by the mayor with the advice and consent of the commission. 
(Prior code § 2-5-2)
2.20.030 - Municipal judge-Qualifications. 
    The municipal judge shall be a registered, qualified elector of the city. 
(Prior code § 2-5-3)
2.20.040 - Municipal judge-Bond and oath. 
    The municipal judge shall, before he or she enters the duties of office, if no corporate surety bond covering all municipal officials exists, execute a surety bond to the city in the amount of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) conditioned upon the faithful performance of his or her duties and the paying over to the city of all fines, forfeited bonds and other money which comes into his or her hands by virtue of his or her office as required in Section 35-14-3 NMSA, 1978. 
(Amended during 1999 codification; prior code § 2-5-4)
2.20.050 - Municipal judge-Temporary incapacity or absence. 
    The mayor with the advice and consent of the commission shall designate three qualified electors of the city as alternate municipal judges, one of whom shall serve as acting municipal judge during the vacation, temporary absence, unavailability or incapacity of the municipal judge. The municipal judge before absenting himself or herself shall select, or upon his or her failure to select, the mayor shall select, one designee from those set forth above to serve as temporary municipal judge to exercise all powers of the municipal judge until the return of the municipal judge. The alternate municipal judge shall be compensated as follows: twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per day for each day that he or she serves for court appearances, and fifteen dollars ($15.00) per day for warrant standby. 
(Ord. 932 § 10, 1999; Ord. 791, 1988: Ord. 786 (part), 1988: prior code § 2-5-5)
2.20.060 - Municipal judge-Salary. 
    The municipal judge shall receive an annual salary of fifteen thousand seven hundred and ninety dollars ($15,790.00) per year. 
(Ord. 963 § 1, 2002: Ord. 927 § 1, 1998: Ord. 816 (part), 1990: prior code § 2-5-6)
(Ord. No. 1069, § 1, 7-23-2009; Ord. No. 1128, § 1, 12-3-2015)
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1128, adopted Dec. 3, 2015, will become effective Mar. 8, 2016. 
2.20.070 - Traffic fines payable to clerk. 
    The municipal judge shall designate the specific offenses under the traffic code of the city, the fines for which may be accepted by the desk sergeant or police department clerk upon a plea of guilty and shall specify by suitable schedule the amount of such fines. 
(Prior code § 2-5-7)
2.20.080 - Records to be kept. 
    The municipal judge shall keep or cause to be kept a record of every traffic complaint, uniform traffic citation and other form of traffic charge filed in his or her court and every official action and disposition of the charge by his or her court. Within ten days after disposition of every charge of violating the traffic code of the city, the municipal judge shall upon forms furnished by the commissioner of motor vehicles prepare, certify as correct, and forward to the State Department of Motor Vehicles an abstract of record. A report need not be made of any conviction involving illegal parking or standing of a vehicle except when a uniform traffic citation is used. When the uniform traffic citation is issued the form of the abstract on the back of the officer's first copy containing the above information shall be used. 
(Prior code § 2-5-8)
2.20.090 - Municipal judge-Duties. 
    In addition to those duties set forth in the laws of the state of New Mexico, the municipal judge shall hold court once each day at eight a.m. on Mondays through Fridays inclusive and shall hold court on the first and third Wednesdays of each month at three p.m. The municipal judge shall also fix the amount of bail for any person arrested for the violation of this code or any city ordinance and also shall fix the amount of bond on appeals to the district court from convictions for violations of this code or any city ordinance, the amount of the bail to be in the discretion of the municipal judge. This authority shall be in addition to the authority given to the desk sergeant or clerk at the Tucumcari police department to fix bail for any person arrested for violation of a city ordinance and when the municipal judge is not available to set bail for a prisoner. The municipal judge shall also set the day and time on which the person arrested and for whom bail is fixed in which to appear before the municipal judge for trial. This authority and duty is in addition to that granted to the desk sergeant or clerk at the Tucumcari police department. 
(Ord. 932 § 11, 1999; Ord. 786, 1988: prior code § 2-5-9)
2.20.100 - Failure to appear. 
    The municipal judge or police officer herein mentioned fixing bail shall set the day and time on which the person arrested and for whom bail is fixed in which to appear before the municipal judge for trial, and any person failing to appear on the day and time stated shall forfeit the bond to the city, and further, may be fined by the municipal judge in a sum of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or be imprisoned in the city jail for not more than ninety (90) days, or be punished by both such fine and imprisonment in the discretion of the court. 
(Ord. 932 § 1 (part), 1999; prior code § 2-5-10)
2.20.110 - Municipal judge-Failure to comply. 
    The failure or refusal of the municipal judge to comply with the provisions of this code shall constitute misconduct in office and grounds for removal from office. 
(Prior code § 2-5-11)
Chapter 2.28 - FIRE DEPARTMENT 
Sections: 

2.28.010 - Established-Personnel. 
A.	A fire department of the city is established and shall consist of a chief, two assistant chiefs, secretary, training officer and fire fighters. The total number of fire fighters including the officers of the department shall not exceed twenty (20). 
B.	The chief shall be appointed by the city manager for an indefinite term and shall be removable by the manager. 
(Prior code § 6-1-1)
2.28.020 - Duties. 
    It shall be the duty of the fire department to: 
A.	Extinguish fires;
B.	Rescue persons endangered by fire;
C.	Resuscitate and administer first aid to persons injured in or about burning structures, or elsewhere, in case of emergencies; 
D.	Promote fire prevention; and
E.	Unless otherwise provided, enforce all ordinances and regulations relating to fires, fire prevention, and safety of persons from fire in theatres, stores and other buildings open to the public. 
(Prior code § 6-1-2)
2.28.030 - Promulgation of regulations. 
    The commission, by motion or resolution, may adopt and change regulations governing the organization and operation of the fire department. The manager, at any time, may recommend such regulations to the commission, and any changes therein which he or she deems desirable. 
(Prior code § 6-1-3)
2.28.040 - Fire chief-Duties. 
    The chief shall: 
A.	Be the director of the fire department;
B.	Be accountable to the manager for the personnel, morale and general efficiency of the department; 
C.	Direct the operations and have administrative supervision and control of the fire department, subject to the rules and regulations thereof; 
D.	Supervise the manner of handling fires personally whenever possible in order to minimize injury to persons and damage to property. During the progress of a fire the authority of the fire chief in all matters connected with the management or direction thereof, or the disposition of property endangered by it, shall be absolute. All orders issued by him or her on such occasions shall be respected, and any fire fighter or citizen refusing to obey the same is guilty of a misdemeanor; 
E.	Conduct suitable drills or instruction in the operation and handling of equipment, first aid, rescue work and salvage; conduct a study of buildings in the municipality, establishment of fire zones, water supplies and all other matters generally considered essential to adequate fire protection and safety of life and property from loss by fire; 
F.	Assist the proper authorities in suppressing the crime of arson by investigating or causing to be investigated the cause, origin, and circumstances of all fires; 
G.	Inspect buildings and premises and serve written notice upon the owner or occupant to abate, within a specified time, any and all fire hazards that may be found. For the purpose of conducting such inspection, the chief or fire marshal may enter any and all buildings and premises within the municipality at any reasonable hour. Any person served with a notice to abate any fire hazard shall comply therewith and promptly notify the chief of the remedial measure taken; 
H.	Keep complete records of all fires, inspections, apparatus and equipment, personnel and other information concerning operations of the department. He or she shall furnish the council with such information when requested, and his or her records shall be open to public inspection at all reasonable times; 
I.	Make a complete annual report, to the commission within two months after the close of the calendar year, together with comparative experience data for the previous year with any recommendations for improving the effectiveness of the department; 
J.	Demote, dismiss or expel any officer or member of the department for neglect or refusal to perform departmental duties, subject to the rights of any members so demoted, dismissed, or expelled as provided in Title 2 of this code; 
K.	Enforce or cause to be enforced all ordinances, laws and regulations of the city and state, insofar as they pertain to fire and safety; 
L.	Appoint the assistant chiefs from the membership of the department.
(Ord. 943 § 5, 1999; prior code § 6-1-4)
2.28.050 - Fire fighters. 
A.	Qualifications and Appointment. Fire fighters shall be appointed at such time, and in such manner, as the commission may deem necessary. Such appointees shall be able-bodied citizens residing within the city limits, preferably property owners whose business activities are normally within the confines of the municipality, and who have telephones in their homes. 
B.	Duty of Members. It shall be the duty of all members of the department under the control and direction of the proper officers thereof, upon an alarm of fire being given, to go to the place of such fire in the city and there to work and manage the fire apparatus under the direction of the chief or other officer being in control. The members shall not retire therefrom except by permission of the officer having chief control. Thereafter, the members of the department shall return all apparatus to its place of keeping and then and there leave the same properly housed and in condition ready for immediate use. The chief of the fire department is authorized to suspend any member refusing to obey orders or for misconduct or for failure to perform his or her assigned duties at any fire or for failure to attend departmental meetings and he or she shall make a report of his or her action to the city manager for his or her further action thereon. 
(Prior code § 6-1-5)
2.28.060 - Interference with fire department. 
    It is unlawful for any person or persons to hinder, delay or obstruct any member of the fire department while in the performance of his or her duties at any fire. No person shall place on or about any fire hydrant any rubbish, building materials, fence or other obstruction of any character or hitch to any fire hydrant any animal or animals or fasten to any such hydrant any guy rope, wire or brace or otherwise interfere with the fire department in the discharge of its duties. 
(Prior code § 6-1-6)
2.28.070 - Entry on adjacent property. 
    It shall be lawful for any fire fighter acting under the direction of the chief or another officer in command to enter upon the premises adjacent to or in the vicinity of any building or other property that is on fire, for the purpose of extinguishing such fire, and no person shall hinder, resist or obstruct any fire fighter in the discharge of his or her duty as hereinbefore provided. 
(Prior code § 6-1-7)
2.28.080 - Equipment. 
    The department shall be equipped with such apparatus and other equipment as may be required from time to time to maintain its efficiency and provide adequate fire protection. Recommendations for acquisition of necessary equipment and facilities shall be made by the chief, and after approval by the council, shall be purchased pursuant to the Public Purchases Act. 
    All equipment of the department shall be safely and conveniently housed in such a place or places as may be designated by the commission. No person shall use any fire apparatus or equipment for any private purpose, nor shall any person wilfully take away or conceal any article used in any way by the department. No person shall enter any place where fire apparatus is housed or handle any apparatus or equipment belonging to the department unless accompanied by, or having special permission of an officer or authorized member of the department. No fire apparatus or equipment shall be hired out or permitted to leave the fire station except in response to a call for aid at a fire within the corporate limits of the city, or in response to a call for aid at a fire within a fire district described in Section 2.28.090. 
(Prior code § 6-1-8)
2.28.090 - Agreements with fire districts. 
    The commission may from time to time enter into agreements, for the joint use of facilities, buildings and equipment, with fire districts organized under the laws of the state. 
(Prior code § 6-1-9)
2.28.100 - Fire protection outside the city. 
    The city is authorized to enter into agreements or contracts to furnish fire protection outside the municipality or to enter into mutual aid agreements. The members of the fire department are authorized and directed to render fire fighting service to communities, organizations, owners or occupants of premises outside the corporate limits of the city. Such service shall only be rendered subject to the terms of the agreement or contract entered into by the city. 
(Prior code § 6-1-10)
2.28.110 - Vehicles of fire fighters. 
    Each member of the department is authorized to have one vehicle owned by him or her designated as an "authorized emergency vehicle" pursuant to Section 66-7-6 NMSA 1978. Each member of the department owning a car, upon designation of the car in writing, shall be issued suitable insignia to be attached to the car. The driver of an authorized emergency vehicle shall operate such vehicle in compliance with Section 66-7-6 NMSA 1978. No person shall drive any vehicle over fire hose except from specific orders from the chief or other officer in charge where the hose is used. 
(Amended during 1999 codification; prior code § 6-1-11)
2.28.120 - Fire alarms. 
    Suitable alarm systems, arrangements or equipment shall be provided for use in turning in an alarm, and for alerting department members to report to duty stations. It is unlawful for any person to maliciously turn in or cause to be turned in a false alarm. 
(Prior code § 6-1-12)
2.28.130 - Compensation. 
    All volunteer fire fighters of the city shall be compensated according to the rates established by the city commission. 
(Ord. 932 §§ 12, 28 (part), 1999; prior code § 6-1-13)
Chapter 2.36 - LIBRARY DEPARTMENT 
Sections: 

2.36.010 - Tucumcari Public Library-Established. 
    The name of the municipal library for the city of Tucumcari, New Mexico shall be the Tucumcari Public Library, in memory of Kenneth Schlientz. The name may be abbreviated to "Tucumcari Public Library" for the purpose of all legal documents. 
(Ord. 976 (part), 2003: Ord. 960 (part), 2001)
2.36.020 - Library board-Appointment and terms. 
    For the purpose of protecting the interests of all of the citizens of the city of Tucumcari and for advancing and promoting the education and general welfare of such citizens, it is declared necessary that a Tucumcari Public Library board be created to advise in the operation and management of the Tucumcari Public Library. The city commission, the governing body of the city of Tucumcari, New Mexico, shall appoint the advisory board consisting of six appointed members. Four of the appointed members shall be responsible residents of the city of Tucumcari, all will be appointed for terms of one, two, three, and four years, respectively. A fifth member shall be a responsible resident of the city of Tucumcari or the county of Quay and shall be appointed by the city commission for a term of four years. When the terms of the original members expire, the city commission shall appoint a successor for each for a term of four years. A resident of Quay County shall serve as a sixth member of the board with the term of one year, appointed by the Quay County commission, subject to approval by the commission of the city of Tucumcari. Quay County shall have the right to appoint a member to the Public Library board, so long as the county of Quay, New Mexico, allocates money to the Tucumcari Public Library. 
(Ord. 1039 § 1, 2006: Ord. 976 (part), 2003: Ord. 960 (part), 2001: Ord. 921 § 1, 1997: Ord. 852 § 1, 1992) 
2.36.030 - Library board-Advisory duties. 
    The Tucumcari Public Library board shall act in an advisory capacity and shall advise the city commission in every possible way to insure the efficient and economical management of the Tucumcari Public Library. 
(Ord. 976 (part), 2003: Ord. 960 (part), 2001: Ord. 921 § 3, 1997: Ord. 852 § 3, 1992)
2.36.040 - Board meetings. 
    The Tucumcari Public Library board shall have a regular meeting each month at a time and place to be selected by the board and announced pursuant to the state of New Mexico Open Meetings Act. 
(Ord. 976 (part), 2003: Ord. 960 (part), 2001: Ord. 921 § 4, 1997: Ord. 852 § 4, 1992)
2.36.050 - Board secretary-Reporting duties. 
    The board shall appoint a secretary from among its members, who shall keep minutes of the meeting of the board. The board, or its secretary, shall report, by way of its monthly minutes, all business matters with reference to the operation and management of the library to the city commission at least one time per month at a regular meeting of the city commission. 
(Ord. 976 (part), 2003: Ord. 960 (part), 2001: Ord. 921 § 5, 1997: Ord. 852 § 5, 1992)
2.36.060 - Conflicting prior ordinances. 
    All ordinances or parts of ordinances codified in this chapter, previously enacted and in conflict herewith, are repealed. 
(Ord. 976 (part), 2003: Ord. 960 (part), 2001)
2.36.070 - Severability. 
    If any part of the ordinance codified in this chapter is declared invalid, it shall not affect the validity of the remainder of the provisions contained herein. 
(Ord. 976 (part), 2003: Ord. 960 (part), 2001)
2.36.080 - Execution. 
    The ordinance codified in this chapter shall take effect five days after final publication following final passage date herein. 
(Ord. 976 (part), 2003: Ord. 960 (part), 2001)
Chapter 2.40 - POLICE DEPARTMENT 
Sections: 

2.40.010 - Purpose. 
    There is established the authority to organize a Tucumcari reserve police force in order to assist in the betterment of the city and the better protection of persons and property of the city at a very low cost. 
(Ord. 675 § 1, 1980)
2.40.020 - Use of reserve officers. 
    Reserve officers shall be utilized for the following departmental duties: 
A.	Patrol: accompanying regular officers on patrol;
B.	Assistance with ambulance driving on regular runs;
C.	Assistance to radio dispatcher;
D.	Handle routine duties in order to free regular officers for other calls.
(Ord. 675 § 2, 1980)
2.40.030 - Number of reserve officers. 
    The police reserve shall be limited to ten persons initially consisting of nine reserve patrol officers and one reserve detective. Number of officers may be increased to a maximum total reserve force of twenty (20) officers upon recommendation by the chief of police and approval of the city manager. 
(Ord. 675 § 3, 1980)
2.40.040 - Reserve officers-Authority. 
    A reserve officer shall have the full authority of a regular officer while accompanying or under the direct supervision of a certified officer. This authority shall include the right and responsibility for the utilization of appropriate firearms when absolutely necessary. 
(Ord. 675 § 4, 1980)
2.40.050 - Reserve officers-Training. 
    Reserve officers shall receive training consisting of classroom and field instruction in police and medical operations, law, court procedure, fire arm safety, traffic control, self defense, arrest and detention and criminal investigations. 
(Ord. 675 § 5, 1980)
2.40.060 - Reserve officers-Minimum hours. 
    Reserve officers shall be required to work a minimum of sixteen (16) hours monthly including training time and shall be expected to respond when called in an emergency. 
(Ord. 675 § 6, 1980)
2.40.070 - Reserve officers-Regulations and chain of command. 
A.	Reserve officers shall obey and adhere to the same manual of regulations and code of conduct as regular officers and shall be subject to the same disciplinary actions. 
B.	Chain of command for reserve officers shall be the following:
1.	Regular officer with whom reserve officer is accompanying;
2.	Shift sergeant or detective sergeant;
3.	Police captain;
4.	Chief of police.
(Ord. 675 § 7, 1980)
2.40.080 - Selection of reserve officers. 
    Reserve officers shall be selected for service in the same manner as regular officers. 
(Ord. 675 § 8, 1980)
Chapter 2.44 - STREET DEPARTMENT 
Sections: 

2.44.010 - Street superintendent. 
    There shall be a street department of the city. The street superintendent shall be the director, or head, of the street department and shall be appointed by the manager for an indefinite term, and removable by the manager. The street superintendent shall have administrative supervision and control of the street department. 
(Prior code § 14-1-1)
2.44.020 - Duties. 
    It shall be the duty of the street department, among others, to: 
A.	Construct, repair, maintain and improve streets, alleys and other public ways;
B.	Collect and dispose of garbage and other refuse.
(Prior code § 14-1-2)
Chapter 2.48 - RECREATION BOARD 
Sections: 

2.48.010 - Establishment-Membership-Terms of office. 
    For the purpose of creating a supervised recreation system in the city, there is established a city recreation board composed of seven members. Members of the board will be appointed by the city commission, the governing body of the city of Tucumcari, after receiving recommendations for appointment from the existing board. These appointed members shall be responsible citizens, and residents of the city. The first members of the board shall be appointed for the following terms: three members shall be appointed for terms of two years, three members shall be appointed for terms of three years, and the seventh member shall be a senior citizen appointed for a term of two years. Thereafter, the members of the board shall be selected in the same manner as the member he or she is succeeding and the term of office shall be three years. 
    Persons appointed to the board shall serve as a member until the expiration of the term. However, an appointed board member who fails to attend two consecutive meetings, without a valid reason, shall be replaced by a new member. 
    The board shall elect a chair and a vice-chair who will serve for a calendar year next succeeding his or her election. 
(Ord. 1042 § 1, 2006: Ord. 897 § 1, 1995)
2.48.020 - Meeting times. 
    The recreation board shall meet once each quarter of the calendar year. Emergency meetings may be called should business come up that needs immediate attention or approval from the board. 
(Ord. 897 § 2, 1995)
2.48.030 - Powers and duties. 
    The Tucumcari recreation board shall recommend to the city commission suitable rules and regulations for the city recreation facility, to insure the proper operation of a supervised recreation system. These regulations shall be for all city-owned and -operated city recreation facilities, including all playgrounds and ballpark facilities. The board shall make budget recommendations to the city commission. The minutes of the recreation board will be taken and maintained by city staff persons, and presented to the city commission for their acknowledgement. 
(Ord. 897 § 3, 1995)
Chapter 2.49 - TUCUMCARI MEMORIAL PARK CEMETERY ADVISORY BOARD 
Sections: 

2.49.010 - Tucumcari memorial park cemetery advisory board, appointment and terms. 
    For the purpose of protecting the interest of the operations of the city of Tucumcari memorial park cemetery, it is hereby declared necessary that a Tucumcari memorial park cemetery advisory board be created to advise in the operation of the Tucumcari memorial park cemetery. The mayor of the city of Tucumcari, New Mexico, with the approval of the city commission shall appoint the advisory board consisting of five appointed members. The appointed members shall be responsible residents of Quay County, New Mexico, with three or more of the members residing within the city of Tucumcari, and shall be appointed for terms of one and two years respectively. When the terms of the original members expire, the mayor with the advice of the city commission shall appoint a successor for each for a term of two years. 
(Ord. No. 1081, § 2, 12-9-2010; Ord. No. 1087, § 2, 2-24-2011)
2.49.020 - Tucumcari memorial park cemetery advisory board duties. 
    The Tucumcari memorial park cemetery advisory board shall act in an advisory capacity and shall advise the city commission in every possible way to insure the efficient and economical operation of the Tucumcari memorial park cemetery. 
(Ord. No. 1081, § 2, 12-9-2010; Ord. No. 1087, § 2, 2-24-2011)
2.49.030 - Board meetings. 
    The Tucumcari memorial park cemetery advisory board shall meet on a monthly basis at a time and place to be selected by the advisory board. Special meetings of the Tucumcari memorial park cemetery may be called by the chairman or a quorum of the board. All meetings shall be announced pursuant to the State of New Mexico Open Meetings Act. 
(Ord. No. 1081, § 2, 12-9-2010; Ord. No. 1087, § 2, 2-24-2011; Ord. No. 1097, § 1, 11-17-2011) 
2.49.040 - Organization, quorum, records of proceedings. 
    The Tucumcari memorial park cemetery advisory board shall elect from among its members a chairman, vice-chairman and secretary. The terms of the chairman, vice chairman and secretary shall be for a term of one year. The secretary shall keep minutes of the meetings of the board. The board, or its secretary, shall report by way of its minutes, all business matters with reference to the operation of the Tucumcari memorial park cemetery to the city commission. A quorum of the board shall consist of three members. 
(Ord. No. 1081, § 2, 12-9-2010; Ord. No. 1087, § 2, 2-24-2011)
Chapter 2.52 - TUCUMCARI SENIOR CITIZEN'S ADVISORY BOARD 
Sections: 

2.52.010 - Tucumcari senior citizen's advisory board, appointment and terms. 
    For the purpose of protecting the interest of all of the senior citizens of the city of Tucumcari and for advancing and promoting the quality of life and general welfare of such citizens, it is hereby declared necessary that a Tucumcari senior citizen's advisory board be created to advise in the operation and of the Tucumcari senior citizen's center. The mayor of the city of Tucumcari, New Mexico, with the approval of the city commission shall appoint the advisory board consisting of seven appointed members, one of which shall represent the Foster Grandparent's Program; and one of which shall represent the Senior Companion Programs, as long as funding is received for these two programs. Six of the appointed members shall be responsible residents of the city of Tucumcari. A seventh member shall be a responsible resident of the city of Tucumcari or the county of Quay and shall be appointed by the city commission. The appointed members shall be responsible residents of the city of Tucumcari, and shall be appointed for terms of one and two years respectively. When the terms of the original members expire, the mayor with the advice of the city commission shall appoint a successor for each for a term of two years. 
(Ord. 1043 § 1, 2006: Ord. 1003 §§ 1, 2 (part), 2005)
(Ord. No. 1082, § 2, 12-9-2010)
2.52.020 - Tucumcari senior citizen's advisory board duties. 
    The Tucumcari senior citizen's advisory board shall act in an advisory capacity and shall advise the city commission in every possible way to insure the efficient and economical operation of the Tucumcari senior citizen's center. 
(Ord. 1003 §§ 1, 2 (part), 2005)
(Ord. No. 1082, § 2, 12-9-2010)
2.52.030 - Board meetings. 
    The Tucumcari senior citizen's advisory board shall meet on a monthly basis at a time and place to be selected by the advisory board. Special meetings of the senior citizen's advisory board may be called by the chairman or a quorum of the board. All meetings shall be announced pursuant to the State of New Mexico Open Meetings Act. 
(Ord. 1003 §§ 1, 2 (part), 2005)
(Ord. No. 1082, § 2, 12-9-2010)
2.52.040 - Organization, quorum, records of proceedings. 
    The Tucumcari senior citizen's advisory board shall elect from among its members a chairman, vice-chairman and secretary. The terms of the chairman, vice chairman and secretary shall be for a term of one year. The secretary shall keep minutes of the meetings of the board. The board, or its secretary, shall report by way of its minutes, all business matters with reference to the operation of the Tucumcari senior citizen's to the city commission. A quorum of the board shall consist of three members. 
(Ord. 1003 §§ 1, 2 (part), 2005)
(Ord. No. 1082, § 2, 12-9-2010)
Chapter 2.56 - MUSEUM BOARD 
Sections: 

2.56.010 - Purpose. 
    For the purpose of conserving the property and promoting and advancing the public welfare of the citizens of the city, it is declared necessary that a city museum board be created to advise in the operation and management of the Tucumcari Historical Museum. 
(Ord. 814 § 1, 1990)
2.56.020 - Appointment-Terms of office. 
    The city commission, the governing body of the city of Tucumcari, shall appoint a nonpartisan board to consist of seven members, to be known as the city museum board. The first members of the board shall be appointed for the following terms: three for terms of one year each and four for terms of two years each. Thereafter, upon expiration of the term of each member of the board, his or her successor shall be appointed for a term of two years in the manner hereinbefore provided. Board members who fail to attend three meetings without cause shall be taken off the board. 
    All members of the museum board may be appointed from recommendations made by the Tucumcari Historical Research Institute to the city commission. 
(Ord. 1040 § 1, 2006: Ord. 814 §§ 2, 3 1990)
2.56.030 - Duties. 
    The city museum board shall act in an advisory capacity and shall advise and assist the city commission in every possible way to insure efficient and economical management of the Tucumcari Historical Museum. This to include the entire budget process. 
(Ord. 814 § 4, 1990)
2.56.040 - Meetings. 
    The museum board shall meet every other month on a day and at a time to be decided by the board, in the Tucumcari Historical Museum building and at such other times as in the judgement of the board may be necessary and advisable, usually meeting to follow the Tucumcari historical society. It will be the duty of the board to assist and advise the city commission in establishing policies concerning the operation and management of the Tucumcari Historical Museum. 
(Ord. 814 § 5, 1990)
2.56.050 - Officers of the board. 
    The board shall appoint, from among its members, a chair and also a secretary who shall keep minutes of the meetings of the board and shall prepare and furnish copies of the minutes of such meetings to the city clerk's office for the information of the city commission. 
(Ord. 814 § 6, 1990)
2.56.060 - Compensation. 
    Members of the city museum board shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. 814 § 7, 1990)
Chapter 2.60 - CIVIL DEFENSE 
Sections: 

2.60.010 - Department of emergency management-Established. 
    There is established under the executive branch of the government of the municipality of Tucumcari in accordance with Chapter 12, Articles 10-1 through 10-10 NMSA 1978, as amended, (being laws 1959, Chapter 190, as amended) a department of emergency management, which shall consist of: 
A.	A coordinator of emergency management who shall be appointed by the governing body of the city and subject to approval by the State Director; 
B.	All other municipal officers and employees, together with those volunteer forces enrolled to aid them during periods of emergency, shall be considered as part of the emergency management organization of the municipality of Tucumcari. 
(Ord. 943 § 8 (part), 1999; Ord. 879 § 1, 1994)
2.60.020 - Purpose of emergency management organization. 
    The purpose of the emergency management organization is to develop and implement the municipal emergency management program and to coordinate the efforts of all municipal agencies and employees and nongovernmental agencies to prepare for and function in the event of emergencies endangering the lives and property of the citizens of the municipality of Tucumcari, New Mexico. It shall be the duty of the organization to coordinate the development of comprehensive emergency management plans for the effective employment of municipal resources to protect the lives and health of the citizens of Tucumcari, New Mexico and the private and public property therein from the effects of natural or man-caused emergency events, including acts of war, and to coordinate the implementation of such plans during periods of emergency. Such plans shall be coordinated with those of Quay County, and in consonance with the state emergency management plans. 
(Ord. 943 § 8 (part), 1999; Ord. 879 § 2, 1994)
2.60.030 - Emergency management coordinator. 
    The emergency management coordinator shall be responsible to the city manager for the organization, administration and operation of the emergency management program of the municipality of Tucumcari, New Mexico.
