The coordinator shall coordinate the emergency management activities of all municipal departments and agencies and nongovernmental agencies (when the city has jurisdiction), and shall maintain liaison with and cooperate with the emergency management agencies of the federal government, the state of New Mexico and other political subdivisions therein. 
    The coordinator shall develop an organizational structure for the department, subject to the approval of the city manager and governing body. 
(Ord. 943 § 8 (part), 1999; Ord. 879 § 3, 1994)
2.60.040 - Appropriation of funds. 
    Funds for necessary expenses and functions of the department of emergency management, including salaries for approved paid positions, shall be made available through appropriations by the municipal council in accordance with Section 12-10-7, NMSA 1978, as amended (being Laws 1959, Chapter 190, as amended). 
    The coordinator shall prepare and submit to the council an annual proposed budget for emergency management expenditures and functions and shall indicate therein those amounts eligible for matching funds under the federal emergency management assistance program. Emergency management funds may be obligated by the coordinator only in the amounts appropriated and for the purposes authorized by the municipal council. 
(Ord. 943 § 8 (part), 1999; Ord. 879 § 4, 1994)
Chapter 2.64 - PERSONNEL[1] 
Sections: 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note-Ord. No. 1114, § 1, adopted Aug. 14, 2014, amended Ch. 2.64 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Ch. 2.64, §§ 2.64.010-2.64.550, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. 1062, § 1, adopted 2008; and Ord. No. 1086, § 1, adopted Jan. 13, 2011.

2.64.005 - Definitions and acronyms. 
1.	Scope. Definite rules and regulations cannot be readily formulated for every possible problem and situation. This ordinance serves as a general basis and guide for the proper, efficient, and effective administration of personnel matters for the city of Tucumcari. The rules contained herein replace and supersede all previously issued personnel rules and regulations applicable to employees of city of Tucumcari, including, but not limited to the city of Tucumcari Personnel Ordinance 1062, Chapter 2.64 of the Tucumcari Municipal Code Pertaining to Personnel, effective April 12, 1990, and all amendments and regulations related thereto. 
2.	Amendment of Policy. The city commission reserves the right to amend these personnel policies and procedures at its discretion. 
3.	Pronouns. All pronouns used in this personnel policy manual shall include the masculine and feminine, and shall include the singular and plural, and the context of this personnel policy manual shall be read accordingly. 
4.	Department Head. Management-level official responsible for overseeing one of the city's functional departments and who has supervisory authority over the department. The city commission may create and eliminate city departments as dictated by the needs of the city. A list of the current departments of the city is available from the director of human resources. 
5.	Earned Leave. Refers to that leave which is earned and accrued by employees on a periodic basis through the payroll process as described in this personnel policies and procedures, and is a benefit of employment. Annual leave and sick leave are considered earned leave. 
6.	Elected Official. Mayor, city board of commission member(s).
7.	Employer. The city government and its subsidiary organizations and enterprises.
8.	Employee. A person who is hired to perform work for the city and receives compensation for work performed. The term "employee" does not include persons who are independent contractors, bona-fide volunteers, bona-fide trainees (receiving stipend payments), prisoners, or elected officials (who receive fee payment, honorarium, travel compensation, etc.). 
9.	Immediate Family Member. The employee's father, mother, brother, grandparents, sister, spouse, child, grandchild, father-in-law, mother-in-law, son-in-law, daughter-in-law, stepparents, step-children and step-brother and sister. Also includes a non-biological child through adoption or other legal guardianship. 
10.	Non-Immediate Family Member. Members of the employee's extended family not qualified as an immediate family member, including the employee's spouse's grandparents, and the employee's uncle, aunt, nephew and niece and other step-relatives not listed above. 
11.	Reasonable Cause. Specific and articulable facts and inferences that would lead a reasonable person to believe that an employee 1) has contraband in their possession, 2) is under the influence of alcohol or illegal substances, 3) is using an illegal substance(s), or 4) is misusing prescription drugs. 
12.	Supervisor. As used in this policy, a generic term for a management employee who is responsible for assigning, directing, coordinating and monitoring an employee's functional services, daily work activities, and performance and who has the authority to recommend the hire, administer corrective discipline and recommend discharge of an employee. 
13.	City. City of Tucumcari, New Mexico Government, a political sub-division of the state of New Mexico; established August 5, 1908. 
14.	Visitors. Those who are not employees of the city, including employees' families or friends, vendors, consultants, and clients. 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
Article 1. - Employment 

2.64.010 - Equal employment opportunity. 
    It is the policy of the city of Tucumcari that every hiring and promotion opportunity will be filled by the best qualified applicants, based exclusively on job-related qualifications without regard to race/color, national origin, sex, religion, age or any other non-job related criteria. The city provides equal employment opportunity to all applicants for employment and employees, and will not discriminate on the basis of race/color, national origin, sex (gender, sexual orientation and pregnancy), religion, retaliation (on the basis of a person opposing an unlawful employment practice), age, veteran status, or disability in any decision regarding consideration for employment, duration of employment, training opportunities, transfer or promotion opportunities, salary, benefits or any other terms and conditions of employment. It is the goal of the city to comply with the requirements of equal employment opportunity as established by federal and state law. 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
2.64.020 - Reasonable accommodation. 
    It is the policy of the city of Tucumcari to provide reasonable accommodation for any person who is an employee or an applicant for employment who has or who acquired a physical or mental impairment (e.g. any physiological disorder, disfigurement or anatomical loss or limitations, or any mental or psychological disorder acquired as a result of illness, accident or birth) as defined by state and/or federal law as having an impairment which limits one or more major life activities, but whose experience, education and/or training enable the person to perform the essential functions of the job. 
    Position descriptions will be developed for every position employed by the city. The position description will define the essential functions, elements and tasks of the position as well as the environment in which the job activities are performed. 
    It is the responsibility of the employee to request a reasonable accommodation from the employee's department head and the human resources department. 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
2.64.030 - Competitive hiring: Recruitment, selection and appointment. 
    It is the policy of the city to hire the best qualified candidates for employment with the goal of continuously improving the city's operations, improving citizens' satisfaction with the quality of services provided by the city, and otherwise place applicants in jobs that best suit their abilities, interests and skills. 
    When a position vacancy occurs, the human resources director and the city manager's office will conduct a recruiting and selection process designed to identify the best qualified and most suitable individual for the position, unless compliance with the law or these personnel policies and procedures requires otherwise. Current city employees desiring to fill a vacant position shall be required to complete an application and shall participate competitively in the selection process. 
    It is the general policy of the city to accept the employment application as the only official instrument for employment consideration with the city. Résumés and other similar candidate profiles may be submitted but they will not replace the requirement of an official employment application signed by the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
2.64.040 - Ineligibility. 
    Applicants or employees will be considered ineligible for hire or rehire by the city of Tucumcari if the applicant/employee has: 
1.	Made any false statement or omitted any relevant information on the application for employment. 
2.	Not met the requirements of the position.
3.	Failed to successfully complete the pre-employment screening process.
4.	Not been certified by a physician that the applicant can perform the physical requirements of the position. 
5.	Been previously dismissed from city employment as a result of a disciplinary matter or failure to successfully complete the introductory period. 
6.	Not a legal resident of the United States.
7.	Been convicted of a felony or misdemeanor under the provisions of the Criminal Offender Employment Act NMSA 1978, 10-1-3 (1987 Repl. Pamp.) 
8.	Not met the criteria for bonding if required by the position.
9.	Has had a DWI, felony conviction and/or reckless driving within the past three years.
    The city manager has at his or her discretion the ability to waive any or all the above elements of ineligibility and to extend the probationary period to twelve (12) months for employees hired under this criteria. 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
2.64.050 - Hiring: Temporary and casual employment. 
    In order to have the necessary flexibility in staffing to meet department demands, seasonal or cyclical fluctuations in workload, to temporarily replace employees absent due to termination or extended leave, or to complete special short-term projects, the city manager may hire an employee through a non-competitive selection process for a temporary or a "casual" job assignment. (See also: Section 2.64.090 Employment classifications.) 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
2.64.060 - Hiring: Appointed employees. 
    Appointed official, i.e., the city manager, is recruited, selected and hired through a process determined at the sole discretion of the board of commissioners at the time of recruitment. 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
2.64.070 - Pre-employment screening. 
    The city of Tucumcari is committed to a policy of hiring the best qualified available candidate to fill vacant city staff positions. To accomplish that goal, once the best qualified candidates for a position have been identified, the city will conduct pre-employment screening of those candidates in accordance with the procedure described below. 
    All applicants selected for hire shall complete a pre-existing condition form pursuant to the worker's compensation statutes, NMSA 1978, § 52-1-1 et seq. 
    The human resource department will conduct a pre-employment screening on every candidate prior to an offer of employment. The nature of pre-employment screening performed will vary depending on the requirements of the position being filled; certain positions have more stringent requirements than others. Uncertified or certified by waiver candidates for law enforcement positions will be required to successfully pass a physical agility test prior to employment. Every candidate selected for hire is required to pass a pre-employment drug test prior to employment (See: Drug and alcohol-free workplace section). The cost of pre-employment screening will be paid by the department that seeks to employ the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
2.64.080 - Probationary period. 
    Every newly hired employee will serve a probationary period. The purpose of the probationary period is to give the supervisor the opportunity to evaluate the employee's suitability, potential and performance in the position and to provide the employee the opportunity to decide if he or she is satisfied with the position. 
    The probationary period for employees, except those hired as non-certified police officers, is the first one hundred eighty (180) calendar days of continuous employment. During this time, all employees are on an introductory status, are terminable at will, and do not have access to the grievance resolution procedure. With the approval of the city manager, the probationary period for an individual employee may be extended for up to an additional ninety (90) calendar days. 
    Employees cannot avail themselves of the grievance resolution procedure set forth herein with relation to discipline or termination while serving the probationary period. 
    The probationary period for an employee hired as a non-certified police officer recruit will be extended as necessary to include the employee's training at the law enforcement academy. A recruit who fails to earn certification at the completion of training within the one-year period required under New Mexico law will be released from employment for failure to successfully complete the probationary period. A recruit who successfully completes his or her training at the academy and attains certification will serve an additional 180-day probationary period beginning on the date of certification. A recruit may be terminated from employment for any reason while serving the probationary period. 
    Any break in service or position transfer within the city shall require completion of a new probationary period upon rehire. 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
2.64.090 - Employment classifications. 
    This policy establishes employment classifications in order to determine proper compensation administration, working hour requirements, eligibility for benefits, and the application of other city policies. 
    The employment classification of each position within the city will be established by the city manager's office, based upon the specific job duties and responsibilities. More than one status may apply to an individual employee. 
RegularRegular employees are hired through the competitive hiring process to fill a position with a term greater than four months. Regular employees can work either full-time or part-time and are eligible for employee benefits as described in the personnel policies and procedures.TemporaryTemporary employees are hired to fulfill specific requirements for limited periods of time not to exceed four months unless extended by the city manager for another ninety (90) days. Temporary employees can work on a part-time or full-time basis, are terminable at-will, cannot avail themselves of the grievance resolution procedures set forth herein, do not receive city benefits and do not accrue leave. CasualCasual employees are hired to fulfill specific requirements for limited hours of work on an intermittent basis over an extended period of time. Casual employees work on a part-time basis not to exceed nineteen (19) hours in any one work week, on an intermittent basis, over a period of a year or more, are terminable at-will, cannot avail themselves of the grievance resolution procedures set forth herein, do not receive city benefits and do not accrue leave. AppointedThe city manager is an appointed employee of the city. The city manager is recruited, selected and hired through a process determined at the sole discretion of the board of commissioners at the time of recruitment. The city manager is terminable at will and cannot avail themselves of the grievance procedures set forth herein, but are entitled to all other benefits provided by the city in accordance with the personnel policies and procedures, except as stated otherwise. Full-timeFull-time employees are normally scheduled to work forty (40) hours per week or more. They are eligible for all employee benefits. Part-timePart-time employees are normally scheduled to work fewer than forty (40) hours per week. Part time employees accrue sick and annual leave at a reduced rate (see: Annual leave section). SalariedSalaried employees are paid a fixed salary amount for all hours worked in a pay period and perform work that is considered exempt under the provisions of the Federal Fair Labor Standards Act. They are not eligible for overtime pay for hours worked in excess of forty (40) in a work week. HourlyHourly employees are paid a specific rate for every hour worked. Employees in this category are non-exempt under provisions of the Federal Fair Labor Standards Act and are eligible to be compensated for hours worked in excess of forty (40) in a work week. ContractContract employees are employees who are covered by the terms and conditions of their specific employment contracts. In all cases where the personnel policies and procedures herein conflict with an employment contract, the terms and conditions of the specific employment contract shall prevail. MinorsRefer to conditions stated at 2.64.130.  
    All classification changes must be authorized on a personnel action form (PAF) with proper signatures and submitted to the human resources so that a record is maintained in the personnel file. Employees shall report any name changes or changes of address to human resources as soon as possible. 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
2.64.100 - Transfers and promotions. 
    In order to provide management the flexibility to accomplish department/program goals and objectives, and to give current employees the opportunity to apply their experience and education to a different position or to achieve a promotion, the city of Tucumcari may transfer employees to other duties in the department/program, or between departments with the approval of the city manager. No employee has a right to any particular position within city employment. The city manager may transfer an employee without loss of pay for any reason, and that employee has no right to avail himself of the grievance resolution procedures. 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
2.64.110 - Outside employment. 
    To give employees the opportunity to earn additional income without disrupting their employment with the city, breaching the conflict of interest policy or any other policies herein, the city of Tucumcari has a policy to allow employees to engage in outside employment under certain conditions. 
    An employee may engage in outside employment. However, no employee may engage in outside employment, which, in any manner, interferes with proper and effective job performance, results in a conflict of interest or may subject the city to public criticism or embarrassment. Employees engaged in or wishing to engage in outside employment must first have the written approval of their immediate supervisor and the city manager. A request that is denied is not grievable. 
    Employees may engage in outside voluntary activities that are on an unpaid basis, so long as those activities do not represent a conflict of interest, impair their ability to perform their work, or employ city assets and resources. 
1.	No employee may engage in outside employment while absent from work using any leave benefits (other than annual leave), without prior written approval from the supervisor. 
2.	The employee may not make material changes to such outside employment without the approval of their immediate supervisor and the city manager. 
3.	An employee, who engages in outside employment without approval may be subject to corrective disciplinary action up to and including discharge. 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
2.64.120 - Nepotism. 
    Nepotism, the showing of favoritism or giving preferential treatment to near relatives or to unrelated persons who are cohabiting based upon that relationship rather than on an objective evaluation of ability or suitability, resulting in actual or perceived preferential treatment in the hiring, appointment, pay, promotion, transfers, benefits and management of family members is prohibited. "Near relatives" for purposes of this policy are defined as: employee's spouse or ex-spouse, children, parents, siblings, grandparents, grandchildren, aunts, uncles, first cousins, and like relations of the employee's spouse. This definition includes any person related to the employee by birth, adoption, or marriage. This includes any person who would fall under the above definition if the persons who are cohabiting were in fact married. 
    Near relatives will not be hired into a department where the employee directly supervises or is supervised by another immediate family member. 
    Employees will not influence or participate in the hiring, promotion, transfers or management of near relatives. If an employee is scheduled to be part of a panel interview for a near relative, the employee will decline his/her involvement. The supervisor will provide a substitute for that employee for that particular panel interview. 
    If employees become near relatives after employment and a conflict of interest or management problems of supervision, safety, security or morale result; or, if a government operations reorganization creates such a conflict, reasonable time may be provided to resolve the matter. If a resolution is not possible, the city may require one of those employees to be transferred or laid-off. 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
2.64.130 - Employment of minors. 
    As a general rule, employees of the city must be eighteen (18) years of age or older. Occasionally, the city may hire students or others who are as young as fourteen (14) years old, but this is done only under special conditions, usually under the provisions of a grant agreement, and must be approved by the city manager's office. In no case will minors be permitted to work in any occupation declared to be hazardous or detrimental to their health or well-being by the U.S. Secretary of Labor. 
    Minors younger than eighteen (18) years of age must provide a signed parental permission form to the city in order to work, including a parental permission for the provision of emergency medical care. 
  Minors who are sixteen (16) or seventeen (17) years old may perform any non-hazardous job for unlimited hours. 
  When school is in session, fourteen (14) and fifteen (15) year olds may work up to three hours per day on school days, including Fridays; they cannot work more than eighteen (18) hours per week in school weeks; more than eight hours a day on non-school days; or more than forty (40) hours per week when school is not in session. 
  Fourteen (14) and fifteen (15) year olds may not work before 7:00 a.m. or after 7:00 p.m., except from June 1 through Labor Day when their permissible hours are extended to 9:00 p.m. Under a special provision, fourteen (14) and fifteen (15) year olds who are enrolled in an approved Work Experience and Career Exploration Program may be employed for up to twenty-three (23) hours during school weeks and three hours on school days (including during school hours). 
    Wages and/or stipends will be determined as provided in the grant agreement and approved by the city manager's office. 
    Students and/or minors who hold stipend assignments must satisfy the training program requirements of the position and the conduct of the services to ensure compliance with the associated regulations for stipends. All other positions for students are considered employment and associated tax withholding will be maintained. 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
2.64.140 - Reduction-in-force (RIF). 
    If it becomes necessary for the city to reduce the number of city employees because of economic conditions, termination of a grant, organizational changes, lack of funds, lack of work or other circumstances the supervisor may implement adjustments in staff levels by means of a personnel RIF. 
    Before instituting a RIF, the supervisor, department head, human resources department and city manager will explore reasonable possibilities for reassignment of affected employees and will consider requirements to maintain the city's operations. 
    Selection of employees to be RIF'd will be done without regard to the employee's race/color, national origin, sex (gender, sexual orientation and condition of pregnancy), religion, age, disability, or any status protected by law. 
    The city manager's office and/or human resources department will provide assistance throughout the RIF process to accomplish any possible inter-department transfers of personnel and communication. The city manager shall have final approval on all RIF. 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
Article 2. - Compensation 

2.64.150 - Compensation administration. 
    No employee will be paid less than the applicable legal minimum wage. 
    The city strives to pay salaries that are internally and externally equitable, and to provide fair and competitive pay for work performed. In order to accomplish this goal, each job, or position within the city of Tucumcari has been formally described in a written position description that describes in summary form the purpose of the position, the essential duties and responsibilities of the position, the supervision given and received, the minimum qualification standards that must be met by a candidate for employment to be hired for the position, the physical demands of the position and the typical work environment experienced when performing the work. 
    Based on the position description, each position has been evaluated on objective factors with consideration given to current competitive labor-market conditions and assigned to a pay grade, which establishes the value of the position in relation to other positions in the organization. 
    Starting Salary. Determination of the specific starting salary will be based on previous experience, knowledge, skills, abilities and education. Consideration must also be given to current employees in the position, their experience, qualifications and pay. Internal fairness is important, to reflect comparable pay for comparable skills, responsibilities and objectives. 
    Starting salaries will be determined in consultation with the city manager prior to making the job offer. 
    Wage Increase. Through the city's annual budgeting process, depending on the availability of funds, the board of commissioners may approve a wage increase for all employees. When such an increase is approved, it will become effective for each employee after final budget approval of the department of finance administration and the city manager. Employees on probation may be eligible for a wage increase upon completion of the probationary period, with the city manager's approval. 
    Performance Based Increase. Performance based Increases are related to the achievements and contributions of the employee as determined during the annual performance evaluation (See Section 2.64.160 Employee performance appraisal section), along with business considerations and conditions; budgetary constraints will also affect such decisions. 
    Performance based increases, if awarded, are generally provided for in amounts determined through the city's annual budgeting process. When budgeted funds are available, the supervisor may recommend a salary increase by completing a recommendation form and submitting it along with a copy of the employee's performance appraisal form to the city manager for approval. Compensation changes will generally be effective on the first pay period following the city manager's approval. 
    Certification Increases. Employees who receive approved certifications for their department will receive a five percent increase effective at the start of the next pay period, following submittal to the human resources department. 
    Promotional Increases. When an employee is transferred or promoted, salary changes associated with the move are generally granted immediately upon the effective date of the change of position (See Transfers and promotions section). The amount of a compensation adjustment is determined by the city manager in comparison to other incumbents for internal equity and the budget for compensation approved for the department concerned. 
    Employees who are placed in an "interim" or "acting" position are not automatically entitled to an increase in salary. This decision will be made by the city manager on a case-by-case basis. If the employee receives an increase, it will be considered temporary and will cease with the conclusion of the interim appointment. Loss of an interim appointment and any raise in pay accompanying the appointment are considered temporary and are not grievable. The interim employee retains whatever employment status he or she had prior to the appointment to an interim position. 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
2.64.160 - Employee performance evaluations. 
    It is the policy of the city that each employee's job performance will be evaluated formally on an annual basis. Evaluations are conducted by the employee's supervisor. The performance evaluation will be conducted objectively and constructively on the basis of departmental and program mission, goals and objectives, position responsibilities and the employee's annual performance plan (see procedure). The employee's performance evaluation is the most important consideration when decisions regarding performance based merit increases are made. Evaluations do not automatically result in salary increases. No discussion of compensation will occur during the performance evaluation. All employees will receive a formal performance review upon the successful completion of their introductory period and annually thereafter on their anniversary date. (See Compensation administration section) 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
2.64.170 - Work schedule. 
    The city of Tucumcari's normal workday is 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. with one hour for lunch. Other regular hours may be established by the city manager or upon request from the department head to meet the department's needs. Once established, the work schedule will be adhered to on a consistent basis. 
    Lunch breaks and other office absences are to be coordinated with other staff and management when necessary, to maintain coverage of services. Employees who work an eight-hour day will have two fifteen-minute breaks each day; one break will be scheduled at mid-morning and the second will be scheduled at mid-afternoon. 
    The scheduling of break and meal periods is the responsibility of the supervisor, who will ensure that proper coordination occurs so that business operations are maintained. 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
2.64.180 - Pay period, work week and paycheck. 
    Employees of the city of Tucumcari are paid every two weeks on the Friday following the end of the pay period. The payroll period consists of two consecutive work weeks. If a payday falls on one of the holidays observed by the city of Tucumcari, employees will receive pay on the last working day before the holiday. 
    The work week of the city of Tucumcari consists of seven consecutive 24-hour periods beginning at 12:01 a.m. on Tuesday and ending at 12:00 midnight on the following Monday. 
    All employee paychecks will be distributed through direct deposit. Employees will designate, on a form provided by the human resource department, the bank and the account number(s) where they want their paycheck deposited. Employees may change their designated bank and account(s) at any time by contacting the human resource department and completing another form. 
    If an employee discovers an error in their paycheck, he or she must notify their supervisor immediately. The supervisor will investigate the error and contact the payroll office. The payroll office will review the information and make any necessary adjustments. Adjustments will generally be made on the next paycheck. If no adjustment is necessary, an explanation will be provided to the employee. 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
2.64.190 - On-call and call-back pay. 
    Some employees of the city, by the nature of their duties, are on-call to respond to emergencies that may arise outside of normal working hours. Employees will be notified of their on-call status by their supervisor. On-call employees are required to report to the scene of the emergency within thirty (30) minutes of being called. Other response requirements may be established by the supervisor and approved by the department head to meet the needs of specific departments. On-call employees will be provided a cell phone to be used while on-call. 
    Hourly employees required to be on call for five consecutive days shall receive eight hours of compensation at their applicable overtime rate of pay. 
    Hourly employees who are called back to work outside of their regular work day will be paid for all hours actually worked at their regular rate of pay, unless they qualify for overtime, for which they will be paid time and a half. 
    If no work is available after an employee responds to a call, the employee will receive not less than one hour's pay for responding. 
    Failure of the on-call employee to respond to a call may result in corrective disciplinary action up to and including discharge. 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
2.64.200 - Timekeeping. 
    All employees are required to complete a time sheet for each week of work, including exempt employees. The time sheets are to be completed showing all actual hours worked, and all compensated time-off such as annual leave, sick leave, holiday, etc. The time sheet will be signed by both the employee and the supervisor. 
1.	Employees are responsible for submitting accurate time sheets, including all annual leave, holiday or other paid/unpaid leave forms taken in a pay period. Falsifying any time record is prohibited. 
2.	Employees will sign their own time sheet for each pay period and give it to their supervisor. An employee is not permitted to record time for another employee. Any employee intentionally reporting time not worked whether for himself or for another employee will be subject to discipline up to and including discharge. 
3.	Supervisors will review their employees' time sheets for accuracy and sign them before forwarding them to the payroll office. 
4.	Time sheets are due in the payroll office by Monday at 12:00 noon after the end of the pay period. When one of the holidays observed by the city falls on a date the time sheet is due, the time sheet due date will be moved ahead by one working day. The city manager's office will provide advance notice of changes in the time sheet due date. 
5.	Exempt employees will keep track of their hours so that the city can keep a record of the employee's use of sick and annual leave. An exempt employee who takes leave of less than four hours at a time will not lose compensation as a result. Time off in excess of four hours shall be designated as sick or annual leave, as appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
2.64.210 - Overtime. 
    Overtime for purposes of this policy is defined as those hours worked in excess of forty (40) in any one work week by an hourly (non-exempt) employee. 
    All overtime must be approved by the employee's supervisor before the work is performed. Failure to obtain authorization to work overtime may be grounds for disciplinary action. Overtime work should not be approved unless funds are available. (See also: Section 2.64.220 Compensatory time off section.) 
    Overtime compensation, unless compensatory time-off is offered (see below) will be paid to hourly employees, according to the following: 
  Hourly employees will be paid one and one-half times their regular hourly rate for hours worked in excess of forty (40) in one work week. 
  The minimum overtime that will be compensated is fifteen (15) minutes. 
  Only hours actually worked will be used to calculate overtime pay. Paid time off for annual leave, sick leave, jury duty, management initiated work release, or any other type of leave will not be considered as "hours worked." 
  Overtime for hourly paid police officers, fire fighters, paramedics and EMTs will be calculated based on the special rules provided for these occupations by the U.S. Department of Labor and the provisions of Section 7(k) of the U.S. Fair Labor Standards Act. 
  Premium pay for overtime will not be pyramided. An hour compensated at the overtime premium rate will not be counted again for the payment of premium pay for any other reason. 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
2.64.220 - Compensatory time-off. 
    At the discretion of the supervisor, hourly employees may be granted paid time off (compensatory or "comp" time) in lieu of receiving pay for overtime worked. 
Procedure: 
1.	When it is necessary that an employee work overtime (see overtime policy), the supervisor may choose to compensate the employee for the overtime worked by granting compensatory time off in lieu of overtime pay. 
2.	Compensatory time earned will be reported on the employee's time sheet submitted for the week. 
3.	When granted, compensatory time will be earned at the rate of one and one-half hours for each hour of overtime worked. 
4.	Hourly paid police officers, fire fighters and emergency medical personnel may accrue a maximum balance of two hundred forty (240) hours of compensatory time. All other hourly employees may accrue a maximum balance of one hundred twenty (120) hours of compensatory time. 
5.	Compensatory time off may be used in the same manner as annual leave (See Section 2.64.280 Annual leave section). 
6.	Unused accumulated compensatory time off will be paid out to the employee when his or her employment terminates. 
7.	Compensatory time-off cannot be transferred to another employee.
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
2.64.230 - Pay for travel time. 
    All payments of per diem and mileage allowance to city employees will be made pursuant to policies established by the state of New Mexico. In no event shall any mileage be paid for travel by a city employee in connection with the employee's regular job duties within the boundaries of the city of Tucumcari without the express written consent of the department head. 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
2.64.240 - Termination administration. 
    It is the policy of the city of Tucumcari to administer terminations of employment consistently and ensure that terminating employees receive required benefit continuation notifications and a timely issuance of their final paycheck and accrued benefits. Termination includes voluntary resignations and disciplinary discharge. Two consecutive days of failing to report for work without notification to the supervisor will be treated as a voluntary resignation (see: Attendance section). 
    When an employee resigns from employment, the employee shall give at least two weeks advance notice to their immediate supervisor to ensure the timely processing of the termination and issuance of a final payroll check. Failure to provide advance notice may preclude the re-hiring of the employee in the future. 
    The city reserves the right to accelerate the final day of employment when accepting an employee's resignation, but the employee will be paid through the resignation date or the actual last day of work, whichever is later. 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
2.64.250 - Payroll deductions. 
    The city is required by federal and state law to make certain deductions or withholdings from employee pay. Only the deductions required by law, or city policy, or authorized by the employee, will be made from payroll checks. Such deductions may include, but are not limited to, the following: 
  Federal Income Tax Act (FITA). 
  Federal Insurance Contributions Act (FICA); Social Security and Medicare. 
  State Income Taxes. 
  Group Insurance Premium if applicable, or other insurance selected by the employee. 
  Public Employees Retirement Association Contributions. 
  Public Employees Retiree Health Care. 
  Other Reimbursements as permitted by law. 
  Wage Garnishments (tax levies, marital settlement agreements, child support, etc.). 
  Other deductions, as requested by the employee and approved by the city manager or required by law or city policy. 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
Article 3. - Attendance and Time-Off 

2.64.260 - Attendance. 
    Unexpected absences from work and tardiness in reporting to work disrupt the city's ability to deliver the high quality of service its citizens expect. In order to minimize these disruptions in service delivery and to ensure a productive and efficient work effort the city has established the following attendance policy and procedures. 
    When unexpected situations come up occasionally, which may require an employee to be absent from work, the employee must notify their supervisor within thirty (30) minutes of their regularly scheduled starting time that he or she cannot report for work or needs to leave the worksite early. Notification to a person other than the immediate supervisor, when that supervisor is at work, is not acceptable and is cause for disciplinary action up to and including discharge in the rare instances when employees are unable to report to work as scheduled, or know they will be late, they must notify their supervisor within thirty (30) minutes of the start of the regularly scheduled work day. If an employee must leave work early, they must notify their supervisor as soon as possible. 
    Irregular attendance, excessive absenteeism, repeated tardiness or absence without notice is cause for disciplinary action up to and including discharge. 
    If an employee is unable to provide notice, the employee is responsible for having someone do it for them. When calling in absent, every employee must: 
a.	State the reason for the absence (personal, illness, transportation, etc.).
b.	Leave a phone number where he or she can be reached.
c.	Notify the supervisor when they can be expected to report back to work.
d.	Employees will maintain daily contact with their supervisor for any period of absence beyond one day, unless he or she has provided a health care provider's certification covering a specified period. 
    All personal and health care provider appointments should be scheduled whenever possible to accommodate the city's established working hours. 
    An employee who is absent for two consecutive work days without providing proper notice is considered to have voluntarily resigned his or her job. 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
2.64.270 - Holidays and holiday pay. 
    The city observes the following full-day holidays and half-day holidays per year. The city commission may declare additional days to be observed as city holidays to commemorate special events. The designated holidays are: 
New Year's Eve (December 31st) (Half-Day) 
New Year's Day (January 1st) 
Martin Luther King Day (3rd Monday in January) 
President's Day (3rd Monday in February) 
Good Friday (Half-Day) 
Memorial Day (Last Monday in May) 
Independence Day (July 4th) 
Labor Day (1st Monday in September) 
Veterans' Day (2nd Monday in November) 
Thanksgiving Day (4th Thursday in November) 
The Day after Thanksgiving Day 
Christmas Eve Day (December 24th) 
Christmas Day (December 25th) 
    When a holiday falls on a Sunday, it is officially observed the following Monday. When a holiday falls on a Saturday, it is officially observed on the preceding Friday. Employees eligible for the holiday pay benefit will receive holiday pay at their regular straight time hourly rate for a maximum of four hours on half-day holidays and eight hours on full day holidays. Part-time employees will receive holiday pay at a regular rate of fifty (50) percent per recognized holiday. 
    Hourly employees required to work on an official city holiday will be paid at regular time, unless they qualify for overtime. 
    Casual and temporary employees are not entitled to holiday pay. 
    In order to receive pay for a holiday an employee must have worked on their last regularly scheduled day of work preceding the holiday and their next regularly scheduled day of work following the holiday. Paid leave scheduled in accordance with the city's leave policy will satisfy this requirement. 
    If a regularly scheduled holiday falls during an employee's requested annual leave time, the day will be paid as a holiday and not as annual leave. 
    An employee who terminates employment or commences an unpaid leave of absence on the last scheduled workday preceding a holiday will not receive holiday pay. 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
2.64.280 - Annual leave. 
    The city of Tucumcari provides its employees the opportunity to earn paid time off from work in the form of an annual leave benefit. Annual leave is earned on a pro-rata basis each pay period. 
General Provisions 
    Annual leave must be approved by the employee's supervisor before being taken. 
    Hourly employees may use annual leave in hourly or daily increments. Salaried employees may use annual leave in half- or full-day increments. 
    Annual leave time-off will not be granted in advance of accrual. 
    Employees will be paid for unused accrued annual leave upon termination. Pay will be computed based on the rate earned by the employee at the time of termination. Annual leave accrued during the probationary period will not be paid to an employee terminated during the probationary period. 
Annual Leave Accrual 
    Full-time hourly employees are eligible to accrue 3.7 hours of annual leave per pay period, for an annual total of 96.2 hours until they have reached their tenth anniversary date. Accrual begins on the employee's date of hire and newly hired full time hourly employees will be credited with 3.7 hours of annual leave at the end of their first pay period. After ten (10) years of service, hourly employees are eligible to accrue 4.615 hours per pay period, for an annual total of one hundred twenty (120) hours leave until they have reached their twentieth anniversary date. After twenty (20) years of service, full-time hourly employees are eligible to accrue 6.154 hours of annual leave per pay period for an annual total of one hundred sixty (160) hours. 
    Full-time hourly employees will accrue annual leave during the probationary period but cannot use annual leave until they have completed the probationary period. 
    Hourly employees may carry-over a maximum of one hundred twenty (120) hours of annual leave from one year to the next. Hours in excess of one hundred twenty (120) accrued but not used by the final pay period of the year which includes December 31 will be forfeited. 
    Full-time salaried employees are eligible to accrue 4.615 hours of annual leave per pay period until they reach their tenth anniversary date. Beginning with the first pay period following their tenth anniversary date, full-time salaried employees will accrue 6.154 hours of annual leave each pay period. Full-time salaried employees are eligible to carry-over not more than one hundred sixty (160) hours of annual leave from one year to the next. Annual leave in excess of one hundred sixty (160) hours accrued and not used by December 31 of each year will be forfeited. 
    Part-time hourly employees who work twenty (20) hours per week or more will accrue 1.85 hours of annual leave per pay period. 
    Annual leave time is not earned during an unpaid leave of absence. Accrual resumes upon return to active status. Accrual is effective for every week that an eligible employee receives compensation for all regularly scheduled hours of work. 
    Annual Leave accrued as of April 12, 1990, shall be retained by the employee and the recordkeeping for such accrued Leave shall be kept separate from the accrual records maintained after that date. 
    Casual or temporary employees do not accrue annual leave. 
Leave Transfer/Payout 
    An employee whose employment with the city is terminated shall be paid for unused, accrued annual leave and comp time. If the effective date of termination is before the end of a pay period, no leave will be credited for that pay period. 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
2.64.290 - Sick leave. 
    The city of Tucumcari provides paid sick leave time-off to employees to allow employees to accumulate time off with pay to take care of themselves due to short-term illness or injury, or to take care of an ill or injured immediate family member. 
    Sick leave is provided to the employee to use for the following purposes: 
  To recover from illness or injury, which prevents the employee from working. 
  For general health/medical exams and treatment, employee must provide documentation of appointment. 
  For hospital stay or home bed rest ordered by physician. 
  For dental or vision exams and procedures. 
  For psychological examination and treatment (includes related counseling). 
  If the employee's household is quarantined due to contagious disease of a resident member. 
  To take care of a member of the employee's immediate family (See Definitions and acronyms) who is ill or injured. 
    Abuse of sick leave may result in disciplinary action up to and including termination. 
    To request sick leave, employees must notify their supervisor immediately upon knowing that sick leave is required. If an employee is unable to provide notice, the employee is responsible for having someone provide notice for them. The employee must notify the supervisor of the following: 
a.	The date the sick leave will begin;
b.	Documentation of medical need if will be absent three or more days;
c.	The estimated date of return; and
d.	A phone number where he or she can be reached.
    Employees will maintain daily contact with their supervisor for any period of absence beyond one day, unless he or she has provided a health care provider's certification covering a specified period. 
    Salaried employees do not need to account for sick leave that is less than four hours at a time. 
    If an employee using sick leave is absent from work for three days or more, employees must provide their supervisor a health-care provider's written statement as additional justification for absences of three days or longer. For absences of three days or more for their own illness or injury, employees must obtain and submit to their supervisor a health-care provider's written statement showing that the individual can return to work, including any limitations or restrictions the employee may have. 
    Employees who have a serious health condition may qualify for family and medical leave. (See Section 2.64.320). 
Sick Leave Accrual 
    Full-time employees accrue 3.7 hours of sick leave time per pay period. Part-time employees accrue 1.85 hours of sick leave per pay period. Accrual begins on an employee's first pay period. Accrued sick leave may be accumulated from year to year. 
    Casual and temporary employees do not earn sick leave. 
Leave Transfer/Payout 
    No payout of sick leave will be made at termination of employment. 
    Upon retirement, all employees who were employed by the city as of April 12, 1990, will receive pay for one-half of their accumulated sick leave. 
    At the time of PERA approved retirement from the city, the employee will be reimbursed for one-sixth of the total sick leave accumulated. In no event shall the employee be reimbursed for more than one hundred seventy-four (174) hours, which is one-sixth of the maximum accumulation allowed. 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
2.64.300 - Donated leave. 
    In order to provide income protection for employees who experience a non-job related, seriously incapacitating and extended illness or injury leading to the exhaustion of all the employee's appropriate paid leave balances, the city provides a policy that allows other employees to donate some of their earned leave balances to the employee in accordance with the following provisions. 
    An employee who experiences a non-job related, seriously incapacitating and extended illness or injury and who has consequently exhausted all available leave balances may apply through the supervisor to the city manager's office for donated leave, not to exceed one hundred twenty (120) hours per occurrence. 
Requesting Donated Leave 
    An employee wishing to receive donated leave will submit an application for donated leave to the supervisor and attach a statement from their physician that verifies the nature and expected duration of the condition. In the event the employee is unable complete the application, an authorized personal representative may submit the request on behalf of the employee. The requesting employee must be an employee who is eligible to earn sick leave under the provisions of this personnel policies and procedures manual. 
    The application will be reviewed and approved by the supervisor. The approved application will be forwarded to the city manager's office. The city manager will review the application and ensure that all applicable conditions are satisfied before approving the request. 
    Once the request is approved, the city manager's office will communicate the employee's request for donated leave to other city employees. 
Donating Leave 
    Employees who have completed their introductory period and who wish to donate earned leave may donate either annual leave or sick leave. The donating employee may only donate leave they have accumulated in excess of forty (40) hours. The donating employee must maintain a minimum earned leave (either annual leave or sick leave) balance of forty (40) hours after the donation. 
    An employee who has an earned leave balance in excess of forty (40) hours and who wishes to donate leave to the requesting employee may do so by completing a donation of earned leave form. The employee will indicate on the form the specific recipient of the donated leave. The completed form will be forwarded to the city manager's office and will be maintained there in confidence. 
    The city manager's office will review all donations to ensure that all requirements for donating leave are met. The office will accumulate the number of full hours donated, deduct the donated leave from the balance of the donating employee, and credit those hours to the leave balance of the requesting employee. The office will maintain records to ensure that only the leave needed is used. 
Leave Transfer/Payout 
    Donated leave time is donated and transferred to the requesting employee in full-hour increments only. The requesting employee will be paid for donated leave at the pay rate of the requesting employee. Donated leave will be accumulated only to the extent needed by the requesting employee. Leave that is donated, but not used, will not be deducted from the leave balance of the donating employee. No payout of donated leave is made at termination of employment. 
Procedure: 
1.	In order to request donated leave, the requesting employee must be eligible to earn sick leave in accordance with the sick leave policy. 
2.	The requesting employee will complete an application for donated leave and attach a statement from their attending physician describing the nature of the injury/illness, and the anticipated length of absence from work. The application will be submitted to the employee's supervisor. If the employee is not able to complete the application a designated personal representative may complete it on behalf of the employee. 
3.	The supervisor will verify the information contained in the application and indicate approval by signing the application and forwarding it to the city manager's office. 
4.	The city manager will review the application to ensure that all requirements of this policy have been met. 
a.	If the city manager approves the application, other employees of the city will be notified of the request for donated leave. 
b.	If the application is denied, the city manager will communicate the specific reasons to the requesting employee. 
5.	Employees who have completed their probationary period and wish to donate leave to the requesting employee and have more than forty (40) hours of accumulated earned leave (see definitions and acronyms), may donate leave in full-hour increments by completing a donation of earned leave form and submitting it the city manager's office. 
6.	The city manager's office will ensure that all leave donations meet the requirements of this policy and will administer the deduction of donated leave from donating employees and the payment of leave to the requesting employee in accordance with this policy. 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
2.64.310 - Leaves of absence. 
    To provide income protection for employees who must be away from work under certain circumstances, and also to allow certain absences on an unpaid basis with no loss of accumulated service. The city is committed to respecting the needs and desires of their employees for time off while balancing the needs of the city's operations. 
    Leaves of absence may be granted to employees for the reasons specified herein, and are available to employees who have completed their probationary period with the city unless otherwise noted. 
    Abuse or falsification of leave time will result in disciplinary action up to and including termination of employment. 
    Paid leave offered under this section does not accumulate from year to year. 
Paid Leaves of Absences 
Bereavement Leave 
Up to three, eight-hour days of paid leave may be granted for bereavement in the case of the death of a member of the employee's immediate family (see Definitions and acronyms). 
Up to two, eight-hour days of paid leave may be granted for bereavement in the case of the death of an employee's non-immediate family members (see Definitions and acronyms). 
Hourly employees may use bereavement leave in hourly or full day increments. Salaried employees may use bereavement leave in half- or full-day increments. 
    If the funeral for a member of the employee's immediate family as outlined above is held out of town, the employee will be granted additional paid time off: one additional day with pay will be granted if the funeral is held more than three hundred (300) miles from the city of Tucumcari; two additional days off with pay will be granted if the funeral is held more than six hundred (600) miles from the city of Tucumcari. 
    The supervisor may also approve additional time-off, either as unpaid leave, or the employee may use other earned paid leave at the time of bereavement. 
Personal Leave 
    A full-time employee will be granted sixteen (16) hours of paid personal time-off each calendar year. An eligible employee who has completed the probationary period may use personal leave for any personal business. Personal leave may be used in increments of four hours, and must be approved in advance by the supervisor. Personal leave not used by the end of the calendar year will be forfeited and may not be accumulated from year to year. Unused personal leave will not be paid out at resignation or termination. 
Voting Leave 
    An employee who is registered to vote will be allowed up to two hours of paid time-off for purposes of voting in a national, state or local election, if the employee's work schedule prevents them from voting before or after working hours. 
    Such time-off will generally be at the beginning or end of the regular working shift, whichever allows the most free time for voting and the least time-off from working, unless otherwise provided by the employee's supervisor. This leave will not be granted to any employee whose work day begins more than two hours after the opening of the polls, or ends more than three hours before the closing of the polls. 
Jury or Witness Duty Leave 
    Employees who serve on a grand jury or a trial jury or who are subpoenaed to appear in court as a witness, as required by law, will be granted paid time-off from work for the time the employee is actually required to be away from work. Those employees who receive paid leave must give any fee received to the city. If they choose not to take paid leave, they may keep any compensation received from jury service or witness duty. If the employee is excused by the court during a working day, the employee shall immediately return to work if at least one hour of the employee's regularly scheduled work day remains to be completed. 
    Part-time and temporary employees are not eligible for jury or witness duty leave. 
    Employees must provide reasonable notice to their supervisor for days he or she will be absent and when he or she can be expected to report to work. Employees on jury or witness duty leave must call their supervisor at the commencement of each work day, as per the attendance policy, to notify the supervisor if the employee is to be on jury or witness duty that day. The employee must provide their supervisor with a copy of the summons for duty, or the subpoena. 
United States Military Reserve/National Guard Leave 
    Employees who are members of the United States Military Reserve, or the National Guard will be granted up to fifteen (15) days of paid time-off during a one year period to attend military training drills, encampment, naval cruises, and special duty or like activity. 
  To be eligible for Military Reserve/National Guard Leave, the employee must provide a copy of the orders requiring the leave. 
  United States Military Reserve/National Guard Leave must be requested twenty (20) days in advance. 
  For this period of service, up to fifteen (15) days, employee health benefits will be continued and the employee will not be required to pay more than the stated employee share of any premium. 
Inclement Weather 
  The city manager may at his/her discretion close city offices and send non-essential employees home due to inclement weather. The non-essential staff is paid as if they were at work. 
  Public works and public safety employees are expected to work; it is part of their responsibilities to always have staff for public safety and are paid at their normal rate of pay. The street department must work on roads, fire, EMS, and PD must have staff available to respond to the public needs. 
Unpaid Leaves of Absence 
    Any employee who is granted an unpaid leave of absence will not accrue sick or annual leave during the period of absence. 
Military Leave 
    Employees who enter the Armed Force of the Untied States or who are members of the Reserve Corps of the Armed Forces of the United States, or the National Guard who are called up for active duty or special duty or like activity for more than fifteen (15) working days will be granted an unpaid leave of absence. 
  To be eligible for military leave, the employee must provide a copy of the orders requiring the leave. 
  Applicable laws will be observed regarding reinstatement at close of tour. To be re-employed, the employee must make application for re-employment within ninety (90) days after being released from duty, or within ninety (90) days of release from hospitalization which continued after discharge for a period of not more than one year. 
  The returning employee will be deemed to have accrued seniority and length of service rights as though his employment with the city had been continuous since his last date of hire with the city. 
  The returning employee shall have all unused annual and sick leave accrued, and not paid at the time the leave began restored. 
Continuation of Benefits While on a Leave of Absence 
    If an employee is granted an unpaid leave of absence, the employee may continue group health insurance coverage through the city in conjunction with applicable Federal COBRA guidelines by making monthly payments as directed by the city manager's office, for the amount of the relevant premium. 
Return from a Leave of Absence 
    Prior to the end of the leave of absence, the employee should notify his or her supervisor and confirm the date of return within a reasonable time frame. 
    When an employee is able to return from a leave of absence, the city will make all reasonable efforts to reinstate the employee in his or her previous position and salary. However, it may be necessary to reassign the employee if the city no longer can accommodate the employee in the former job. If reassignment is necessary, the city will make every reasonable effort to place the employee in an equivalent position with similar duties, pay and status. 
Failure to Return from a Leave of Absence 
    If an employee fails to return from a leave of absence on the scheduled date, it will be considered a voluntary resignation of employment. 
Leave Procedure: 
1.	Employees must submit leave requests to their supervisor using the appropriate form. Required supporting documentation will be attached to the leave request. 
2.	The request will state the reason for the leave and the length of time the employee desires. 
3.	The supervisor who has the authority to approve leaves of absence must sign the request for leave form. Leaves may be denied in cases where workload or grant objectives could be seriously affected. 
4.	The supervisor will notify employees whether a leave request is granted or denied within one week of receipt of the written leave request. 
5.	If a leave is granted, the leave request form will be forwarded to the city manager's office. 
6.	If an employee needs an extension to the leave, he or she must make the request in the same way as outlined in the steps above. 
7.	Employees must not accept outside employment or apply for unemployment insurance while on a leave of absence. Acceptance of outside employment while on leave will be treated as voluntary resignation from employment at the city. 
8.	Certain benefits, such as employee insurance, may not be paid by the city while the employee is on an extended unpaid leave of absence depending on the provisions of the benefit plan documents. The employee should consult the city manager's office for information. Unpaid leave will not count as time worked for the accrual of earned leave benefits. 
9.	Upon return from a leave of absence, where possible, employees will be credited with the full employment status that existed prior to the start of the leave, except in the case that the leave extends beyond thirty (30) days when reinstatement may be affected if it is an undue hardship to fully reinstate the employee; reasonable accommodation will be applied whenever possible in such cases. In the case of military leave applicable laws will govern reinstatement. 
10.	If an employee fails to return from leave, it will be considered a voluntary resignation.
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
2.64.320 - Family and medical leave. 
    All employees who have worked for the city of Tucumcari for at least twelve (12) months, and who have worked at least one thousand two hundred fifty (1,250) hours during the previous twelve (12) months will be eligible to receive up to sixty (60) work days, comprising twelve (12) calendar weeks of unpaid family and medical leave during a twelve-month period measured backward from the date the leave first commences for one or more of the following reasons: 
Newborn or Newly Adopted Children 
    Eligible employees may request a family and medical leave of absence to provide care for a child following the child's birth, adoption, or foster placement in the employee's home. This leave must be taken within a year after the child is born, adopted or placed in the employee's home. 
Illness of a Family Member 
    Employees may request a family and medical leave of absence to provide care for a member of the employee's immediate family who has a serious health condition. A "serious health condition" is understood to be an illness, injury, impairment, or physical or mental condition serious enough to involve hospitalization, in-patient care in a hospital, residential health care facility, hospice, or continuing treatment or supervision by a health care provider. The city may require appropriate medical certification before a leave is granted. 
Illness of the Employee 
    Eligible employees may request a family and medical leave of absence when the employee is unable to work because of their own serious health condition, including pregnancy. 
    An employee who qualifies for FMLA leave may be permitted to take a reduced schedule or take intermittent leave to tend to the employee's medical needs or the needs of the family member. 
    The city will require an employee to use all of the employee's accrued and unused annual and sick leave to cover the leave-time prior to going on unpaid leave. All time taken off from work whether paid or unpaid will be counted against the remaining balance of family and medical leave. Once paid time off is exhausted, family and medical leave will continue to the maximum allowable time off if needed. An individual who is unable to return to work after all of their available sick leave and/or family and medical leave is exhausted is subject to termination. 
Procedure: 
Application and Commencement 
1.	A family and medical leave of absence (FMLA) form must be completed and submitted to the employee's supervisor thirty (30) days prior to the commencement date of the leave, except where medical conditions make meeting such a requirement impossible. 
2.	When the leave is to care for a family member, the requesting employee must submit a letter signed by a physician that states: (a) the date the illness or condition began; (b) the probable duration of the condition; (c) the estimated time the employee will need to care for the family member; and (d) a statement that the illness or condition requires the employee to provide such care. 
3.	If the leave request is for the employee's own serious health condition, the medical certification must also state that the employee is unable to perform the essential functions of the employee's current position. 
4.	If the supervisor has any doubt as to the validity of the certification, a second opinion may be required from a medical provider of the city manager's choice and at the city's expense. In addition, the city manager may require that a third opinion be obtained from a health care provider at the city's expense. In such an event the opinion of the third provider shall be final and binding. 
5.	The FMLA form and relevant medical certifications must be submitted to the city manager's office for approval. 
6.	When the leave is for planned medical treatment, the employee must attempt where possible to schedule the treatment so as not to disrupt city operations. 
7.	Employees will be required to use available paid time off during the family and medical leave period. 
Reinstatement 
1.	Upon returning from a family and medical leave that does not exceed the maximum eligible length of leave, the employee will be reinstated to their original position held prior to commencement of the leave or to an equivalent position with no loss of seniority or benefits that accrued prior to taking the leave. 
2.	Employees on leave must notify their supervisor at least two weeks prior to the end of leave of their availability to return to work. 
3.	A medical release to return to work from a leave taken for the employee's own serious health condition will be required from the employee's health care provider. 
4.	An employee's failure to return from leave, or failure to contact his or her immediate supervisor or the city manager's office on the scheduled date of return, will be considered a voluntary resignation. 
Continuation of Benefits 
1.	During an approved leave, the city shall continue to provide, if otherwise available, medical coverage under its group health plan on the same conditions that would have applied if the employee had not taken the leave. In no case will the city continue to pay for such coverage for more than the maximum eligible duration of the leave. 
2.	The employee shall be responsible for paying the employee's portion, if any, of the insurance premium, including the premium for dependent coverage, if available. Failure of the employee to pay these premiums on a timely basis may result in a lapse of coverage. 
3.	If the employee fails to return to work at the end of the leave period, the employee will be required to reimburse the city for group health insurance premiums paid by the city on behalf of the employee during the leave unless the failure to return is due to a continuation, reoccurrence or onset of a serious health condition that entitles the employee to leave under this policy or due to circumstances beyond the employee's control. 
4.	No annual or sick leave will accrue while an employee is on a family and medical leave.
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
Article 4. - Discipline and Rules 

2.64.330 - Corrective disciplinary action. 
    The city understands that most employees are diligent, dedicated and intent upon making a strong contribution to the success of the city. For the purposes of achieving the city's mission, goals and objectives, this policy is a guide for correcting those instances of unacceptable work behavior or poor performance and providing employees the opportunity to succeed. 
    The city may proceed with suspension or discharge at any point in the corrective disciplinary action process, at its sole discretion, taking into consideration business necessity or the seriousness of the employee infraction. 
Administrative Leave 
a.	Under certain serious circumstances (such as when a fight, theft or other major behavior problem occurred), it may be necessary to remove an employee from the workplace pending investigation or pre-disciplinary hearing, and the determination of the final recommended disciplinary action. In such cases, the supervisor may place an employee on administrative leave with pay. The department manager and the city manager's office will be notified prior to an employee being placed on administrative leave. 
b.	Depending on the outcome of the investigation, further disciplinary action may be imposed. 
Suspension and Demotion 
    If the employee continues to fail to meet expectations, or is found to have violated policy but not to a degree that would warrant discharge, the supervisor may recommend to the city manager that the employee be suspended or demoted. A demotion is defined as a change in job responsibilities accompanied by a loss in pay. A disciplinary suspensions will be without pay. The suspension will be imposed for a specific length of time with a date of return to work. 
    Suspension and/or demotion are an attempt to correct inappropriate behavior of an employee before discharge. Before imposing a disciplinary suspension or demotion, the employee's supervisor will provide the employee with a written notice of intent to suspend or notice of intent to demote and will conduct a pre-suspension meeting with the employee where the employee has a chance to contest the suspension or demotion. 
Discharge 
    Under certain circumstances, an immediate discharge may be appropriate. Examples of situations which may result in immediate discharge include but are not limited to: the unlawful manufacturing, distributing, dispensing, possessing or using of controlled substances or alcohol while on the city's premises or while on duty or reporting to work under the influence of an unlawful controlled substance or alcohol; theft; acts of negligence causing damage to persons or property; falsification of information on the employee's job application or other city records; refusal or failure to comply with city policy; insubordination; disruptive conduct interfering with the city's operations; unauthorized use of city property, facilities, materials or other city assets for personal use; accepting gratuities; bringing unapproved weapons onto city property; conviction of a job related felony or misdemeanor as described in the Criminal Offender Employment Act NMSA 1978, § 28-2-1, et seq.; actual or threatened physical violence towards another employee or a citizen customer; or any other conduct deemed not to be in the best interests of the city and its employees. 
    Before imposing a discharge, the supervisor will provide the employee with a written notice of intent to discharge. The employee will then be allowed an opportunity to meet with the supervisor within three working days of the notice and will be given an opportunity to respond to the proposed discharge. The supervisor will then make a final decision. if discharge is recommended, the discharge decision will be presented to the city manager for approval. The discharge is not final unless approved by the city manager. 
Appeal 
    Regular employees, who have successfully completed their probationary period, and who receive a disciplinary suspension, demotion or discharge penalty may appeal the action by following the grievance resolution section. 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
2.64.340 - Drug and alcohol-free workplace. 
    It is the policy of the city of Tucumcari to provide a workplace reasonably free of known hazards. The city views the use and presence of illegal drugs and the abuse of legal drugs and alcohol as extreme hazards to employees, visitors, customers and the community. The city of Tucumcari intends to ensure a drug and alcohol-free workplace, to establish guidelines for responding to incidents of abuse of controlled substances and alcohol by employees of the city, and to provide a safe and secure workplace for all employees, visitors and guests. 
    This policy applies regardless of whether the employee's conduct constitutes an illegal act or whether the employee in question is criminally prosecuted and/or convicted for such conduct. 
    The city of Tucumcari prohibits the unlawful manufacture, use, distribution, possession or sale of any illegal substance in the workplace, including illicit drugs and other controlled substances. 
    The city of Tucumcari further prohibits the presence or use of alcohol by employees, other than bartenders, while at work or on city property, except when attending sanctioned functions after hours at city facilities. Distribution of prescription drugs to others or use of those drugs in a manner other than as prescribed by a physician is similarly prohibited while at work or on city property. 
    Reporting for work or conducting city business while intoxicated or under the influence of any illegal substance is expressly prohibited. 
    Some programs (departments and/or positions) must comply with the commercial driver's license (CDL) regulations. Supervisors will inform their employees and enforce these regulations if this is the case, for positions requiring a CDL. 
    The city of Tucumcari reserves the right to apply this policy in a manner appropriate and in support of the city's mission and values.
