    An employee who believes that he or she has a problem with alcohol or drugs that is interfering with their job performance is encouraged to voluntarily seek help before their substance abuse problem becomes the subject of corrective disciplinary action. 
    Employees who violate this policy will be subject to corrective disciplinary action up to and including discharge and may also be required to participate in a rehabilitation program of a type reviewed and approved by the city manager's office. Failure to cooperate with or complete such a program may result in further corrective disciplinary action including immediate discharge. 
    Employees participating in a rehabilitation program shall use available earned leave for which they are eligible. When available earned leave is exhausted, the employee may be eligible for unpaid leave, upon request and approval by the supervisor. Returning to employment from leave may also be contingent upon the ability of the city to reasonably accommodate the employee. 
    In administering this policy, the city manager's office and/or the supervisor will strive to maintain the employee's status and any information regarding substance abuse in strictest confidence. 
    For purposes of this policy, an illegal drug is any drug or drug-like substance which is prohibited or restricted by law. This policy prohibits an employee's use or possession of the drug, regardless of whether such conduct constitutes an illegal act or whether the employee is criminally prosecuted and/or convicted for such conduct. 
    A legal drug is a drug which is prescribed by a physician or available over-the-counter. 
    The city requires any employee taking legal drug(s) which may impair the employee's ability to safely perform their job functions to report the use of the medication to their immediate supervisor. The supervisor may assign other duties or grant sick leave time-off if the employee is unable to perform his/her assigned duties or perform any duties in a safe manner. If the use of a legal drug impairs the employee's ability to safely perform the essential functions of the employee's job, transfer or even termination may be considered. 
Employee Testing 
    Employees will be required to undergo drug and substance abuse testing upon the following conditions: 
  Pre-Employment: The city will test all applicants who receive an offer of employment. The city will revoke a job offer to any applicant who tests positive for any illegal drug. 
  Reasonable Cause: If the supervisor has reasonable cause (see: Definitions and Acronyms), the employee will be required to submit to a substance abuse test; refusal to do so will be grounds for disciplinary action, up to and including discharge. When a motor vehicle accident occurs that results in injury to a person or damage to property, it will be considered as reasonable cause for testing of the employee(s) involved, which may include a blood alcohol test. 
  Random: Employees who have had positive test results, or who have been convicted of any criminal alcohol/drug statute will be required to submit to random substance abuse tests as a condition of continued employment, whether or not they are involved in a rehabilitation process. A positive test result during random screening will result in immediate discharge. 
  Job-Specific: Positions that by their nature can affect public safety, including CDL operators, will be designated as those requiring random testing after hire. Any such requirement shall be indicated in the position description. 
  Motor Vehicle Accidents: An employee who is involved in a motor vehicle accident while on duty which results in property damage or personal will be tested in all circumstances, regardless of fault. 
Testing Procedures 
    The city will determine the type and manner of drug and alcohol testing, including what constitutes a positive test result at its sole discretion. Test samples will be collected in a reasonable and sanitary area and will be labeled and handled in such a way reasonably designed to preclude sample contamination, adulteration or misidentification. The city is entitled to rely on the results of its drug or alcohol testing to determine if any employee has violated this policy and is subject to corrective disciplinary action. 
    All drug or alcohol testing will be performed by a certified laboratory facility, using scientifically accepted analytical procedures and meeting confidentiality requirements. This facility has been identified and its name and address is on file in the city manager's office. 
    Positive results of alcohol and drug testing guidelines are established by the department of health and human services will be used to determine whether an employee test positive. Any employee who test positive for drugs or alcohol will be dismissed. 
    An employee has the right to have the original sample retested at the employee's own expense. Inconsistent test results will be reviewed by the city manager, who has the discretion to accept the retest results or to request an additional test. The ultimate decision of the reliability of the results will be made by the city manager. 
    At the time of testing, a person will be given the chance to provide any information that may be relevant to the test, including whether the person is taking prescription or over the counter medication or undergoing any medical treatment that may affect the result of the test. Additionally, individuals will be given the chance to explain a positive test result in a confidential setting. 
Threshold of Positive Results 
    The positive results thresholds are as follows: 
  Alcohol: A blood alcohol concentration of 0.02, except that for individuals holding a CDL as a job requirement, any test greater than 0.00 is considered positive. 
  Illegal Drugs: Current limits set by the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services to indicate confirmed presence of the drugs. 
  Prescription Drugs: Sample levels in excess of what would be expected by using the drugs as prescribed by the attending physician or where the drug has not been prescribed to that employee. 
Employee Notice of Conviction or Arrest 
1.	Any employee who is convicted of any criminal alcohol/drug statute must notify the supervisor within five working days of conviction. Conviction includes a finding of guilt, a plea of "no contest" or an imposition of sentencing by any judicial body for such criminal drug statute violations. 
2.	Employees who are employed in safety-sensitive positions as identified in their job descriptions must notify the supervisor within five working days of an arrest for a drug or alcohol-related offense. The city manager will decide whether the employee's job duties will be modified and will take whatever action is deemed appropriate under the circumstances. 
3.	The supervisor shall take the following action when such notice of conviction is received or when he/she receives any verifiable information relative to violation of the drug and alcohol-free workplace policy: 
a.	Notify the city manager's office after receiving notice from an employee or otherwise receiving actual notice of a criminal alcohol/drug statute conviction. 
b.	Take appropriate personnel action, if the employee is unable to perform his or her job duties as a result of the conviction. 
c.	Encourage, according to circumstances, such employee to seek rehabilitation in a substance abuse program. 
Procedure: 
1.	Employees are encouraged to seek voluntary treatment for substance abuse. If an employee wishes assistance or referral information, he or she should contact their supervisor and human resources. 
2.	Any employee who observes another employee violating this policy will notify the employee's supervisor, whose responsibility will be to verify the abuse through direct observation if at all possible, through investigation, or through the assistance of other management, depending upon the circumstances of the suspected abuse. 
3.	If a reasonable cause is found, the employee's supervisor will require the employee to submit to substance abuse testing, as provided in this policy. 
4.	Refusal by an employee to submit to a drug or alcohol test as required by the supervisor, or testing positive for illegal drugs or alcohol, will result in corrective disciplinary action, up to and including immediate discharge for a first offense, depending upon the facts and circumstances involved in each situation. 
5.	The city manager's office will notify the employee and the employee's supervisor of the results. 
6.	The supervisor will initiate disciplinary actions as appropriate.
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
2.64.350 - Grievance resolution procedure. 
    It is the policy of the city of Tucumcari to provide a grievance resolution procedure to be followed exclusively for the resolution of disputes between a regular employee (see: Employment status section) (excluding temporary and appointed employees) and a supervisor that may arise over the suspension, demotion or discharge of the employee. Any regular employee who has successfully completed the probationary period, and who feels that he or she has been unfairly suspended, demoted or discharged or who believes that mitigating facts may not have been fully considered before the suspension or discharge was administered may apply for reconsideration of that decision through the procedures provided in this policy. 
    Temporary, casual and appointed employees may not use the grievance resolution policy and procedure. The following are not grievable: 
  Dismissal of probationary employees prior to the expiration of their probationary period. 
  Release of temporary or emergency-hire employees prior to or at the end of their anticipated employment period. 
  Dismissal of appointed employees at any point during their employment with the city. 
  Transfers, temporary assignments, removal from temporary assignments, and promotions. 
  Job evaluations, performance appraisals, verbal or written reprimands, or selection for vacant positions. 
  Matters where the city is without authority to act or does not have the ability to provide a remedy. 
  Failure by the employee to proceed to a higher step of the procedure within the time periods provided herein will terminate the grievance resolution process. 
    Only the issues raised and presented originally for resolution shall be considered on appeal. 
    Decisions rendered by the personnel hearing officer (See Procedure, below) may serve as precedents for the resolution of similar subsequent disputes. 
Procedure 
1.	The city manager (or his/or her designee) shall meet with the employee, the employee's supervisor and the manager of the department where the employee works. The employee shall have the opportunity to respond to the proposed corrective disciplinary action, provide physical evidence, and provide any mitigating or exculpatory information. 
2.	The city manager will issue a decision in writing or approve the written decision of his or her designee within five working days of the hearing. 
3.	The employee may appeal the city manager's written decision to the personnel hearing officer by submitting a written appeal and request for a post-disciplinary grievance hearing to the city manager's office within five working days of the receipt of the city manager's written decision. 
4.	Within ten (10) working days of receipt of the grievant's appeal and request, the city manager will provide the grievant with the name of the hearing officer. The hearing officer shall be familiar with public and/or private personnel systems, or have pertinent experience in the appropriate areas of management or law. Qualifications for service as a hearing officer shall be verified by the city manager's office. The hearing officer need not reside in the city of Tucumcari. 
5.	The personnel hearing officer will determine the date, time and location of the post-disciplinary hearing and grant continuances agreed to by both parties. The hearing will be conducted at a time and place which is mutually convenient to all parties. Requests for continuances of hearings shall be made in writing to the hearing officer with a copy to the opposing party at least five working days prior to the scheduled hearing, absent extenuating circumstances. The hearing must be held within sixty (60) days of the receipt of the grievant's appeal and request by the city manager. The parties must agree in writing to any postponement of the grievance hearing beyond sixty (60) days. Notice of the hearing will be sent by certified mail to the grievant and postmarked at least ten (10) days prior to the scheduled hearing. Copies of the hearing notice will be sent concurrently to all relevant parties. 
6.	Post-disciplinary hearings shall be conducted as open meetings with notice given to the public pursuant to the New Mexico Open Meetings Act, and the city of Tucumcari's Open Meetings Resolution. The grievant shall have an opportunity to present witnesses and physical evidence and cross examine the city's witnesses before the hearing officer. The grievant, at his own expense may have legal counsel represent him at the hearing. The city may have legal representation at the hearing, even if the grievant is not represented by counsel. 
7.	The personnel hearing officer shall determine the order of agenda items; rule on procedural and substantive issues of the hearing; determine the admissibility of evidence and testimony, all of which must have a direct bearing on the issue considered by the hearing officer according to the evidentiary standard for administrative agencies, the New Mexico Rules of Evidence will be liberally interpreted; and issue findings of fact and conclusions of law. The hearing will be recorded by a certified court reporter. In most cases the order of presentation of the case will be as follows: 
a.	Opening Statement: The city will present its statement of issues, followed by the grievant. 
b.	Presentation of the City's Case: Witnesses for the city may be called and questioned. The grievant will have the opportunity to cross-examine witnesses. The hearing officer may also question witnesses on matters relating to the witness' testimony. 
c.	Presentation of the grievant's case following the same format as the city's presentation and the city will have the opportunity to cross-examine the grievant's witnesses. 
d.	Following the grievant's presentation the city may offer rebuttal testimony.
e.	Closing Statements: The city will present first, followed by the grievant. Closing statements will be limited to ten (10) minutes and will at a minimum contain a request for the desired outcome. The city may make a final statement following the grievant's closing statement. 
8.	The parties shall stipulate to the facts and issues to the greatest extent possible prior to the hearing. Prior to the hearing the parties shall prepare copies of all exhibits and evidence which are expected to be presented. The parties shall stipulate to exhibits to the extent possible and bring to the hearing enough copies for the hearing officer and the opposing party. At least five working days prior to the hearing, all parties must submit to the hearing officer a statement of the issues to be heard, a witness list, and a complete list of documents to be admitted as evidence. 
9.	Witnesses will not be admitted to the hearing room until called upon to testify except those required to be present: The grievant, the grievant's legal counsel (if any), the city's legal counsel, the department manager, and the city manager. 
10.	The personnel hearing officer shall prepare written findings and conclusions and submit them to the parties within thirty (30) calendar days of the date of the hearing. The hearing officer may uphold, modify, or reverse the decision of the city manager and may reinstate the employee and award only back pay and benefits. The decision of the personnel hearing officer is binding and subject to review by petition for writ of certiorari by either party to the Tenth Judicial District of the state of New Mexico. The record of the proceedings will be retained by the city manager's office or the certified court reporter for a period of not less than three years from the hearing date, along with all of the physical evidence admitted by the hearing officer. The verbal transcript shall be transcribed only in the case of appeal to the district court by one of the respective parties. 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
2.64.360 - Open door communications. 
    To promote open two-way communication between employees and management, and to encourage employees to come forward in an atmosphere of courtesy and cooperation to develop mutually beneficial solutions to problems or complaints which may affect the employee in the course of their employment and which can improve the city's operations, the city of Tucumcari provides an open door policy. The "open door" is for positive communication flow as well as for addressing concerns. This policy also provides employees the opportunity to voice complaints concerning alleged improper actions of supervisors or management. The employee is required to begin all discussions under this policy with their immediate supervisor. 
    The city believes that employees have the individual right to speak for themselves and respectfully voice their concerns. 
    Supervisors are responsible for listening with respect and assisting employees whenever possible. 
    The existence of this policy is to provide communication and promote problem solving. The existence of this policy does not give the employee an independent right to pursue a grievance. 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
2.64.370 - Driving requirements. 
    The city of Tucumcari has developed this policy to ensure that all employees who are required to operate a motor vehicle in the course of their duties do so in a safe and courteous manner and to remain in compliance with the city's insurance requirements. 
    All employees who must operate their own vehicle or a city-owned vehicle to conduct the city's business must possess a valid New Mexico State Drivers license, active automobile insurance, and a safe driving record. 
    The city may request a copy of a DMV report for any employee, or prospective employee prior to hiring and periodically after employment as determined to be appropriate by the city manager's office if their job responsibilities include driving for the city. 
1.	In order to obtain a position with the city, an employee must possess a valid New Mexico Driver's License, and attend a city of Tucumcari Driver Safety Education Class annually. 
2.	Employees who drive for the city must immediately inform their supervisor if their State issued driver's license is expired, suspended or revoked. 
3.	Employees driving privately owned vehicles for the city's business purposes must personally possess and provide, at a minimum, proof of liability insurance for the vehicle they will be operating. 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
2.64.380 - External communications. 
    All external communication with the press or other media outlets will be coordinated through the city manager's office to maintain accuracy and ensure the interests of the city are correctly represented. An individual employee may not represent the city's position or view to the general public without specific assignment and authority to do so. 
    Information regarding city policies, issues, or problems must not be discussed with other organizations, the media, or the general public, except by those individuals who are directed to communicate such information at the appropriate times. 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
2.64.390 - Confidentiality. 
    Employees of the city of Tucumcari will by the nature of their duties have access to confidential information regarding employees, citizen customers, competitive bids and/or awards, etc. 
    Confidential information learned by employees in the course of performing their duties for the city, shall not be discussed with anyone who does not have a need to know. 
    Transmittal of information within or outside of the city that would serve no useful purpose and could be harmful to the interests of the city or to fellow employees including information regarding promotions, terminations, demotions, complaints or charges against an individual employee, salary information, certain procurement transactions of the city including the purchase, acquisition or disposal of real property or water rights, deliberations in connection with an administrative adjudicatory proceeding, personal medical information, letters of reference, law enforcement records that reveal, confidential sources, methods, or information on individuals accused but not charged with a crime, etc., is not permitted, except as expressly allowed by law. 
    People who may have a "need to know" confidential information are employees, citizen customers or vendors who require confidential information to properly perform assigned tasks related to the provision of services, well-being or the growth and development of the city. This will include management and administrative personnel who have supervisory and oversight responsibilities for services provided and service staff whose required activities provide a direct ability to benefit the customer. 
    Citizens have a right to know information about city operations and activities that does not disclose personal employee information, or violate other established confidentiality policies that protect the city's interests. There is a formal process for citizens to follow to request information that is important to understanding the city's operations and finances. This confidentiality policy is not intended to nor does it in any way interfere with a citizen's rights under the Open Meetings Act [Chapter 10, Article 15 NMSA 1978] or the Inspection of Public Records Act [14-2-4 NMSA 1978]. 
    All information regarding employees and citizen customers is to be held in the strictest of confidence, and only shared when there is a legitimate business need with those other employees or business associates of the city who have a need to know the information in order to provide services to the clients. 
    Employees may be required to obtain citizen customer permission to disclose information to other employees or to outside parties, depending upon the situation and the information involved. 
    Employees, or former employees, privileged to know confidential information in the course of performing their duties are expected to maintain the confidentiality of that information during and after their employment. In the case of employees who terminate, any confidential documents in their possession will be returned to the city upon termination. 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
2.64.400 - Personal and professional conduct. 
    The city of Tucumcari expects its employees to uphold the values and mission of the city of Tucumcari by maintaining a professional and team-oriented work environment, representing the city in the workplace and in public in a manner that represents the city's values of hard work and exceptional public service. 
    City employees are constantly in the public eye; consequently, it is important that every employee present the best possible image to the public. Employees should always be neat and clean and dressed in clothing suitable for their work assignments. When uniforms are available for employees they must be worn. 
    While an employee's conduct after hours is generally considered his or her personal business, serious personal misconduct may adversely affect public confidence in the city government and its employees. Personal misconduct that bears a reasonable nexus to the employee's job responsibilities and that affects the employee's ability to effectively perform their job, whether through unsatisfactory performance or loss of public confidence and/or unfavorable publicity to the city, may result in corrective disciplinary action up to and including termination. Examples of such misconduct include, but are not limited to, domestic violence or driving while under the influence. 
    Employees are expected to conduct themselves at all times with professionalism and courtesy. Every employee is a representative of the city and is expected to present the highest professional and ethical behavior at all times to customers, vendors and any other associates of the city. (See: Section 2.64.410 Conflict of interest section for additional guidance.) 
    All business relationships involving employees, customers, vendors, guests, or others will be conducted with mutual respect and in a manner that is conducive to achieving the city's goals and that upholds the city's beliefs and values. 
    Outside relationships, activities and/or employment by any individual engaged or employed by the city shall not in any way jeopardize the confidentiality, business or employment responsibilities, program/business interests, or good standing of the city. 
    City employees are encouraged to exercise their political rights as citizens, vote as they may choose, support candidates of their choice, and express their political opinions. However, political activities must take place outside of working hours and away from city offices. Employees may not use their official position with the city to endorse any candidate for office or influence the outcome of an election. 
    If any employee is unsure as to whether certain behavior is considered unprofessional conduct, they are encouraged to ask their immediate supervisor. 
    Violations of this policy may result in disciplinary action up to and including discharge (See: Section 2.64.330 Corrective disciplinary action section). 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
2.64.410 - Conflict of interest. 
    In order to prevent a conflict of interest or the appearance of a conflict of interest, every employee will maintain professional conduct in line with the city's mission and values. No employee shall use his or her position with the city for purposes that are motivated by a desire for private financial gain for themselves or others such as immediate family, business associates, or other similar ties. 
    Activities prohibited include, but are not limited to the following: 
  Accepting any gifts, gratuities or tips from clients, vendors or other business associates of the city, for any value greater than twenty-five dollars ($25.00). In no case are gifts allowed that may interfere with an employee's ability to make sound business decisions. 
  Receiving or accepting any fee or gratuity for negotiating contracts or other agreements. 
  Accepting compensation from, acting as a board member for, or having other business relations with consultants and vendors of the city without prior written permission by the city manager. 
  Offering favorable contract terms in order to obtain a personal benefit, which may or may not include monetary benefit, from any person or business entity. 
  Any use of your official authority or duties that results in unwarranted personal gain or provides an improper benefit to friends or relatives. 
    The city manager shall investigate any allegation of conflict of interest, and if the allegation is confirmed, shall work together with the supervisor to determine the most appropriate administrative action in accordance with the corrective counseling and disciplinary action policy. In the cases where the employee who commits the violation is employed with grant-related funds, the supervisor shall, if requested or required, report the actions taken to the appropriate grantor official. 
    City employees may not also hold positions as city board of commissioners member. If an employee is elected or appointed to a commission seat, the employee shall resign from their job, or decline the appointment. 
    Any employee elected to municipal office shall resign from the employ of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
2.64.420 - Personnel records. 
    The city manager's office will maintain a system of confidential personnel records. A personnel records folder will be created at the time of hire and maintained on each employee. All personnel records pertaining to an employee will be kept in secure files within the city manager's office. 
File Access 
    Access to all personnel files is restricted to authorized employees on a "need to know" basis. Personnel files are the property of the city and may not be removed from the city manager's office. The city manager will determine who has a "need to know". 
    Employees should be aware that information contained in employee personnel files, including employee applications, is subject to disclosure under the Inspection of Public Records Act, pursuant to NMSA section 14-2-1, except for records pertaining to physical or mental examinations and medical treatment letters of reference, and letters or memoranda that are matters of opinion. 
    Any employee may arrange to see his/her personnel, financial and restricted access files. This can be done by contacting the city manager's office and arranging an appointment. The file may not be removed from the office, but a copy of documents signed by the employee can be made available with the courtesy of a request in advance. Once copies have been issued to the employee, the employee assumes the responsibility for maintaining the confidentiality of the information. 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
2.64.430 - Safe workplace. 
    It is the policy of the city of Tucumcari to provide a safe workplace for its employees that is free of known and reasonably foreseeable hazards. 
    Safety in the work place is everyone's business and requires the personal commitment of each employee. 
    The following represent the major guidelines for maintaining a workplace free of recognizable hazards. 
  The city will take all necessary measures to maintain a safe and healthy working environment that is as free from recognizable hazards as is possible. The immediate supervisor is responsible for the safety of the employees working for him/her. The supervisor is responsible for identifying known or reasonably foreseeable hazards in a work area and educating employees to those hazards. 
  The city has issued a safety manual which describes safe work processes and rules that will be applicable to the particular work being done by the various programs in work areas throughout the city, employees must familiarize themselves with the safety manual, and supervisors must ensure that employees, contractors and visitors follow its provisions. 
  Every employee must take responsibility for working safely, staying alert to potential hazards in the work environment, reporting hazards or unsafe conditions to their supervisor and wearing the personal protective equipment required for the work they are doing. 
  Employees who behave in an unsafe way, or who jeopardize the safety of themselves or others through either action or inaction, or who fail to follow the established safety procedures will be subject to corrective disciplinary action. 
  Well-organized and clean work areas are essential to maintaining a safe and hazard-free work environment. Every employee is responsible for maintaining the city's premises in a neat, orderly and clean fashion. 
  Repairs to equipment and electrical lines must be made by qualified personnel only. 
  Employees must use proper lifting techniques whenever moving boxes, furniture, equipment, supplies or other material. 
  Employees who operate a motor vehicle in the conduct of city business are expected to obey all applicable traffic laws. 
  Seat belts must be worn at all times while driving or riding in any motor vehicle while on city business. 
  Employees are prohibited from using a cell-phone, including texting, while driving a vehicle on city business. A driver who must use a cell-phone must first pull over to the side of the road in a safe location, out of traffic. 
  All accidents, "near misses" and incidents where someone could have been injured must be reported to the supervisor. 
  Employees who observe an unsafe condition should report the condition to the immediate supervisor as soon as possible. If the condition persists, the employee should state the problem in writing and submit it to the department manager. 
  Employees must immediately report all work-related accidents, injuries, and illnesses, no matter how minor, to their supervisor for evaluation and appropriate documentation. When an employee is injured, the supervisor will notify the department head, the safety department and the city manager's office. 
  If an injury requires medical attention beyond simple first aid, the city will arrange for medical care and the injured employee will be transported to the authorized health care provider or hospital. 
    For all on-the-job injuries, whether or not medical attention is rendered, the supervisor must complete the supervisor's first report of injury form. The city manager's office has the appropriate forms. The completed form will be returned to the city manager's office. 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
2.64.440 - Secure workplace. 
    It is the policy of the city of Tucumcari to provide a safe and secure work environment for city employees. 
    Contractors will not be permitted to work unsupervised and will not be allowed free access or passwords to either the building or the voice or data communications network. 
    When entering the building, employees should immediately notify their supervisor if they notice any unusual conditions, such as unlocked doors that should be locked, unattended or unclaimed packages or bags lying around, missing equipment or other materials, or other unusual conditions. 
    It is the city's policy to require all visitors to check in at the front desk before entering the work area. It is also the policy of the city that the presence of visitors is primarily intended as a part of ongoing functions and work requirements. While non-work related visitors may be allowed, this will only be to the extent that productivity is maintained. 
    Employees are hereby notified that: The city reserves the right to search workstations, lockers, desks, and city-owned vehicles, for illegal drugs, alcohol, weapons, and stolen property, referred to collectively as 'contraband', to ensure the safety and security of its employees and property. Lunch boxes, briefcases, purses, coats, toolboxes, and other personal property of employees, and their contents may be searched in certain circumstances in accordance with applicable regulations by law enforcement officers. 
Procedure: 
1.	All visitors must receive authorization to enter the office area.
2.	Visitors must indicate who their host is in the city; the host will be called to receive the visitor. Visitors will be escorted by their host at all times while on premises. 
3.	It is the responsibility of every employee to ensure that the presence of visitors does not interfere with productivity in the workplace. Department management may decide to decline the presence of visitors if, in the judgment of the department management, the presence of the visitors causes disruption of productivity in the workplace. 
4.	When there is reasonable cause to believe that an employee has brought contraband onto city premises, the city may conduct a search for the suspect item(s). Any contraband in plain view may be confiscated immediately. 
5.	When contraband is not in plain view, but there is reasonable cause to believe that the item is on city property, city management will notify the employee that a search has been conducted or will be conducted. 
6.	Employees have no reasonable expectation of privacy in, and may not withhold permission for searches of city-supplied equipment or furniture, including desks, lockers, toolboxes, computer systems, e-mail accounts and city owned vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
2.64.450 - Anti-discrimination and sexual harassment policy. 
    It is the policy of the city of Tucumcari to provide a workplace free from harassment of any sort, including but not limited to: intimidation, threats, physical assault, stalking, badgering, insults, bullying and sexual harassment. Harassment includes any repeated unwanted behavior that substantially prevents the person being harassed from performing his or her duties, threatens or intimidates the receiver, or produces an uncomfortable or hostile work environment. The city will not tolerate any harassment or disrespect shown to an employee based on their sex, race, age, sexual orientation, religion or disability. 
    The city will also not tolerate harassment of an employee by non-employees in the workplace. Any employee who experiences harassment by a non-employee, or who observes harassment of an employee by a non-employee should immediately notify their supervisor, and if the employee believes circumstances warrant also contact the city manager's office. Management will take appropriate action to ensure the safety of its employees. 
    Harassment of the city's citizen customers or vendors by city employees is also prohibited. 
Harassment is a Form of Discrimination 
    For this purpose, the term harassment includes slurs, jokes, other offensive remarks, and physical conduct. 
Sexual Harassment 
    The equal employment opportunity commission has adopted guidelines which state that unwelcome sexual advances, requests for sexual favors, and other verbal or physical conduct of a sexual nature constitute "sexual harassment" when: 
1.	Submission to the conduct is an explicit or implicit term or condition of an individual's employment; 
2.	The submission to or rejection of the conduct by an individual is the basis for any employment decision affecting that individual; or 
3.	The conduct has the purpose or effect of unreasonably interfering with an individual's work performance or creating an intimidating, hostile, or offensive working environment. A hostile work environment may be one where crude or vulgar language is used, jokes of a sexual nature are told, comments are made that demean an individual based on gender, unwelcome nicknames, such as honey or sweetie, are used, or photographs, calendars, magazines, books, etc. of nude or partially nude individuals are disseminated. 
    Retaliation against any employee by another employee or by management for using the provisions of this policy is prohibited. Prohibited retaliation includes, but is not limited to, demotion, suspension, failure to make employment recommendations impartially, adversely affecting working conditions or otherwise denying any employment benefits. 
Procedure: 
1.	The first step to resolving a problem is for the employee to communicate directly with the offending person to let them know what the offending behavior is and that it is unwanted. The employee should take care to document the incident(s) of harassment and the steps taken toward resolution. 
2.	If direct discussion is not practical or safe, or the situation is not satisfactorily resolved by the employee and the offending person, then it is imperative that the behavior perceived as harassment be reported as soon as possible to the city manager and/or the human resources director. This immediacy allows for swift investigation, action and resolution. Notification of the problem is essential. 
3.	It is the responsibility of the employee to make this report, as management cannot investigate or remedy situations of which they are not aware. 
4.	Once the city manager or human resources has been notified of a harassment problem, the employee's supervisor will be notified, unless the supervisor is one of the offending parties. All complaints will be treated seriously and will be investigated as promptly and thoroughly as possible. 
5.	Any employee found, through the investigation, to be violating this policy will be subject to corrective disciplinary action (see: Corrective disciplinary action policy). 
6.	The city prohibits employees from hindering internal investigations.
7.	All reported complaints of harassment will be treated with as much confidentiality as possible, consistent with the city's confidentiality policy, and the need to conduct an adequate investigation, while protecting the privacy of those involved. 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
2.64.460 - Anti-violence. 
    It is the policy of the city of Tucumcari to provide a safe, violence-free workplace. 
    Workplace violence will not be tolerated. Examples of workplace violence include, but are not limited to, the following: 
  All threats or acts of violence, including intimidation, harassment, and/or coercion, occurring on the city's premises, regardless of the relationship between the city and the parties involved in the incident. 
  All threats or acts of violence, including intimidation, harassment, and/or coercion, occurring off the city's premises, involving someone who is acting as a city representative. 
  All threats or acts of violence, including intimidation, harassment, and/or coercion, occurring off the city's premises, involving an employee of the city if the threats or acts affect the legitimate interests of the city. 
  Any acts or threats of violence including intimidation, harassment, and/or coercion resulting in the conviction of an employee of the city, or of an individual performing services for the city on a contract or temporary basis, under any criminal code provision relating to violence or threats of violence which adversely affect the legitimate mission and values of the city. 
    Specific examples of conduct, which may be considered threats or acts of violence including intimidation, harassment and/or coercion, include, but are not limited to, the following: 
  Hitting or pushing an individual. 
  Threatening an individual or his/her family, friends, associates, or property with harm. 
  The intentional destruction or threat of destruction of city-owned or employee-owned property. 
  Harassing or threatening phone calls. 
  Harassing surveillance or stalking. 
  The suggestion or intimation that violence is appropriate. 
  Unauthorized possession or inappropriate use of firearms or weapons. 
  Assault or battery. (Assault includes the threat of violence, not necessarily the act. Battery is the enactment of violence.) 
  Unauthorized use, inappropriate display or presentation of any type of weapon that serves to intimidate, threaten or cause fear. 
    Violations of this policy by any employee on the city's property, by any employee acting as a representative of the city while off the city's property, may lead to corrective disciplinary action, up to, and including, discharge, and/or legal action as appropriate. 
    For instances involving actions by non-employees, the city may forcibly remove the individual, institute a restraining order or other legal means as necessary to ensure a safe workplace. 
    The city prohibits retaliation against any employee by another employee for reporting an incident under this policy. Prohibited retaliation includes, but is not limited to, demotion, suspension, failure to make employment recommendations impartially, adversely affecting working conditions or otherwise denying any employment benefit. 
Procedure: 
1.	Every employee and every person on the city's property is encouraged to report incidents of workplace violence of which he or she is aware to the proper authorities. 
2.	The report should also be given to the city manager's office, the reporting individual's immediate supervisor, or another member of management if the immediate Supervisor is not available. 
3.	See the safety policy for handling accidents or injuries that may have occurred due to workplace violence. 
4.	If at any time an employee feels that his or her safety or life is at risk, the employee is instructed to flee the situation immediately and seek help from Tucumcari Police Department or another law enforcement agency. 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
2.64.470 - Smoke free workplace. 
    The city is committed to providing a healthy and safe environment in its buildings and offices for its employees and visitors. In accordance with city of Tucumcari Ordinance 1048, smoking is not permitted in any indoor public place or indoor workplace. Smoking is also not permitted in any city of Tucumcari owned vehicle, or outside the city's buildings within a reasonable distance of any entrance, including a door, window or ventilation system so as to prevent secondhand smoke from entering the indoor workplace. 
    Employees who wish to smoke may do so during their rest breaks, meal period and before and after work. 
    Smoking is permitted only outside the buildings in designated areas a reasonable distance from any entrance, window, or ventilation system. Smoking is not permitted in any city owned vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
2.64.480 - Use of city-owned equipment. 
    Employees shall not misuse or abuse city property, records or other material entrusted to their care, control, or custody. Employees may not remove any city property, records or other material from the premises of the city unless permission has been given by the employee's supervisor. 
    Employees may be required to use certain city-owned equipment off-site in order to more effectively meet the needs of the city. 
    Unauthorized use of any city-owned equipment will subject the employee to corrective disciplinary action up to and including termination. 
City-Owned Vehicles 
    City vehicles will be used only for city business and commuting to and from work, if required for a work-related purpose. When not in use, the vehicle must be parked at city facilities or another location approved by the supervisor. City vehicles shall not be used for personal business, except as incidental in commuting or as determined by the employee's supervisor. Vehicles will not be taken out of the city of Tucumcari without authorization of the department manager. This section does not apply to employees of the police department, which has its own policy. 
    Passengers may not be transported in the city vehicles unless this is a part of the city service or they are on official business. 
    Only the authorized driver or drivers may drive the city vehicle. 
    Misuse of a city vehicle, including use for personal business, transporting or consuming alcoholic beverages other controlled substances in the vehicle, or turning it over to an unauthorized driver, may subject the employee to corrective disciplinary action, up to and including termination. 
    An employee who is found, after investigation, to be negligent in an automobile accident resulting in damage to the vehicle that exceeds the deductible will be required at a minimum to reimburse the city this amount, which is determined under the city's property and liability insurance. 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
2.64.490 - General workplace rules. 
    The workplace behaviors identified below are intended to provide a general overview of the types of employee behaviors that are unacceptable. This is not presented as a complete list. Certainly there may be other behaviors that are clearly not acceptable and will be dealt with by the supervisor when they occur. The exclusion of a specific type of unacceptable behavior from this list does not prevent the city from taking the necessary corrective disciplinary action to ensure that it does not happen again. In addition to the unacceptable behaviors listed here, other unacceptable behaviors have been identified in other chapters of this manual that may result in corrective disciplinary action. 
    All of the behaviors listed here may result in corrective disciplinary action up to and including discharge. 
  Fighting. 
  Abusive or profane language directed at a citizen, a co-worker or a supervisor. 
  Repeated absenteeism or tardiness. 
  Bringing firearms or other weapons to the workplace (other than law enforcement officers or other employees authorized to carry firearms as part of their work assignment). 
  Insubordination, refusal to perform assigned duties or ignoring the directives or assignments issued by the supervisor. 
  Failure to perform assigned duties, or careless performance of duties. 
  Neglect of duty. 
  Theft. 
  Horseplay. 
  Negligence or carelessness resulting in damage to the city's or a citizen's property. 
  Intentional damage to the city's or a citizen's property. 
  Bringing or using illegal drugs or alcohol to the workplace or while on duty or abusing or intentionally misusing prescribed drugs, or reporting for duty while under the influence of illegal drugs or alcohol. 
E-Mail, Telecommunications, Voicemail, and Computer Network System Use 
    The city respects the individual privacy of its employees. However, privacy rights do not extend to work-related conduct or the use of city-owned equipment or supplies. The following policies apply: 
  Systems are Restricted to City Business. Employees are expected to use the e-mail, telecommunications, voicemail, and computer network systems for city business only. Abuse of these system privileges may result in revocation or suspension of the employee's access rights to the systems, and corrective disciplinary action up to and including discharge, and may also include repayment by the employee of expenses incurred. 
  City's Right to Access. Although employees have individual passwords (access codes) to voicemail, e-mail, and computer network systems, these systems are accessible at all times by the city, and are subject to periodic unannounced inspections by the city for business purposes. Employees should not assume that such systems are confidential or that access by the city will not occur. All system passwords must be available to the city, and employees may not use passwords that are unknown to the city. Back-up copies of e-mail and voicemail may be maintained and can be referenced for business and legal reasons. 
  Forbidden Content. Employees are prohibited from using the city's information systems in any way that may be disruptive or offensive to others, including, but not limited to, the transmission of sexually explicit messages, any criminal activity or criminal content, cartoons, ethnic or racial slurs, soliciting for commercial ventures, religious or political causes, outside organizations, other non-job-related solicitations, or anything that may be construed as harassment or disparagement of others. 
  Password Security and Integrity. Employees are prohibited from the unauthorized use of the passwords of other employees to gain access to their e-mail and voicemail messages. 
  Use of Licensed Software. The city respects all computer software copyrights and adheres to the terms of all software licenses to which the city is a part. Employees may not duplicate any licensed software or related documentation for use either on city property or elsewhere unless the city is expressly authorized to do so by agreement with the licensor. Unauthorized duplication of software may subject the employee and/or the city to both civil and criminal penalties under the United States Copyright Act. 
  Employees may not give software to any non-employees including contractors, customers, and others. Employees may use software on local area networks or on multiple machines only in accordance with applicable license agreement. 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
Article 5. - Employee Benefits 

2.64.500 - Insurance benefits. 
    The city of Tucumcari makes available comprehensive medical, disability and life insurance benefit plans for its employees and their dependents, the cost of which is shared by the city and the employee. The employee's contribution is made through payroll deduction. Full-time employees become eligible for insurance benefits on the first day of the month following the month in which they complete thirty (30) days of employment. Information regarding these insurance plans may be obtained by contacting the city manager's office. 
    The city reserves the right and privilege to modify and amend any or all of its benefit plans on an as-needed basis as the benefit plans apply to all current, former and retired employees; to terminate existing benefit programs; or to implement new benefit programs as often as necessary to meet market conditions or to meet budgetary limitations or for any other reason as determined by the board of commissioners. 
    Questions concerning coverage, eligibility, services provided, or any other aspect of the insurance plans, should be directed to the city manager's office. In the case of any conflict between the general descriptions of plan benefits provided here, or by the city manager's office and the plan documents or the summary plan descriptions, the provisions of the governing plan documents shall prevail. 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
2.64.510 - COBRA health benefits continuation. 
    Employees whose employment with the city is terminated or who take an extended leave of absence may be eligible to continue their coverage and that of their covered dependents under the city's group health insurance plans for up to eighteen (18) months. This continuation of coverage is provided in compliance with the provisions of the U.S. Consolidated Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act (COBRA). Additional information regarding this continuation health coverage is available from the city manager's office. 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
2.64.520 - Public Employees Retirement Act. 
    In order to provide the city's employees the opportunity to enjoy a retirement with pay, the city of Tucumcari is a member of the Public Employees Retirement Association (PERA) of New Mexico, the public employee retirement system of the state of New Mexico. For a complete description of the terms and provisions of the PERA Plan please refer to the Public Employees Retirement Act, or your PERA Member Handbook. Further explanation of the PERA Plan may also be obtained from the city manager's office, or by calling the PERA office toll-free at 1-800-342-3422, or by visiting the PERA website online at www.state.nm.us/pera. 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
2.64.530 - New Mexico Retiree Healthcare Program. 
    The city of Tucumcari is a member of the New Mexico Retiree Healthcare Program of the state of New Mexico. For a complete description of the terms and provisions of the plan please refer to your NMRHCA Active Employee Handbook. Further explanation of the plan may also be obtained from the city manager's office, or by calling the authority office toll-free at 1-800-233-2576, or by visiting the authority website online at www.nmrhca.state.nm.us. 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
2.64.540 - Employee training and development. 
    It is the policy of the city of Tucumcari to encourage its employees to further their professional development in fields of study directly related to their present job assignment and for normal lines of career progression within the city. The city believes that the continuing education and professional development of its employees, if pursued in accordance with a plan developed mutually with the supervisor and under the guidance of the city manager's office will result in improvement in the effectiveness and efficiency of the delivery of services to the city's citizens which is the goal management seeks to achieve. 
    Also, employees in certain job classifications or assignments with the city are required by regulatory agencies of the state or federal government to attend continuing professional education classes or seminars to attain or maintain professional certifications. 
    The city may choose to pay for education that will improve the employee's ability to contribute to the mission of the city, or for the training necessary to attain or maintain professional certification required of certain job classifications, provided that budgeted funds are available. The city may also provide paid time off from work and necessary travel expenses for the employee to attend educational sessions. 
(Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 8-14-2014)
Chapter 2.72 - DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ASSISTANCE PROGRAM 
Sections: 

2.72.010 - Regulations adopted by reference. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, the New Mexico State Highway and Transportation Department Disadvantaged Business Assistance Program, is adopted by reference pursuant to Section 3-17-6(11), New Mexico Statutes Annotated 1978, as amended. 
(Ord. 844 § 1, 1992)
2.72.020 - Copy available for inspection. 
A.	A copy of the New Mexico State Highway and Transportation Department Disadvantaged Business Assistance Program is available for inspection during the municipal clerk's normal and regular business hours at City Hall, 215 East Center Street, Tucumcari, New Mexico. 
B.	A copy of the New Mexico State Highway and Transportation Department Disadvantaged Business Assistance Program can be purchased from the municipal clerk, at a cost of fifty cents ($0.50), per page. 
(Ord. 844 §§ 2, 3, 1992)
Chapter 2.76 - LABOR MANAGEMENT RELATIONS 
Sections: 

2.76.010 - Short title. 
    The ordinance codified in this chapter may be cited as the "city of Tucumcari labor management relations ordinance." 
(Ord. 999 § 1, 2004)
2.76.020 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of the labor management relations ordinance is to guarantee employees the right to organize and bargain collectively with their employer; to protect the rights of the employer and the employees and to promote harmonious and cooperative relationships between the employer and the employees; and to acknowledge the obligation of the employer and the employees to provide orderly and uninterrupted services to the citizens. 
(Ord. 999 § 2, 2004)
2.76.030 - Conflicts. 
    In the event of conflict with other city of Tucumcari ordinances, the provisions of the city of Tucumcari labor management relations ordinance shall supersede other previously enacted ordinances. City of Tucumcari sanctioned rules and regulations, administrative directives, departmental rules and regulations, and workplace practices shall control unless there is a conflict with a collective bargaining agreement. Where a conflict exists, the collective bargaining agreement shall control. 
(Ord. 999 § 3, 2004)
2.76.040 - Definitions. 
    As used in the labor management relations ordinance: 
    "Appropriate bargaining unit" means a group of employees designated by the board for the purpose of collective bargaining. 
    "Board" means the city of Tucumcari labor management relations board. 
    "Certification" means the designation by the board of a labor organization as the exclusive representative for all employees in an appropriate bargaining unit. 
    "Collective bargaining" means the act of negotiating between the employer and an exclusive representative for the purpose of entering into a written agreement regarding wages, hours, and other terms and conditions of employment. 
    "Confidential employee" means a person who devotes a majority of his or her time to assisting and acting in a confidential capacity with respect to a person who formulates, determines and effectuates management policies. 
    "Emergency" means one-time crisis that was unforeseen and unavoidable. 
    "Employee" means a regular, nonprobationary employee of the city of Tucumcari. 
    "Employer" means the city of Tucumcari. 
    "Exclusive representative" means a labor organization that, as a result of certification by the board, represents all employees in an appropriate bargaining unit for the purposes of collective bargaining. 
    "Fair share" means the payment to a labor organization which is the exclusive representative for an appropriate bargaining unit by an employee of that bargaining unit who is not a member of that labor organization equal to a certain percentage of membership dues. Such figure is to be calculated based on United States and New Mexico statutes and case law identifying those expenditures by a labor organization which are permissibly chargeable to all employees in the appropriate bargaining unit under United States and New Mexico statutes and case law, including, but not limited to, all expenditures incurred by the labor organization in negotiating the contract applicable to all employees in the appropriate bargaining unit, servicing such contract, and representing all such employees in grievances and disciplinary actions. 
    "Governing body" means the city of Tucumcari city commission. 
    "Impasse" means failure of the employer and an exclusive representative, after good faith bargaining, to reach agreement in the course of negotiating a collective bargaining agreement. 
    "Labor organization" means any employee organization one of whose purposes is the representation of public employees in collective bargaining and in otherwise meeting, consulting, and conferring with employers on matters pertaining to employment relations. 
    "Lockout" means an act by the employer to prevent its employees from going to work for the purpose of resisting demands of the employees' exclusive representative or for the purpose of gaining a concession from the exclusive representative. 
    "Management employee" means an employee who is engaged primarily in executive and management functions and is charged with the responsibility of developing, administering, or effectuating management policies. An employee shall not be deemed a management employee solely because the employee participates in cooperative decision-making programs on an occasional basis. 
    "Mediation" means assistance by an impartial third party to resolve an impasse in contract negotiation between the employer and an exclusive representative through interpretation, suggestion and advice. 
    "Professional employee" means an employee whose work is predominantly intellectual and varied in character and whose work involves the consistent exercise of discretion and judgment in its performance and requires knowledge of an advanced nature in a field of learning customarily requiring specialized study at an institution of higher education or its equivalent. The work of a professional employee is of such character that the output or result accomplished cannot be standardized in relation to a given period of time. 
    "Strike" means an employee's refusal, in concerted action with other employees, to report for duty or his or her wilful absence or withholding of service in whole or in part from the full, faithful, and proper performance of the duties of employment for the purpose of inducing, influencing, or coercing a change in the working conditions, compensation, rights, privileges, or obligations of employment. 
    "Supervisor" means an employee who devotes a majority amount of work time to supervisory duties, who customarily and regularly directs the work of two or more other employees, and who has the authority in the interest of the employer to hire, promote, or discipline other employees or to recommend such actions effectively. This definition does not include individuals who perform merely routine, incidental, or clerical duties or who occasionally assume supervisory or directory roles or whose duties are substantially similar to those of their subordinates and does not include lead employees or employees who occasionally participate in peer review or evaluation of employees. 
(Ord. 999 § 4, 2004)
2.76.050 - Rights of employees. 
    Employees, other than management, supervisory, confidential, and probationary employees, may form, join, or assist any labor organization for the purpose of collective bargaining through a representative chosen by the employees without interference, restraint, or coercion. Employees also have the right to refuse to form, join, or assist any labor organization. 
(Ord. 999 § 5, 2004)
2.76.060 - Management rights. 
    Unless limited by the provisions of a collective bargaining agreement or by other statutory provision, the employer's rights shall include, but are not limited to, the following: 
A.	To direct the work of, hire, promote, assign, transfer, demote, suspend, discharge, or terminate public employees; 
B.	To determine qualifications for employment and the nature and content of personnel examinations; 
C.	To take actions as may be necessary to carry out the mission of the employer in emergencies; and 
D.	The employer retains all rights not specifically limited by a collective bargaining agreement or by the Public Employee Bargaining Act. 
(Ord. 999 § 6, 2004)
2.76.070 - Labor management relations board-Created-Terms. 
A.	The "labor management relations board" is hereby created. The board shall be composed of three members appointed by the mayor and approved by the city commission. One member shall be appointed on the recommendation of individuals representing labor, one member shall be appointed on the recommendation of the city manager and one member shall be appointed on the recommendation of the first two appointees. 
B.	Board members shall serve for a period of one year with terms commencing in the month of September, except in the initial appointment, which will be a shorter term effective, the same day as the ordinance codified in this chapter. Vacancies shall be filled in the same manner as the original appointment, and such appointments shall only be made for the remainder of the unexpired term. A board member may serve an unlimited number of terms. 
C.	During the term of appointment, no board member shall hold or seek any other political office or public employment or be an employee of a union, an organization representing public employees or a public employer. 
D.	Each board member shall be paid per diem and mileage in accordance with the provisions of the Per Diem and Mileage Act. 
(Ord. 999 § 7, 2004)
2.76.080 - Board-Powers and duties. 
A.	The board shall promulgate rules and regulations necessary to accomplish and perform its functions and duties as established in the labor management relations ordinance, including the establishment of procedures for: 
1.	The designation of appropriate bargaining units;
2.	The selection, certification, and decertification of exclusive representative; and
3.	The filing, hearing, and determination of complaints of prohibited practices. This does not apply to negotiation impasse or grievances subject to the required negotiated grievance process. 
B.	The board shall:
1.	Hold hearings and make inquiries necessary to carry out its functions and duties;
2.	Request from employers and labor organizations the information and data necessary to carry out the functions and responsibilities of the board. 
C.	The board may issue subpoenas requiring, upon reasonable notice, the attendance and testimony of witnesses and the production of any evidence, including books, records, correspondence, or documents relevant to the matter in question. The board may prescribe the form of the subpoena, but it shall adhere insofar as practicable to the form used in civil actions in the district court. The board may administer oaths and affirmations, examine witnesses, and receive evidence. Subject to the approval of funds, the board may contract with a third party to assist it in carrying out its functions. 
D.	The board shall decide all issues by majority vote and shall issue its decisions in the form of written orders and opinions. The decisions of the board on interpretation and applications of the ordinance codified in this chapter are final and binding on the parties subject to the appeal process provided in Section 2.76.200 of this chapter. The board's hearing authority does not apply to negotiation impasses or issues dealing with the collective bargaining agreement where a grievance procedure has been negotiated for that purpose by the parties as required by law. 
E.	The board has the power to enforce provisions of the city of Tucumcari labor management relations ordinance and the board's labor management relations rules and regulations through the imposition of appropriate administrative remedies. 
F.	The board shall have no power to promulgate policy other than for its own operation.
G.	No rule or regulation promulgated by the board shall require, directly or indirectly, as a condition of continuous employment, any employee covered by the labor management relations ordinance to pay money to any labor organization that is certified as an exclusive representative. This issue of fair share shall be permissive as opposed to a mandatory subject of bargaining between the employer and the exclusive representative. 
(Ord. 999 § 8, 2004)
2.76.090 - Hearing procedures. 
A.	The board may hold hearings for the purpose of:
1.	Information gathering and inquiry;
2.	Adopting rules and regulations; and
3.	Adjudicating disputes and enforcing the provisions of the labor management relations ordinance, and rules and regulations adopted pursuant to the ordinance codified in this chapter. 
B.	The board shall adopt regulations setting forth procedures to be followed during hearings of the board. Such regulations shall meet minimal due process requirements of the state and federal constitution. 
C.	Proceedings against the party alleged to have committed a prohibited practice shall be commenced by service upon it and the board of a written notice together with a copy of the charges and relief requested. 
D.	All adopted rules and regulations shall be filed in accordance with applicable laws.
E.	A verbatim record made by electronic or other suitable means shall be made of every rule-making and adjudicatory hearing. The record shall not be transcribed unless required for judicial review or unless ordered by the board. The party requesting the transcript shall pay for the transcription, in the case of judicial review the payment shall be made by the party filing the appeal. 
F.	Each party to a prohibited labor practice shall bear the cost of producing its own witnesses and paying its representative for hearings under the ordinance codified in this chapter. 
G.	No regulation proposed to be adopted by the board that affects any person or governmental entity outside of the board and its staff shall be adopted, amended, or repealed without public hearing and comment on the proposed action before the board. The public hearing shall be held after notice of the subject matter of the regulation, the action proposed to be taken, the time and place of the hearing, the manner in which interested persons may present their views, and the method in which copies of the proposed regulation, proposed amendment, or repeal of an existing regulation may be obtained. All meetings shall be held at a city facility. Notice shall be published once at least thirty (30) days prior to the hearing date in a newspaper of general circulation in the city of Tucumcari, and notice shall be mailed at least thirty (30) days prior to the hearing date to all persons who have made a written request for advance notice of hearings. 
(Ord. 999 § 9, 2004)
2.76.100 - Appropriate bargaining units. 
A.	The board shall, upon receipt of a petition for a representation election filed by a labor organization, designate the appropriate bargaining unit. Appropriate bargaining units shall be established on the basis of occupational groups or clear and identifiable community of interest in employment terms, employment conditions, and related personnel matters among the employees involved. Occupational groups shall generally be identified as blue collar, secretarial clerical, technical, para-professional, professional, corrections, firefighters, and police officers. Department, craft, or trade designations other than as specified above shall not determine bargaining units. The parties, by mutual agreement and approval of the board, may further consolidate occupational groups. The essential factors in determining appropriate bargaining units shall include the principles of efficient administration of government, the history of collective bargaining, and the assurance to employees of their rights guaranteed by the ordinance codified in this chapter. 
B.	If the labor organization and the employer cannot agree on the appropriate bargaining unit within thirty (30) days, the board shall hold a hearing concerning the composition of the bargaining unit. Any agreement as to the appropriate bargaining unit between the employer and the labor organization is subject to the approval of the board. 
C.	The board shall not include in any appropriate bargaining unit, probationary, supervisory, managerial, or confidential employees. 
(Ord. 999 § 10, 2004)
2.76.110 - Elections. 
A.	Whenever, in accordance with regulations prescribed by the board, a petition is filed by a labor organization containing the signatures of at least thirty (30) percent of the employees in an appropriate bargaining unit, the board shall post a notice to affected employees regarding the filed petition and proceed with the process for conducting a secret ballot representation election. 
B.	Once a labor organization has filed a petition with the board requesting a representation election, other labor organizations may seek to be placed on the ballot. Any labor organization may file a competing petition containing the signatures of not less than thirty (30) percent of the employees in the appropriate bargaining unit no later than ten (10) calendar days after the board has posted a written notice that a petition for a representation election has been filed by a labor organization. 
C.	All representation elections shall include the option for "no representation," except in a runoff election where the choice of "no representation" was not one of the two choices that received the highest votes. 
D.	In the event of an election with two or more labor organizations on the ballot and none of the choices on the ballot received a majority of the votes cast, then a runoff election shall be held within fifteen (15) calendar days. The choices on the runoff election shall consist of the two choices, which received the greatest number of votes in the original election. 
E.	A valid election requires that at least forty (40) percent of the eligible employees in an appropriate bargaining unit cast a vote. In an election with only one labor organization, and the majority of the votes cast are in favor of representation the board shall certify that labor organization as the exclusive representative for all the employees in the bargaining unit. 
F.	No election shall be conducted if an election has been conducted in the twelve (12) month period immediately preceding the proposed representation election. No election shall be held during the term of an existing collective bargaining agreement, except as provided in Section 2.76.130(B) of this chapter, or after the expiration of the third year of a collective bargaining agreement with a term of more than three years. 
G.	Election disputes shall be resolved by the board.
H.	As an alternative to the provisions of subsection A of this section, the employer and a labor organization with a reasonable basis for claiming to represent a majority of the employees in an appropriate bargaining unit may establish an alternative appropriate procedure for determining majority status. The procedure may include a labor organization's submission of authorization cards from a majority of the employees in an appropriate bargaining unit. The local board shall not certify an appropriate bargaining unit if the employer objects to the certification without an election. 
(Ord. 999 § 11, 2004)
2.76.120 - Exclusive representation. 
    A labor organization that has been certified by the board as the exclusive representative for employees in an appropriate bargaining unit shall represent all employees in the bargaining unit. The exclusive representative shall act for all employees in the bargaining unit and negotiate a collective bargaining agreement covering all employees in the bargaining unit. The exclusive representative shall represent the interests of all employees in the bargaining unit without discrimination or regard to membership or nonmembership in the labor organization. The existence of an exclusive bargaining representative shall not prevent employees from taking their grievances through the grievance process or filing prohibited practices with the board. Any settlement of a grievance or relief given on a prohibited practice brought by an individual shall not be inconsistent with or in violation of the collective bargaining agreement in effect between the employer and the exclusive representative or inconsistent with or in violation of a memorandum of understanding between the employer and the exclusive representative applicable to the day-to-day administration of the collective bargaining agreement. The exclusive representative shall be afforded the opportunity to be present at such hearings and make its views known. 
(Ord. 999 § 12, 2004)
2.76.130 - Decertification of exclusive representative. 
A.	Any member of a labor organization or the labor organization itself may initiate decertification of a labor organization as the exclusive representative if thirty (30) percent of the employees in the appropriate bargaining unit make a written request to the board for a decertification election. A decertification election shall be valid only if at least forty (40) percent of the eligible employees in the bargaining unit vote in the election. 
B.	When there is a collective bargaining agreement in effect, a request for a decertification election shall be made to the board no earlier than ninety (90) days and no later than sixty (60) days before the expiration of the collective bargaining agreement; provided, however, that a request for a decertification election may be filed at any time after the expiration of the third year of a collective bargaining agreement with a term of more than three years. 
C.	When, within the time period prescribed in subsection B of this section, a competing labor organization files a petition containing signatures of at least thirty (30) percent of the employees in the appropriate bargaining unit, a representation election rather than a decertification election shall be conducted. 
D.	When an exclusive representative has been certified but no collective bargaining agreement is in effect, the board shall not accept a request for a decertification election earlier than twelve (12) months subsequent to a labor organization's certification as the exclusive representative. 
(Ord. 999 § 13, 2004)
2.76.140 - Scope of bargaining. 
A.	Except for retirement programs provided under the Public Employees Retirement Act, the parties shall bargain in good faith on all wages, hours and other terms and conditions of employment and other issues agreed to by the parties. The parties shall enter into a written agreement covering employment relations regarding the issues agreed to in collective bargaining. 
B.	Bargaining in good faith shall not require either party to agree to a proposal or to make a concession. 
C.
