4.	On streets classified as arterial, sidewalks shall be setback at least twelve (12) feet from the back of the curb, at least four inches from the property line, and a minimum of two-tenths feet above the top of the curb. 
5.	Where sufficient right-of-way is not available, the city planning department may set a special sidewalk location standard within the right-of-way. 
6.	The transverse slope of the walk and setback area shall be one-fourth inch per foot, sloping toward the street. 
7.	All sidewalk design plans submitted must specify the materials to be used and any such materials shall conform to the performance standards for sidewalk materials as established by the city planning department through nationally approved testing procedures. 
8.	The city planning department shall be given three days notice before any material is placed in order that an inspection may be made of the sub-grade, the forms, and the spacing for expansion-contraction joints. The excavating and grading shall be smoothly and neatly done, and to the proper depth, all large stones, boulders, roots, other vegetation, and rubbish of every description to conform to the profile and grade of the walk when finished. Soft, spongy or loamy areas in the sub-grade must be removed and the space refilled with stable material thoroughly compacted. 
(Ord. 943 § 16 (part), 1999; prior code § 14-2-22)
11.04.200 - Waivers and variances. 
A.	The city's right-of-way is insufficient in width to permit the construction of a sidewalk of standard dimension and placement. 
B.	The location of the sidewalk may be varied within the right-of-way so that trees possessing the following characteristics may be preserved: 
1.	Adaptability to the particular soil, climate and moisture conditions of this city;
2.	High resistance to gas, smoke and disease;
3.	Freedom from litter and offensive odors;
4.	Wood that is not brittle and thereby easily broken by wind and sleet;
5.	A root structure compatible with planting in confined areas;
6.	Long normal life.
    Any waivers or variances granted hereunder are not to be considered as permanent but are subject to annual review by the city manager. A grant of a waiver or variance will not prohibit the property concerned from being included in an improvement district at a future date. 
C.	Appeals may be taken from a determination by the city manager to the board of appeals by filing written notice with the city clerk within ten (10) days after denial of a permit or a variance or after termination of a variance. 
(Prior code § 14-2-23)
11.04.210 - Sidewalk repair and maintenance. 
A.	All sidewalks shall be kept clean from rocks and other obstructions including ice and snow and in a state of good repair by the owner, occupants or agents in charge of the abutting property. A sidewalk in good repair shall be free of cracks, floats, obstructions, depressions and/or any and all other defects and shall have a uniform longitudinal and transverse gradient. 
B.	All areas directly over sidewalks, to a height of eight feet shall be maintained free of vegetation or other obstruction by the owners, occupants or agents in charge of the abutting property. 
C.	The sidewalk setback area and all plantings therein, shall be maintained by the owners, occupants or agents in charge of the abutting property. 
D.	No item of street furniture or other item which would obstruct pedestrians or effectively reduce the width of a sidewalk below the dimensions established in Section 11.04.190 may be placed in, on, over or under the sidewalk unless a waiver allowing such item is obtained from the city manager. 
E.	When the city manager determines that there is a violation of the provisions of Section 11.04.200, he or she may cause a notice to be served upon the owners or agents in charge of the property abutting the sidewalk or sidewalk setback area directing that repair or maintenance or removal of obstruction be made within a designated period of time. If the owners or agents in charge of the property fail to comply with such order or notice of repair or maintenance or removal of obstructions be made at the cost and expense of such owners or agents in charge of the property and the cost of such repairs or maintenance or removal of obstruction shall constitute a lien against such property and shall be foreclosed in the same manner provided by law for the foreclosure of municipal liens. 
(Ord. 973, 2002; prior code § 14-2-24)
11.04.220 - Curb and gutter. 
    Curb and gutter shall conform in dimension, material and placement technique to standards established by the city planning department. 
(Ord. 973, 2002; Ord. 943 § 16 (part), 1999; prior code § 14-2-25)
11.04.230 - Drive pads. 
A.	Specifications. The grading and excavating for drive pads shall be done in conformance with Section 11.04.190(B)(7). Drive pads within the public right-of-way shall be constructed of materials which shall conform to the performance standards for drive pad materials as established by the city planning department through nationally approved testing procedures. Drive pad design shall be approved by the city planning department prior to issuance of construction permits. 
B.	Drive Pad Crossing of Sidewalks. Drive pad shall cross the sidewalk on the sidewalk grade line without depression of the sidewalk. 
C.	Abandoned Drive Pad. All drive pads abandoned or no longer being used shall have the curb and gutter replaced and the sidewalk installed at the grade of the adjacent sidewalk. 
D.	Drive Pad Location and Width. The location and width of curb cuts for drive pads shall be approved by the city planning department prior to issuance of a construction permit. 
(Ord. 973, 2002; Ord. 943 § 16 (part), 1999; prior code § 14-2-26)
11.04.240 - Delegation of authority. 
    The authority of the city manager as set forth in Sections 11.04.110 through 11.04.240 is delegable by him or her to departments of the city and agencies thereof. 
(Ord. 973, 2002; prior code § 14-2-27)
11.04.250 - Openings in pavement-Permit required. 
    It is unlawful for any person to cut any opening or hole in the pavement on any street or alley in the city without first having secured a permit from the city. 
(Ord. 973, 2002; prior code § 14-2-29)
11.04.260 - Openings in pavement-Application for permit. 
    Every person desiring to cut an opening or hole in any paved street or alley of the city, shall fill out an application form which will be furnished to any person desiring the same by the city planning department. The form shall include sufficient information to enable the city planning department to determine whether the person making the application has a good and sufficient reason for having an opening or hole cut in the pavement. 
(Ord. 973, 2002; Ord. 943 § 16 (part), 1999; prior code § 14-2-30)
11.04.270 - Openings in pavement-City planning department authority to approve application. 
    The city planning department shall examine each application so submitted and shall make any investigation he or she deems necessary to determine whether the necessity exists for the cutting of an opening or hole in the pavement, and shall, when his or her investigation is completed, either reject or approve the application. 
(Ord. 973, 2002; Ord. 943 § 16 (part), 1999; prior code § 14-2-31)
11.04.280 - Openings in pavement-Issuance of permit-Fee. 
    The clerk shall, upon presentation of an application approved by the city planning department and upon payment of a fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00), issue a permit to the applicant for the cutting of an opening or hole in the pavement at a specific location, and for a specific purpose. 
(Ord. 973, 2002; Ord. 943 § 16 (part), 1999; prior code § 14-2-32)
11.04.290 - Opening pavement-Closing-Cost. 
    The holder of a permit may have a proper opening or hole cut in the pavement at the place specified in the application and shall keep the opening barricaded for the protection of all motorists or pedestrians. The permittee shall complete all necessary work as promptly as possible and shall notify the city planning department immediately when the hole is ready to be closed. All such openings shall then be closed and the pavement replaced by the city under the supervision of the city planning department. The cost of labor and material and a reasonable charge for use of equipment shall be paid by the permittee to the city at the office of the clerk. The city planning department shall furnish an itemized statement of such charges to the permittee as soon as possible after replacement work is completed. 
(Ord. 973, 2002; Ord. 943 § 16 (part), 1999; prior code § 14-2-33)
11.04.300 - Removing curbing-Permit-Fee. 
    If any person, firm or corporation desires to remove existing curbing or any portion thereof in the city, approval for such purpose shall first be obtained from the city planning department or the manager, and a permit shall be obtained from the clerk upon payment of the fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(Ord. 1025 § 1, 2006: Ord. 973, 2002; Ord. 943 § 16 (part), 1999; prior code § 14-2-35)
11.04.310 - Removing curbing-Permit required-Exception. 
    No curbing shall be removed by any person, firm or corporation unless the provisions provided for in Section 11.04.300 are first complied with, except that the city in doing street work may remove or replace curbing, and a contractor or other person or firm authorized by the city may remove, build or replace curbing in performing work in the improvement of the city streets, without it being necessary to obtain a permit as provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. 973, 2002; prior code § 14-2-36)
11.04.320 - Curbing replacement-Supervision. 
    The breaking down, building or replacing of curbing in the streets of the city, as provided in Section 11.04.300, shall only be done when it is necessary and it shall be under the general supervision of the city planning department or the manager, and the amount of curb to be torn down and replaced shall first be approved by the city planning department or the manager. 
(Ord. 943 § 16 (part), 1999; prior code § 14-2-37)
11.04.330 - Street numbering. 
    All buildings fronting on the streets, avenues or alleys in the city shall be numbered in conformity with the following provisions: 
A.	Odd numbers shall be given to all buildings on the north and west side of the streets and avenues, and even numbers to those on the south and east sides of the same; and the numbers of the buildings fronting on alleys shall be the same as of buildings of the same lot fronting on the streets, with the figure "1/2" added thus, building fronting street "244," alley "2441/2." 
B.	On streets and avenues running eastwardly and westwardly in the city, numbering shall commence at "100" at Second Street, and increase in each direction at the rate of one hundred numbers for each block or space of ground between two streets or avenues; and to distinguish such numbers the streets aforesaid shall be designated, counting from Second Street as East Main and West Main Street, etc. 
C.	On streets and avenues running northwardly and southwardly in the city, numbering shall commence at "100" at Main Street, and increase in each direction at the rate of one hundred numbers for each block or space of ground between two streets or avenues; and to designate such numbers the streets aforesaid shall be designated, counting from Main Street as North Second and South Second Street, and the same with all other streets running at right angles with Main Street, in the limits of the city. 
(Prior code § 14-2-39)
11.04.340 - Numbering buildings. 
    In designing the numbers of all buildings in conformity with the preceding provisions, one number shall be allowed for each lot or piece of ground twenty-five (25) feet in width, and two numbers for each lot or piece of ground exceeding twenty-five (25) feet and not exceeding fifty (50) feet in width; and the city planning department on application shall furnish the owner or agent of each building, now or hereafter to be erected, with the proper number of the building. 
(Ord. 943 § 16 (part), 1999; prior code § 14-2-40)
11.04.350 - Numbers to be placed on buildings. 
    It is made the duty of every owner, occupant or agent of any building in the city required to be numbered by the provisions herein, to put on such buildings now built, in a conspicuous place, next to the street on which it fronts, the proper number or numbers thereof, and the number or numbers shall be in figures not less than three inches in length, and so place such numbers on all buildings hereafter built within ten (10) days after the completion or occupation thereof, provided, that if the lot or piece of ground occupied by a single dwelling house is of sufficient width to require more than one number, it shall be sufficient to place on such house the number of the lot on which the main entrance thereof is situated. 
(Prior code § 14-2-41)
11.04.360 - Failure to number buildings-Penalty. 
    In case any owner or occupant of any building in this city shall refuse, fail or neglect to number such building within the time specified in the next preceding section, or shall number or attempt to number such building otherwise than in conformity with the provisions herein, such person shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), and when such fine is paid, the city planning department shall cause such building to be correctly numbered at the expense of the city. 
(Ord. 943 § 16 (part), 1999; Ord. 932 § 1(part), 1999; prior code § 14-2-42)
11.04.370 - Signs with street names to be installed. 
    The city planning department shall, at the expense of the city, cause good substantial signs, bearing the names of the streets and avenues of the city, respectively, to be put up and maintained as follows: 
    Upon at least two of the corners at each crossing of all streets and avenues, which sign shall be so placed as to be in plain view of persons passing either way upon any of such streets or avenues; provided that, if there are no buildings at or near such crossing, or the streets and avenues are not open or graded, then putting up of such signs may be postponed until such time as it is deemed necessary, or until after it shall be directed by a resolution of the commission. 
(Ord. 943 § 16 (part), 1999; prior code § 14-2-43)
11.04.380 - Removal of signs-Penalty. 
    Any person who shall purposely take down or in any manner mar or injure any sign or number put up under the provisions herein, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and on conviction thereof, shall be fined in any sum not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Ord. 932 § 1(part), 1999; prior code § 14-2-44)
11.04.390 - Sidewalks required-New construction. 
    From and after the effective date of this code it shall be the duty of any person, firm or corporation that undertakes the construction of any new dwelling house, apartment or other new building within the city limits of the city, to incorporate in their plans and construct sidewalks in accordance with the specifications for sidewalks set forth in detail in Sections 11.04.110 through 11.04.120. 
(Prior code § 14-2-45)
11.04.400 - Construction and repair of sidewalks-City commission authority. 
    The commission may at any time by proper resolutions order the construction of a new sidewalk in any built up area of the city or may condemn any old sidewalk or part thereof, when the same shall have been broken, worn or has become otherwise defective from any cause and may order the same to be reconstructed or repaired, if, in the opinion of the commission the case may require such action, and should any owner of the property, in the case of new construction or owner of the abutting property in the case of defective sidewalks, fail or refuse to so construct, reconstruct, or repair the same as ordered, within sixty (60) days after the resolutions requiring the same are passed, then the city may proceed to construct, reconstruct or repair such sidewalks at the expense of the owner of the property, and shall issue tax bills and file a lien therefor in the manner provided by law. 
(Prior code § 14-2-46)
11.04.410 - Construction and repair of sidewalks-Permit required. 
    All persons desiring to construct, reconstruct or repair sidewalks in the city, or having been ordered to do so, shall first secure a permit from the city planning department 
(Ord. 943 § 16 (part), 1999; prior code § 14-2-47)
11.04.420 - Construction and repair of sidewalks-Specifications-Plans. 
    All sidewalk construction and repair in the city must be in accordance with the specifications referred to in Section 11.04.390 and plans approved by the city planning department. 
(Ord. 943 § 16 (part), 1999; prior code § 14-2-48)
11.04.430 - City planning department to inspect sidewalks. 
    The city planning department must make proper inspection of all sidewalks and is authorized to condemn any or all sidewalks not installed according to specifications and approved plans. 
(Ord. 943 § 16 (part), 1999; prior code § 14-2-49)
11.04.435 - Parking time limits. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, allow or permit any vehicle registered in his or her name, or owned or operated by him or her, or in his or her possession, or under his or her control, to be or remain in a parking space for a period of time longer than two hours on either side of Main Street, between Adams Street and Third Street during the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. Monday through Friday of each week and during the hours of 8:00 a.m. and noon on Saturdays. No parking restriction shall be in effect on Sundays and legal holidays. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, allow or permit any vehicle registered in his or her name or owned or operated by him or her, or in his or her possession, or under his or her control, to be or remain in a parking space for a period of time longer than two hours on either side of Center Street between Adams Street and Third Street during the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. Monday through Friday of each week and during the hours of 8:00 a.m. and noon on Saturdays. No parking restriction shall be in effect on Sundays and legal holidays. 
    Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a petty misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be fined the sum of ten dollars. 
(Ord. 974, 2002)
11.04.440 - Violations-Penalties. 
    Any person who violates any provision of Sections 11.04.020 through 11.04.100 shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not to exceed five hundred Dollars ($500.00) or by imprisonment in jail for not more than thirty (30) days, at the discretion of the court. Each day upon which a violation continues, shall be deemed a separate offense. 
    Any person found guilty of violating any of the provisions of Sections 11.04.110 through 11.04.230 shall be fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned for a period of not more than ninety (90) days or both such fine and imprisonment, and each day any provision of said sections is violated shall constitute a separate offense. 
    Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of Sections 11.04.250 through 11.04.280 or who shall make or authorize any other person to make an opening or hole in the pavement on any street or alley within the city without first complying with the terms of this chapter and securing proper permit for such work, shall be punished by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or by imprisonment for not more than ninety (90) days, in the discretion of the court trying the case. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of Sections 11.04.300 through 11.04.320 shall be punished by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or by imprisonment in jail for a period of not more than ninety (90) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment, in the discretion of the court. 
(Ord. 932 § 1(part), 1999; prior code §§ 14-2-12, 14-2-28, 14-2-34 and 14-2-38)
Chapter 11.08 - EXCAVATIONS AND STREET CUTS 
Sections: 

11.08.010 - Permits required. 
    It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to cut or destroy pavements, curbs or sidewalks, or to remove the same, or to make excavations in the streets, alleys or public ways in the city for any purpose without first applying for and receiving a permit for such purposes from the clerk; provided, however, any person maintaining pipes, lines or other underground facilities in or under the surface of any street may proceed with an opening without a permit when emergency circumstances demand the work to be done immediately and a permit cannot reasonably and practically be obtained beforehand. The person shall thereafter apply for a permit on the first regular business day on which the office of the city planning department is open for business and the permit shall be retroactive to the date when the work was begun. When an application is made and a permit issued in connection with any plumbing or other work requiring excavations to be made in any street, alley or public way, the permit issued therefor shall be deemed to satisfy the requirement of this section. 
(Prior code § 4-5-1)
11.08.020 - Permit application fees. 
    The application for the permit required in Section 11.08.010 shall show the description of the property, the location of and the nature of the work to be done. The permit shall be issued only upon the approval of the city planning department. All such work shall be done and completed in accordance with the provisions of this chapter and the same shall be supervised by the city planning department or some member of his or her department appointed by him or her for the purpose. The application in each case shall be accompanied by a fee of two dollars ($2.00). 
(Ord. 943 § 16 (part), 1999; prior code § 4-5-2)
11.08.030 - Replacement-Backfill-Costs. 
    In every case, except where otherwise required by law, the cost of restoring any pavement, curb or sidewalk, removed in accordance with this chapter, shall be at the expense of the person holding the permit. The city reserves the right to restore the public work removed at its option, the same to be a charge against the permit holder. Where excavation is made in the street or public way, the permit holder shall backfill the same in accordance with, and under the directions of, the city planning department as provided by regulations of the department of engineering in the city. 
(Ord. 943 § 16 (part), 1999; prior code § 4-5-3)
11.08.040 - Curb cuts. 
    Where curbs are cut, removed or cut and replaced, all such work shall be done at the expense of the person having a permit or authority for such purpose. Where the curb shall be replaced, the work shall be done in accordance with the standard specifications and plans therefor established by the city planning department and kept on file in the office of the city clerk and city planning department. It is unlawful for any person to change the grade of any curb line in replacing any curb, or to fail to replace curb; and it is further unlawful to bridge any curb and gutter or to place any building materials therein to establish a crossing from the street to any private premises, except temporarily during the course of any work in the making of a driveway entrance. 
(Ord. 943 § 16 (part), 1999; prior code § 4-5-4)
11.08.050 - Private driveways-Costs. 
    When any street is being paved and curbed, or has been paved and curbed, any person being the owner of lands abutting thereon and who may desire to construct a driveway from the curb line to the lot line may do so; provided, that a permit shall be required as provided by Section 11.08.010 where any curb shall be cut or removed. The driveway shall extend from the curb line to the lot line and the curb and gutter shall be removed and the gutter restored and the driveway constructed under the direction of the city planning department or his or her assistant in accordance with the standard specifications and plans established by the city planning department and kept on file in the office of the city clerk and the office of the planning department. All such work shall be done in such a manner as not to change or interfere with the gutter flow line or sidewalk grades where such driveway crosses any sidewalk; provided further, that where the sidewalk shall not satisfy the requirements or specifications for sidewalks used as a part of a driveway entrance, the sidewalk shall be removed and reconstructed according to the standard specifications therefor; provided, however, that where it is proposed to remove any curb to widen the street for additional parking space at the side thereof, or to remove any curb to establish a filling station or other commercial or business entrance at the application of any private firm or corporation, the application therefor shall be submitted to the planning commission for its approval. Upon approval being granted the work shall be performed and completed in accordance with the standard specifications and plans of the city planning department established for such purposes. All work shall be done at the cost of the person, firm or corporation owning the abutting lands. 
(Ord. 943 § 16 (part), 1999; prior code § 4-5-5)
11.08.060 - Culverts-Conformance to plans and specifications. 
    Culverts may be constructed or maintained across any drainage ditch, irrigation ditch or drain when it shall be impracticable to open, construct or maintain an entrance across any ditch or drain, upon application to and the approval of the city planning department. All such culverts shall be placed and constructed in accordance with the standard specifications and plans established by the planning department for such purposes. The abutting landowner shall pay the cost of all such culverts in the manner provided by law. 
(Ord. 943 § 16 (part), 1999; prior code § 4-5-6)
11.08.070 - Culverts-Construction by city-Assessment. 
    The commission may, if it deems it necessary, pass a resolution declaring it necessary to construct culvert or culverts on a uniform line and grade and of proper size to handle drainage at any private driveway entrance or entrances in any street of dirt, sand or gravel constructed by the city. Before such work shall be authorized, an application for construction of the culvert or culverts may be filed with the clerk by any resident owner or official of the city, and a hearing shall be held on the application by the governing body of the city within a reasonable time after the filing of the application. A ten (10)-day notice of the hearing shall be given to all property owners affected, whose property will be subject to a special assessment as provided hereafter. The notice of hearing shall be published once in the official city paper. If upon the hearing, the governing body deems it desirable and necessary to construct the culvert or culverts as requested in the application, then an ordinance shall be passed directing the culvert or culverts to be placed and constructed. The cost thereof shall be charged to the owner or owners of the adjoining land benefited by the construction. When the cost of construction of the culvert or culverts is ascertained, the governing body shall levy an assessment in not more than five annual installments against the lots and pieces of ground chargeable therefor, the same to be made and collected as provided by law; provided, that the city may temporarily finance the cost of such improvement until such time as the proceeds of the assessment shall be available to the city. 
(Prior code § 4-5-7)
11.08.080 - Cutting and removing pavement-Replacement. 
    The person having a permit or authority to cut or remove any pavement or permanent surfacing of any street shall be at the discretion of the city planning department, replace the same at the expense of the permit holder, the same to be done in accordance with the specifications set forth by the city planning department; provided, that where the work of replacement and restoration is not completed by the permit holder in accordance with the requirements of this section, the city manager may direct the proper officers of the city to remove and replace such work at the cost of the person who had begun such work and the city may refuse to grant permits for additional work of like nature to such persons unless such charges against them have been paid and satisfied. 
(Ord. 943 § 16 (part), 1999; prior code § 4-5-8)
11.08.090 - Excavations generally. 
    The permit in every case authorizing the making of any excavation in any street, alley or public grounds of the city shall fix and limit the extent of the excavation to be made and where it is practicable and desirable, the permit may require the work to be done without making any excavation or the cutting or removing of any pavement, curb or sidewalk; provided that water and sewer lines or other utility service pipes and lines may be installed prior to the permanent improving of any street or the laying of any sidewalk in the places reserved for such lines or pipes. 
(Prior code § 4-5-9)
11.08.100 - Open excavations-Building materials-Barricades. 
    It is unlawful for any person to leave any excavation open or uncovered or to leave any building materials, vehicles or like obstructions in or on any street, alley, sidewalk or public way in the city during the course of any improvement unless the same be guarded by barricades at all times or in the nighttime unless the work or obstruction is guarded with red lanterns or lights sufficient in number and so placed as to guard vehicles and passersby from injury or danger. All such lights shall be lighted before dark and left lighted during the nighttime; provided, that it shall be the duty of any officer or employee of the city having charge of any such work for the city to comply with the provisions of this section and the laws of New Mexico pertaining thereto and to maintain the required barricades, signs and lights as in the case of other persons; provided further, that the street superintendent is authorized to direct the placing of any barricades, warning or detour signs or lights required by law, and the street superintendent is authorized, if the public safety requires it, to close off the public streets or sidewalks or any portion thereof to prevent the use of the same during the progress of any work. 
(Prior code § 4-5-10)
11.08.110 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter or who shall make or authorize any other person to make an opening or hole in the pavement on any street or alley within the city, without first complying with the terms of this chapter and securing proper permit for such work, shall be punished by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or by imprisonment for not more than ninety (90) days in the discretion of the court trying the case. 
(Ord. 932 § 1(part), 1999: prior code § 4-5-11)
Chapter 11.12 - CEMETERIES 
Sections: 
Article 1. - Administration of City Cemeteries 

11.12.010 - Sale of cemetery lots. 
    All cemetery lots owned by the city or which are under the control of the city for the purpose of sale shall be sold for such amounts as may be fixed by motion or resolution of the commission duly passed and adopted. 
(Prior code § 5-1-1)
11.12.020 - Payment in full-Reservation of lots. 
    All cemetery lots which are for sale by the city shall be paid for in full within thirty (30) days from the time that any lot is reserved by any person or firm; provided, however, that no cemetery lot reserved for purchase from the city shall be used for burial purposes without the lot first having been paid for in full, and no cemetery lot shall be reserved for sale unless written application is made to the city clerk for the reservation. 
(Prior code § 5-1-2)
(Ord. No. 1090, § 1, 11-17-2011)
11.12.030 - Lots to be marked. 
    The cemetery superintendent shall, as soon as convenient and possible, cause each and every cemetery lot that is for sale by the city to be marked with a proper identification of the lot describing fully the lot. 
(Prior code § 5-1-3)
(Ord. No. 1090, § 2, 11-17-2011)
11.12.040 - Unlawful to use lot when. 
    It is unlawful for any person to make use or participate in making use for burial purposes or otherwise of a city cemetery lot without the lot first having been paid for to the city. 
(Prior code § 5-1-4)
11.12.050 - Cemetery conveyances-Deed. 
    All cemetery deeds or conveyances shall be issued to the purchaser thereof under the seal of the city and the same shall be signed by the mayor and countersigned by the clerk. All persons desiring to purchase cemetery lots or grave space shall apply to the city clerk at his or her office and upon payment of the purchase price thereof shall be entitled to a certificate conveying such rights to the cemetery lot as shall be authorized by law. All such certificates shall be recorded in the office of the city clerk. 
(Prior code § 5-1-5)
(Ord. No. 1090, § 3, 11-17-2011)
11.12.060 - Cemetery records. 
    The city clerk shall have the custody of the original and official records of the cemetery department and shall keep all maps and plats of the cemetery and the cemetery register showing the ownership of each lot or fraction thereof and the record of interments in each grave space of each lot. He or she shall collect all fees and charges and other sums due the city and account for the same. He or she shall issue all permits in connection with interments, disinterments, buildings and structures and monumental work as provided by this chapter. He or she shall keep separate accounts of the cemetery endowment fund, of the sale of lots and of all service charges received by him or her. All funds coming into the city to be used for the maintenance and operation of the cemetery shall be by him or her paid into the general operating fund of the city. He or she shall make such reports in connection therewith as may hereafter be required. 
(Prior code § 5-1-6)
11.12.070 - Sexton-Assistant sexton. 
    The sexton, or in his or her absence the assistant sexton, shall be charged with the following duties under the general direction of the cemetery superintendent: 
A.	He or she shall superintend all improvements in the cemetery such as grading, planting, trimming the plants and trees, laying out avenues, and keeping the grounds, lots and avenues in proper order. 
B.	He or she shall have general direction of opening, and reopening, of graves and the burying and disinterment of the dead. He or she shall see that an accurate record is kept of the location of the graves in the various lots and make a report thereof to the city clerk upon return of the burial permit. 
C.	He or she shall have general supervision and direction in the building of all foundations, vaults, tombs, mausoleums and monuments and shall construct or cause to be constructed a foundation of sufficient size, depth and proper footings and reinforcement to cause footings and bases to last indefinitely. He or she shall allow no construction work of any kind on lots, graves, or areas, or the planting of trees or shrubbery without his or her supervision. 
D.	He or she shall see that all memorials, markers and corner stones on lots are set in their proper places and set properly in accordance with the permit issued by the city clerk, where one is required. 
E.	He or she shall supervise all employees keeping an account of their hours of work, and shall have general charge of all tools, equipment and implements belonging to the cemetery and be responsible for their safekeeping and maintenance. 
F.	He or she shall have the power and authority of a police officer to enforce all applicable ordinances and regulations of the city. 
(Prior code § 5-1-7)
11.12.080 - Cemetery reports. 
    The sexton shall cause monthly and yearly reports of the cemetery department to be prepared and filed with the manager for submission to the board of commissioners. The report shall among other things include a statement of the number and kind of all permits issued by the sexton and the amount of service charges paid for each kind of permit and the total sums received, the number of lots or fraction thereof sold during the month and the sale price received therefore and the total of such sales, a statement of the number of lots or fraction thereof transferred to the city or other parties and the total consideration involved, and a statement of all other cemetery charges accrued and received and the charges uncollected. The annual report shall include a summary of the monthly reports. 
    The manager is authorized to require reports of other cemetery officers and employees pertaining to their duties with a full accounting of all work performed by them upon such occasion as determined by the manager. 
(Prior code § 5-1-8)
(Ord. No. 1090, § 4, 11-17-2011)
Article 2. - Graves 

11.12.090 - Placing and depth. 
    Unless a grave opening permit shall specify otherwise, all graves shall be not less than eighteen (18) inches within the front boundary line of the lot, nor closer than six inches to another grave and lot less than five and one-half feet deep for an adult grave; provided, that the depth of all other graves shall be determined by the cemetery sexton. 
(Prior code § 5-2-1)
11.12.100 - Number of caskets in grave. 
    There shall be no more than one casket in each grave unless the caskets are placed side by side in the grave and contiguous to each other. 
(Prior code § 5-2-2)
11.12.110 - Burial in endowed lots only-Exception. 
    As a general policy the city will grant burial rights only in endowed lots; provided, that the board of commissioners may otherwise authorize the sale of lots or grave space to the county of Quay for interment of those buried or to be buried, at the expense of the county. 
(Prior code § 5-2-3)
11.12.120 - Grave opening permit-Application. 
    Before any grave shall be opened or dug, an application therefore shall be made to the cemetery superintendent for a grave opening permit. The application shall be made not less than sixteen (16) working hours before the time of interment. 
A.	The application for permit may be made by:
1.	The owner of the lot or his or her duly authorized agent or representative;
2.	The funeral director or person in charge of the interment; or
3.	Some other authorized person.
    The application shall contain a stipulation that the permit holder agrees to indemnify the city for any expense incurred by it if the burial proves to be unauthorized or on the wrong grave space or the wrong lot. 
B.	The application must give the following information:
1.	Name of lot owner or owners;
2.	Legal description of the lot and grave space in which burial is to be made;
3.	Name of person to be buried;
4.	Hour of burial;
5.	Name of funeral director (if such);
6.	Size and kind of box or vault;
7.	Signature of applicant for permit.
C.	The cemetery superintendent shall, upon the approval of an application and upon receipt of all fees and charges fixed for such permits and the opening of a grave (as may be established) and upon the payment of the full purchase price of a lot or grave space (if established) and upon the payment of the full purchase price of a lot or grave space (if the same belongs to the city) at the time of the application, issue a permit giving the above information and permission to dig or open a grave on the lot or gave space described. 
D.	No grave shall be opened in any lot or space until the sexton shall have the permit herein required. Any person, including the sexton, shall be liable to the city for any charges or fees required for opening any grave or making any interment when any work or interment preparations shall be commenced without a permit or without the payment of the fees or charges required therefore. 
(Prior code § 5-2-4)
(Ord. No. 1090, § 5, 11-17-2011)
Article 3. - Tombstones, Decorations and Structures 
    Note: Tombstones, decorations and structures in violation of this article placed prior to adoption of this article on cemetery property will be allowed to stay provided they are appropriately recorded in the sextons office. (Ord. No. 1090, § 6, 11-17-2011) 

11.12.130 - Markers to be placed by permission. 
    It is unlawful for any person or persons to place any tombstones, markers, fixtures or decorations or to construct any structure within the cemetery or any cemetery property of the city under the management or control of the city unless such matters are done with the consent and permission of the sexton and the superintendent. 
(Prior code § 5-3-1)
(Ord. No. 1090, § 7, 11-17-2011)
11.12.140 - Uniform system intended. 
    It is the intention and desire of the commission to develop a uniform system of markers, tombstones and other improvements in the city cemetery; and all improvement in the cemetery or the placing of tombstones, markers, decorations or other work in the cemetery shall be done only under the supervision of the department in charge or its agent or employees and in compliance with regulations adopted or which may be adopted by the commission. 
(Prior code § 5-3-2)
(Ord. No. 1090, § 8, 11-17-2011)
11.12.150 - Curbs and fences prohibited. 
    No person, owning or purchasing lots or graves, or directly or indirectly interested in such lots or graves, shall construct, or cause to be constructed, any cement curbs or curbing or fences of any form whatsoever, by, around or about the lots or graves. 
(Prior code § 5-3-3)
Article 4. - Cemetery Rules and Regulations 

11.12.160 - Purpose. 
    These rules and regulations are designed for the protection of owners of interment rights as a group. They are intended, not as restraining, but rather as preventing the inconsiderate from taking unfair advantage of others. Their enforcement will help protect the cemetery and create and preserve its beauty. These rules and regulations apply to the Tucumcari Memorial Park and the Tucumcari Memorial Gardens, and all owners in interment rights, visitors and contractors performing work within the cemetery, shall be subject to the rules and regulations, amendments or alterations as shall be adopted from time to time. 
(Prior code § 5-4-1)
11.12.170 - Definitions. 
    As used in this article: 
    "Cemetery" means the Tucumcari Memorial Park and Tucumcari Memorial Gardens. 
    "Contractor" means any person engaged in placing, erecting or repairing any memorial, or performing any work in the cemetery grounds, other than an employee of the cemetery. Unless otherwise inconsistent with the purpose of this article, the above definitions shall apply. 
    "Interment" means cremation and inurn-ment, entombment or burial of the remains of a deceased person. 
    "Memorial" means any marker or structure upon or in any lot or niche, placed thereupon or therein or partially therein for the purpose of identification or in memory of the interred. 
    "Owner" means the owner of rights of interment. 
(Prior code § 5-4-2)
11.12.180 - Use of lots. 
    Each and every lot in the park shall be used solely for the purpose of the burial of members of the human race, and no lot shall be used for any other purpose. 
(Prior code § 5-4-3)
11.12.190 - Compliance with rules and regulations required. 
    The cemetery management reserves the right to compel all persons coming into the cemetery to obey all rules and regulations adopted. The rules and regulations may be changed without notice to any owner. 
(Prior code § 5-4-4)
11.12.200 - Loss and damage. 
    The cemetery management shall take reasonable precaution to protect owners, and the property rights of owners, within the cemetery, from loss or damage; but it distinctly disclaims all responsibility for loss or damage from causes beyond its reasonable control, including without limitation because of enumeration, damage caused by the elements, an act of God, common enemy, thieves, vandals, strikers, malicious mischief makers, explosions, unavoidable accidents, invasion, insurrections, riots, or order of any military or civil authority, whether the damage be direct or collateral, other than as herein provided. 
(Prior code § 5-4-5)
11.12.210 - Correction of errors. 
    The cemetery management reserves and shall have the right to correct any errors that may be made by it either in making interments, disinterments or removals, or in the inscription, transfer or conveyance and substituting and conveying in lieu thereof other interment rights of equal value and similar location as far as possible, or as may be selected by the cemetery management or, in the sole discretion of the cemetery management, by refunding the amount of money paid on account of the purchase. In the event such error shall involve the interment of the remains of any person in such property, the cemetery management reserves and shall have the right to remove and transfer such remains so interred to such other property of equal values and similar location as may be substituted and conveyed in lieu thereof. The cemetery management shall also have the right to correct any errors made by placing an improper description, including an incorrect name or date either on the memorial or on the container for cremated remains. 
(Ord. 973, 2002; prior code § 5-4-6)
11.12.220 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1090, § 9, adopted Nov. 17, 2011, deleted § 11.12.220, which pertained to avenues, walks and roads to be used and derived from prior code § 5-4-7; and Ord. 973, adopted 2002. 
11.12.230 - Platting, boundaries, grading and drainage. 
    The right to enlarge, reduce, replat or change the boundaries or grading of the cemetery or of a section or sections, from time to time, including the right to modify or change the locations of, or any part of, or remove or regrade, roads, drives and walks is expressly reserved. The right to lay, maintain and operate, or alter or change pipe lines or gutters for sprinkling systems, drainage, lakes, or any other purpose is also expressly reserved, as well as is the right to use cemetery property not sold to individual owners for cemetery purposes, including the interring and preparing for interment of dead human bodies, or for anything necessary, incidental or convenient thereto. The cemetery reserves to itself, and to those lawfully entitled thereto, a perpetual right of ingress and egress over lots for the purpose of passage to and from other lots. 
(Ord. 973, 2002; prior code § 5-4-8)
11.12.240 - Sale and purchase of interment rights. 
    The sale or transfer by assignment of any interment right by any owner or purchaser, shall not be binding upon the cemetery unless same shall first be duly approved in writing by the properly authorized officer of the cemetery. The same rules shall apply in all cases of assignment of purchase contract for interment right. This procedure is required in order that the cemetery management may at all times have a complete and accurate record of all owners and purchasers. 
(Ord. 973, 2002; prior code § 5-4-9)
11.12.250 - Interment rights-Subject to rules-Charge. 
    The assignee of any purchase contract shall be subject to all rules and regulations which are now in full force and effect or which may be hereafter enacted. All transfers of ownership by assignments shall be subject to a charge of five dollars ($5.00), which charge must be paid when the transfer is recorded, and which charge will be placed in the perpetual care fund. 
(Ord. 973, 2002; prior code § 5-4-10)
11.12.260 - Interment rights-Subdivision of rights. 
    The subdivision of interment rights is not allowed without the consent of the cemetery, and no one shall be buried in any lot not having an interest therein, except by written consent of all parties interested in such lot and of the cemetery management. 
(Ord. 973, 2002; prior code § 5-4-11)
11.12.270 - Grading, improvements, openings and closings. 
    All grading, landscape work, and improvements of any kind, and all care of lots, shall be done, and all trees, shrubs, and herbage of any kind shall be planted, trimmed, cut or removed, and all openings and closings of lots, and all interments, disinterments and removals shall be made by the cemetery management. 
(Ord. 973, 2002; prior code § 5-4-12)
11.12.280 - Enclosures-Mounds. 
    No enclosure of any kind, such as fence, coping, hedge or ditch, shall hereafter be permitted around any grave or lot. Grave mounds will not be allowed, and no lot shall be raised above the established grade. 
(Ord. 973, 2002; prior code § 5-4-13)
11.12.290 - Interment rights-Purchase. 
    Interment rights can be purchased in the cemetery only by compliance with the rules and regulations of such cemetery now and hereafter adopted by the governing body of the city of Tucumcari, for the purpose of interment only. This provision applies to all sales, whether made directly by the cemetery authority, or assignment by owners. The cost of the interment rights shall be as follows: 
All lots for adult burials$350.00All lots for infant burials, in designated areas only$100.00All lots for cremains, in designated areas only$75.00Opening and closing of a cremain lot$100.00Opening and closing of regular graves$300.00Opening and closing of infant graves With full service$100.00 With no service$50.00Pauper section service$25.00Additional charge for services held on Saturdays, holidays and after four p.m. on weekdays $300.00 
(Ord. 1022 § 1, 2006: Ord. 984 § 1, 2003: Ord. 973, 2002; Ord. 893 § 2, 1994: Ord. 877 § 1, 1993: Ord. 792 § 1, 1988: Ord. 768 § 1, 1987: Ord. 679 § 1, 1980: prior code § 5-4-14) 
(Ord. No. 1090, § 10, 11-17-2011)
11.12.300 - Forms to be used for purchase-Terms. 
    All agreements for the purchase of cemetery interment rights must be on the form approved by the Tucumcari cemetery management and signed by the sexton of the cemetery. All terms and conditions for the purchase of interment rights must be recited in the purchase contract; verbal agreements or representation will not be recognized. 
(Ord. 973, 2002; prior code § 5-4-15)
11.12.310 - Exchange of interment rights. 
    The cemetery management may exchange interment rights when desired by owners, but not for interment rights of lesser values. When such an exchange is made, the original conveyance must be surrendered by the proper assignment before any change is effected. 
(Ord. 973, 2002; prior code § 5-4-16)
11.12.320 - Conveyance of interment rights. 
    Each owner is vested with the ownership of his or her interment right for the sole purpose of interment of human dead bodies. Under the regulations of the cemetery the interment rights cannot be conveyed without the assent of the management of the cemetery, nor any use, division or improvements of them be made which the management prohibits, or may deem improper. The owner of interment rights may dispose of same by will, subject to the foregoing conditions. If the owner dies intestate, the interment rights will descend to his or her heirs according to the laws of descent. 
(Prior code § 5-4-17)
11.12.330 - Conditional and partial transfers. 
    No conditional or partial transfer of interment rights and no assignment of an undivided interest, except to a person or persons who are already part-owners, will be recorded, as the cemetery management cannot be responsible for the carrying out of the intent of the grantor. No burial shall be made on any lot until the purchaser shall have paid the full purchase price applicable to the space to be used. 
(Prior code § 5-4-18)
11.12.340 - Care of cemetery-Special care. 
    The general care of the entire cemetery grounds and lots is assumed by the sexton. This, however, does not provide for any special care. Estimates for any special work will be made by the management upon application, and charges for the work must be paid in advance. 
(Prior code § 5-4-19)
(Ord. No. 1090, § 11, 11-17-2011)
11.12.350 - Improvements to be directed by management. 
    The sexton shall direct generally all improvements within the grounds and upon all lots and graves, before as well as after interments have been made therein. He or she shall have charge of the planting, sodding, surveying and improvements generally. 
(Prior code § 5-4-20)
11.12.360 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1090, § 9, adopted Nov. 17, 2011, deleted § 11.12.360, which pertained to permit for work required and derived from prior code § 5-4-21; and Ord. 973, adopted 2002. 
11.12.370 - Offensive memorials and inscriptions-Removal. 
    If any memorial, or any structure whatsoever, or any inscription to be placed on same, shall be determined by the management to be offensive, they shall have the right and it shall be their duty, to enter upon such a lot and remove, change or correct the offensive or improper object or objects. 
(Prior code § 5-4-22)
11.12.380 - Trees. 
    If any tree, shrub or plant standing upon any lot, by means of its roots, branches or otherwise, is or becomes detrimental to adjacent lots or avenues, or if for any other reason its removal is deemed necessary, the management shall have the right and it shall be their duty, to remove such tree, shrub or plant, or any part thereof, or otherwise correct the condition existing as in their judgment seems best. 
(Prior code § 5-4-23)
(Ord. No. 1090, § 12, 11-17-2011)
11.12.390 - Plucking plants and flowers. 
    No person shall pluck or remove any plant or flower, either wild or cultivated, from any part of the cemetery without the written consent of the cemetery management. 
(Prior code § 5-4-24)
11.12.400 - Memorials. 
    All memorials shall be set on uniform lines as prescribed by the cemetery, to conform to the general plan of the cemetery. 
(Prior code § 5-4-25)
(Ord. No. 1090, § 13, 11-17-2011)
11.12.410 - Markings. 
    The marking of each lot, grave or graves in Tucumcari Memorial Garden except as hereinafter provided, is restricted and limited to flat tablets set flush with the turf. 
(Prior code § 5-4-26)
11.12.420 - Markers and memorials-Installation. 
    All markers and memorials shall be installed by qualified personnel employed by the person or persons desiring to have said markers or memorials installed, and such person or persons shall have complete responsibility for the proper construction of the foundation and the proper installation of such marker or memorial and such construction and installation must be inspected and approved by the cemetery management for which inspection there is established a fee of three dollars ($3.00) for inspection of each single base or foundation and a fee of five dollars ($5.00) for inspection of each double base or foundation. 
(Ord. 637 § 1, 1976: prior code § 5-4-27)
11.12.430 - Funerals-Direction. 
    Funerals shall be subject to the direction of the cemetery superintendent. 
(Prior code § 5-4-29)
11.12.440 - Funerals-Time and notice. 
    A minimum of sixteen (16) working hours' notice will be required prior to the announced time of any funeral. No funerals will be allowed on Sundays or on any legal holiday. Exceptions to this rule may be made only when ordered by the cemetery superintendent. 
(Ord. 679 § 3, 1980: Ord. 637 § 3, 1976: prior code § 5-4-30)
(Ord. No. 1090, § 14, 11-17-2011)
11.12.450 - Interment order. 
    Graves will be opened by the management only when an interment order is signed by the family or its authorized representative, and is filed in the office of the cemetery manager. 
(Prior code § 5-4-31)
11.12.460 - Removals. 
    When a removal is to be made from a single grave to another grave, the formerly occupied grave space and all right therein revert to the cemetery. The cemetery removal service charge for the body shall be not less that four hundred dollars ($400.00) payable in advance. Application for the removal permit must be signed by next of kin properly notarized prior to time of removal. Such revenue shall be allocated in the same manner as opening and closing charges. 
(Prior code § 5-4-32)
(Ord. No. 1090, § 15, 11-17-2011)
11.12.470 - Number of interments in grave-Consent of owner. 
    Only one interment will be permitted in a grave, except in case of mother and infant or two small children in one casket. No interment will be permitted in a lot without the consent of the owner. 
(Prior code § 5-4-33)
11.12.480 - Interment receptacle. 
    Any dead human body to be interred or buried in the Tucumcari Memorial Cemetery shall be first enclosed within a rigid receptacle, which shall effectively prevent and impede the spreading of any bacteria, germs or disease from the human dead. The rigid receptacle shall, in addition, be such as to allow the orderly and safe disposal of human body. 
(Ord. 735 § 1, 1984)
11.12.490 - Burial service. 
    The burial services in the park shall be uniform, quiet and dignified. In every instance possible, chairs may be provided for the family and the entire service may be under shelter. The walls of the grave shall be hidden by rich, heavy draperies and a lowering device shall be used. Covers shall be laid on the lot around the grave. Every grave shall be thoroughly tamped to prevent settlement. Every precaution shall be taken as to not disturb surrounding graves. 
    Visitors to the park, who are not members of a funeral procession, shall not intrude upon a funeral or loiter about an open grave. Vehicles shall not pass a funeral procession; nor shall a funeral be closely followed or joined by persons who are strangers. 
(Prior code § 5-4-34)
(Ord. No. 1090, § 16, 11-17-2011)
11.12.500 - Animals prohibited. 
    No animals shall be permitted in the cemetery. 
(Prior code § 5-4-35)
(Ord. No. 1090, § 17, 11-17-2011)
11.12.510 - Bicycles. 
    Bicycles shall be kept on roadways. 
(Prior code § 5-4-36)
(Ord. No. 1090, § 18, 11-17-2011)
11.12.520 - Beer and liquor restrictions. 
    Bringing beer or intoxicating liquors within the cemetery is strictly forbidden. 
(Prior code § 5-4-37)
(Ord. No. 1090, § 19, 11-17-2011)
11.12.530 - Objects allowed on graves. 
    Allowable objects must not interfere with maintenance of graves and can only be placed in above ground receptacles on the headstone itself or on the north or south sides of the headstone. 
(Prior code § 5-4-38)
(Ord. No. 1090, § 20, 11-17-2011)
11.12.540 - Theft and damage-Cemetery not responsible. 
    The cemetery is not responsible for theft or damage to anything placed on grave lots. 
(Prior code § 5-4-39)
11.12.550 - Objectionable objects-Removal. 
    The Tucumcari cemetery management and their agents have authority to enter upon any lot and to remove any objectionable thing or any erection that may have been placed there contrary to the regulations of the cemetery, and they may remove any dead or damaged tree, shrub or vine. 
(Prior code § 5-4-41)
11.12.560 - Entrance and exit to cemetery. 
    No person shall be permitted to enter or leave the cemetery, except by the public gates. 
(Prior code § 5-4-42)
11.12.570 - Speed limit. 
    Speed over fifteen (15) miles per hour will not be permitted, and no person shall either ride or drive upon the lawns. 
(Prior code § 5-4-43)
11.12.580 - Holders of flowers. 
    Holders containing flowers or other decorations will be removed as soon as the flowers fade and wither, and the right is reserved by the cemetery management to make such removal. 
(Prior code § 5-4-44)
(Ord. No. 1090, § 21, 11-17-2011)
11.12.590 - Profane or boisterous language. 
    No person will be permitted to use profane or boisterous language or in any way disturb the quiet and good order of the cemetery. 
(Prior code § 5-4-45)
11.12.600 - Injuring trees and markers. 
    It is unlawful to break or injure any tree, shrub or other plant or mar any landmark marker or memorial or in any other way deface the grounds of the cemetery. 
(Prior code § 5-4-46)
11.12.610 - Attendants. 
    No money shall be paid the attendants at the entrance or on the grounds. The entire time of the persons regularly employed on the grounds belongs to the cemetery. Visitors and owners must not otherwise engage them. All orders, inquiries and complaints must be left at the office. 
(Prior code § 5-4-47)
11.12.620 - Enforcement. 
    All persons are reminded that the grounds are sacredly devoted to the burial of the dead and that the provisions and penalties of the law will be strictly enforced in all cases of wanton injury, disturbance and disregard to the rules. 
(Prior code § 5-4-48)
11.12.630 - Firearms. 
    No person or persons shall be permitted to bring or carry firearms within the cemetery except as a military guard of honor or law enforcement. 
(Prior code § 5-4-49)
(Ord. No. 1090, § 22, 11-17-2011)
11.12.640 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1090, § 9, adopted Nov. 17, 2011, deleted § 11.12.640, which pertained to permit for work on graves required-exception and derived from prior code § 5-4-50; and Ord. 973, adopted 2002. 
11.12.650 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1090, § 9, adopted Nov. 17, 2011, deleted § 11.12.650, which pertained to potted plants and wreaths and derived from prior code § 5-4-51; and Ord. 973, adopted 2002. 
11.12.660 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1090, § 9, adopted Nov. 17, 2011, deleted § 11.12.660, which pertained to cemetery may remove flowers and derived from prior code § 5-4-52; and Ord. 973, adopted 2002. 
11.12.670 - Application of penal provisions. 
    All provisions of this code and such ordinances of the city now in force, or hereafter enacted, relating to public offenses in the limits of the city shall, insofar as the same are applicable, be in full force and effect in the cemetery of the city known as Memorial Park Cemetery. 
(Prior code § 5-4-53)
11.12.680 - Cemetery hours. 
    It is unlawful for any person to enter into or upon the grounds of Memorial Park Cemetery after dark or until daylight. It is further unlawful for any person to be in or upon the cemetery grounds when the gates or entrances thereto provided for ingress or egress are barricaded, closed or locked, without first obtaining the permission of the sexton or other person in charge of the cemetery. 
(Prior code § 5-4-54)
(Ord. No. 1090, § 23, 11-17-2011)
11.12.690 - Driving and parking-Sexton to direct traffic. 
    It is unlawful to drive or move any vehicle within the cemetery except over a roadway open for vehicular traffic or to obstruct any path or driveway within the cemetery open to vehicular traffic. No person shall use the cemetery grounds or any driveway therein as a public thoroughfare nor drive any vehicle through the grounds except for the purpose of making delivers in connection with cemetery work or other lawful purposes. It shall be the duty of the cemetery sexton and his or her assistants when necessary to direct all vehicular traffic and the sexton is authorized to direct the parking or standing of all vehicles in the cemetery. It is unlawful for any person to disobey or disregard the directions of the sexton relating to the movement or standing of all vehicles within the cemetery. 
(Prior code § 5-4-55)
(Ord. No. 1090, § 24, 11-17-2011)
11.12.700 - Rubbish and debris. 
    It is unlawful for any person to dispose of any rubbish, trash or waste materials or debris of any kind in the cemetery; provided, that it shall be permissible to accumulate any refuse resulting from the doing of any authorized work in the cemetery but the same together with all derricks, tools and materials shall be removed immediately upon completion of such work and the grounds shall be left in as good condition as found. 
(Prior code § 5-4-56)
11.12.710 - Monuments and plantings. 
    It is unlawful for any person to erect monumental work, burial structures or buildings without permission from the sexton, or to erect any fence, coping, curbing or enclosure of any kind, or to plant or remove any tree, shrub, flower or other decorative plant in said cemetery contrary to the rules and regulations therefore established by this chapter. 
(Prior code § 5-4-57)
(Ord. No. 1090, § 25, 11-17-2011)
11.12.720 - Property damage. 
    Subject to any additional rules and regulations therefore established, it is unlawful for any person to remove, molest, injure, mar, deface, throw down or destroy any headstone, monuments, markers, tombs, vaults or mausoleum or decoration on any cemetery, or to open, disturb or molest any grave or place of burial therein. 
(Prior code § 5-4-58)
(Ord. No. 1090, § 26, 11-17-2011)
11.12.730 - Trespassing and loitering. 
    It is unlawful for any person to loiter in or trespass upon cemetery lots and graves, within the cemetery or for the parent or guardian of any child to permit such child to be within the cemetery grounds unless accompanied by an adult person; provided, that nothing herein shall be construed to prohibit any person having lawful business in the cemetery in connection with improvement thereof or persons visiting the graves of relatives or friends from being in the cemetery in accordance with rules. 
(Prior code § 5-4-59)
11.12.740 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1090, § 9, adopted Nov. 17, 2011, deleted § 11.12.740, which pertained to animals and derived from prior code § 5-4-60. 
11.12.750 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation who violates any provision of this chapter of the code, shall be guilty of an offense, and upon conviction shall be punished by a fine of not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) dollars or by imprisonment in jail for not more than ninety (90) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment, at the discretion of the court. 
(Ord. 932 § 1(part), 1999; prior code § 5-5-1)
(Ord. No. 1090, § 27, 11-17-2011)
Chapter 11.16 - USE OF PUBLIC LAND 
Sections: 

11.16.010 - Park property. 
    No person in a park shall: 
A.	Wilfully mark, deface, disfigure, injure, tamper with, or displace or remove, any building, bridges, tables, benches, fireplace, railings, paving or paving material, water lines or other public utilities or parts or appurtenances thereof, signs, notices or placards whether temporary or permanent, monuments, stakes, posts or other boundary markers, or other structures or equipment, facilities or park property or appurtenances whatsoever, either real or personal; 
B.	Fail to cooperate in maintaining restrooms and washrooms in a neat and sanitary condition;
C.	Dig, or remove any soil, rock, stones, trees, shrubs or plants, down-timber or other wood or materials, or make any excavation by tool, equipment, blasting or other means or agency. 
(Prior code § 14-4-1)
11.16.020 - Trees, shrubbery and lawns. 
    No person in a park shall: 
A.	Damage, cut, carve, transplant or remove any tree or plant or injure the bark, or pick the flowers or seeds, of any tree or plant. Nor shall any person attach any rope, wire or other contrivance to any tree or plant. A person shall not dig in or otherwise disturb grass areas, or in any other way injure or impair the natural beauty or usefulness of any area; 
B.	Climb any tree or walk, stand or sit upon monuments, vases, fountains, railings, fences or upon any other property not designated or customarily used for such purposes. 
(Prior code § 14-4-2)
11.16.030 - Sanitation. 
    No person in a park shall have brought in or shall dump, deposit or leave any bottles, broken glass, ashes, papers, boxes, cans, dirt, rubbish, waste, garbage or refuse or other trash. No such refuse or trash shall be placed in any waters in or contiguous to any park, or left anywhere on the grounds thereof, but shall be placed in the proper receptacles where these are provided; where receptacles are not so provided, all such rubbish or waste shall be carried away from the park by the person responsible for its presence, and properly disposed of elsewhere. 
(Prior code § 14-4-3)
11.16.040 - Picnic areas and use. 
    No person in a park shall: 
A.	Picnic or lunch in a place other than those designated for that purpose. Attendants shall have the authority to regulate the activities in such areas when necessary to prevent congestion and to secure maximum use for the comfort and convenience of all. Visitors shall comply with any directions given to achieve this end and shall observe all other regulations posted in any public park in the city; 
B.	Leave a picnic area before the fire is completely extinguished and before all trash in the nature of boxes, papers, cans, bottles, garbage and other refuse is placed in the disposal receptacles where provided. If no such trash receptacles are available, then refuse and trash shall be carried away from the park area by the picnicker to be properly disposed of elsewhere. 
(Prior code § 14-4-4)
11.16.050 - Camping. 
    No person in a park shall: 
A.	Camp in any park overnight or remain in the public parks of the city from the hour of eleven p.m. until daylight. The parks are available for temporary rest areas only. No person shall set up any tents, shacks or any other temporary shelter in any public park in the city; 
B.	Take part in or abet the playing of games or engaging in any other activity which could endanger any other visitors in the public parks of Tucumcari. The playing of rough or comparatively dangerous games such as football or baseball is prohibited except on the fields and courts or areas provided therefore. 
(Prior code § 14-4-5)
11.16.060 - Behavior. 
    No person in a park shall: 
A.	Have brought alcoholic beverages, nor shall any person drink alcoholic beverages at any time in any park in the city, except at special public functions where there may be special concession privileges granted in compliance with regulations of the Department of Alcoholic Beverage Control of the state of New Mexico; 
B.	Appear at any place in other than proper clothing. With the exception of regular bathing areas, "properly clothed" shall be construed to prohibit the wearing of trunks or clothing that does not fully cover the body; 
C.	Sleep or protractedly lounge on the seats, or benches, or other areas, or engage in loud, boisterous, threatening, abusive, insulting or indecent language, or engage in any disorderly conduct or behavior tending to a breach of the public peace. 
(Prior code § 14-4-6)
11.16.070 - Enforcement. 
A.	The chief of police and other members of the police force and all park attendants shall, in connection with their duties, imposed by law, diligently enforce the provisions of this chapter. 
B.	Any park attendant or other employee of the city shall have authority to eject from the park any person acting in violation of this chapter or any other provision of this code. 
(Prior code § 14-4-7)
11.16.080 - Permits for use. 
    Permits are required for park use under the following conditions: 
A.	Permits. A permit shall be obtained from the city before participating in or conducting any of the following activities in a park: 
1.	Large group usage of any park. As used herein, the term "large group" refers to a group of fifty (50) or more persons assembling at the same general location to pursue an activity in common. Unless there is clear evidence to the contrary, an event advertised or announced in the news media or otherwise communicated as being open to the general public shall be considered a large group under this code which shall require a permit to be obtained for park use, from the commission; 
2.	An activity inconsistent with the recreational nature of city parks; including without limitation a demonstration, parade, public show, or attraction; 
3.	Erection of structures. No person in a park shall construct or erect any building or structure of whatever kind, whether permanent or temporary in character, or run or string any wire or pipe into, upon, or across such lands, except on special written permit issued hereunder. 
B.	Application for Permit. A person seeking issuance of a permit under this chapter shall file an application with the city at the office of the city manager. The application shall state: 
1.	The name and address of the applicant;
2.	The name and address of the person sponsoring the activity, if any;
3.	The day and hours for which the permit is desired;
4.	The park or portion thereof for which such permit is desired;
5.	An estimate of the anticipated attendance;
6.	Any other information which the city shall find reasonably necessary to a fair determination as to whether a permit should be issued hereunder. 
C.	Standard for Issuance of a Permit. The city shall issue a permit under this chapter unless it is found: 
1.	That the proposed activity or use of the park will unreasonably interfere with or detract from the general public's enjoyment of the park; 
2.	That the proposed activity and use will unreasonably interfere with or detract from the promotion of public health, welfare, safety and recreation; 
3.	That the proposed activity or use is reasonably anticipated to incite violence, crime or disorderly conduct; 
4.	That the proposed activity will entail unusual, extraordinary or burdensome expense or police operation by the city; 
5.	That the facilities desired have been reserved for other use at the day and hour required in the application; 
6.	That, in the case of a large group, the event or gathering is not officially sponsored by a recognized local organization or persons who are permanent residents of the city; or in lieu of such sponsorship, that a bond in a reasonable amount, to be determined by the city has not been posted to indemnify against any potential loss of, or damage to, city property. 
D.	Appeal. Within ten (10) days after receipt of an application the city shall apprise an applicant in writing of the reasons for refusing a permit, and any aggrieved person shall have the right to appeal in writing within ten (10) days to the commission which shall consider the application under the standards set forth in subsection C of this section and sustain or overrule the city's decision within fifteen (15) days. The decision of the commission shall be final. 
E.	Effect of Permit. A permittee shall be bound by all park rules and regulations and all applicable ordinances as fully and as though the same were inserted in the permit. The above statement shall appear on the application and on the permit. 
F.	Liability of Permittee. The person to whom a permit is issued, and the person or organization sponsoring the permit application, shall be liable for any loss, damage or injury sustained by any person whatever or any park property, by reason of the negligence of the person or persons to whom such permit shall have been issued and shall hold the city harmless therefrom. 
G.	Revocation. The city shall have the authority to revoke a permit upon a finding of violating by the permittee or other persons using the park under a permit of any rule or ordinance, or upon good cause shown. 
(Prior code § 14-4-8)
Chapter 11.20 - TREES 
Sections: 

11.20.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
    Administration. The beautification coordinator is the representative of the tree board who is responsible for administration of the community tree program. 
    "Nuisance/hazard/diseased trees" are defined as dead, defaced, broken, dangerous, diseased trees with severe structural damage, or trees interfering with views of traffic or pedestrians. 
    "Property owner" means the person owning such property as shown on the records of the Quay County tax assessor's office. 
    "Public places" includes all streets, highways, parks and grounds owned by the city. 
    "Public trees" are defined as trees, shrubs, bushes and all other woody vegetation on land lying between the property lines on either side of all streets, avenues and boulevards within the city. 
    "Right-of-way" means land owned by the public for travel access or utility use. 
    "Street" or "highway" means the entire width of every public way, to include all rights-of-way. 
    "Topping" or "rounding" is defined as the systematic cutting back of limbs within the tree's crown to such a degree as to remove the normal canopy and disfigure the tree. 
    "Tree" is any plant, shrub or tree over thirty-six (36) inches in height measured from the ground level. 
    "Tree board" means a group of people charged, generally by ordinance, with overseeing the needs of the urban forest. 
    "Urban forest" means trees and related organisms in urban settings, whether small towns, villages, communities or large cities. 
(Ord. 973, 2002; Ord. 931 § 1, 1998)
11.20.020 - Tree board-Established. 
A.	There shall be created and established a tree board of up to ten (10) citizens of the municipality of Tucumcari, a majority of whom shall be residents of the municipality of Tucumcari or of Quay County. Five of the members shall be appointed by the mayor with the approval of the council. The other five will be recommended by the tree board and approved by the city commission. One member who shall be an ex-officio member is the beautification coordinator. 
    All members of the board shall serve without pay. The five members appointed by the mayor, shall be appointed as follows: three for three years; and two for two years and shall serve until their successors are duly appointed and approved by the council. Successors to those members appointed by the mayor shall, thereafter be appointed for terms of three years. Vacancies caused by death, resignation or otherwise, shall be filled for the unexpired term in the same manner as original appointments are made. 
B.	Duties. The tree board shall perform the following duties:
1.	Within a reasonable time after the appointment of the tree board upon call of chairperson of the tree board, the tree board shall meet and adopt rules and procedure for regular and special meetings to fulfill the duties imposed upon it by this chapter. 
2.	The tree board shall advise and consult with the beautification coordinator on any matter pertaining to the tree ordinance. The topics under which this advice and consultation may be given may include but are not limited to, the following: 
a.	Amendments to this chapter, or revisions to any plans and/or specifications;
b.	Policy concerning selection, planting, maintenance, and removal of trees, shrubs and other plants within the city on city property; 
c.	Allocation of and expenditures of funds by the parks department as related to trees;
d.	Establishment of educational and informational programs.
3.	The tree board and the city manager, upon the request of any person who disagrees with the decision of the beautification coordinator shall hear all issues of the disputes which arise between the beautification coordinator and any such person whenever those issues involve the matters of the interpretation or enforcement of any urban forest plan, or of the interpretation or enforcement of this chapter. The decision of a majority of the appointed members of the tree board with regard to such dispute shall be referred to the city manager. Any disputes that have not been resolved through the city manager may be referred to the city commission for resolution.
