Nothing in this section shall be construed to limit the jurisdiction of any court of law with respect to such disputes. 
(Ord. 931 § 2, 1998)
11.20.030 - Distances and clearances. 
    It shall be the duty of any person or persons owning or occupying real property bordering on any street upon which property there may be trees, to prune such trees in such manner that they will not obstruct or shade the street lights, obstruct the passage of pedestrians on sidewalks, obstruct vision of traffic signs, or obstruct view of any street or alley intersections. 
    The minimum clearance of any overhanging portion thereof shall be ten (10) feet over sidewalks, twelve (12) feet over all streets, and truck thoroughfares shall have a clearance of sixteen (16) feet. 
A.	Notice to Prune. Should any property owner bordering on any street fail to prune trees as herein above provided, the beautification coordinator shall order such person or persons, within ten (10) days after receipt of written notice, to so prune such trees. 
B.	Order Required. The order required herein shall be served by mailing a copy of the order to the last known address of the property owner, by certified mail. 
C.	Failure to Comply. When a person to whom an order is directed shall fail to comply within the specified time, it shall be lawful for the municipality to prune, or have pruned such trees. 
(Ord. 931 § 3, 1998)
11.20.040 - Public tree maintenance. 
    The beautification coordinator or their designee, shall have the authority to promulgate the rules and regulations governing the planting, maintenance, removal, fertilization and pruning of trees on the street or other public sites in the municipality and shall direct, regulate and control the planting, maintenance and removal of all trees growing now or hereafter in public areas in Tucumcari. The beautification coordinator shall cause the provisions of this chapter to be enforced. 
(Ord. 931 § 4, 1998)
11.20.050 - Tree topping. 
    It is unlawful as a normal practice for any person, firm or city department to top any tree on public property. Trees severely damaged by storms or other causes, or certain trees under utility wires or other obstructions where other pruning practices are impractical may be exempted from this section at the determination of the beautification coordinator. 
(Ord. 931 § 5, 1998)
11.20.060 - Abuse or mutilation of public trees. 
    Unless specifically authorized by the beautification coordinator or his or her designee, no person shall intentionally damage, cut or carve any public tree; allow any liquid or solid substance, which is harmful to such tree to come in contact with them. 
(Ord. 931 § 6, 1998)
11.20.070 - Protection of trees. 
    All trees on any street or publicly owned property near any excavation or construction of any building, structure, or street work, shall be guarded with a substantial fence, frame or box not less than four feet from the outer perimeter of the trunk. 
    No person shall deposit, place, store or maintain upon any public place of the city any stone, brick, sand, concrete or other material which may impede the free passage of water, air or fertilizer to the roots of any tree growing therein except by written permit of the city-designated beautification coordinator. 
(Ord. 931 § 7, 1998)
11.20.080 - Property owners to consult with coordinator when. 
    Property owners shall consult with the beautification coordinator on any of the following acts: 
A.	Cultivate, treat, prune, remove, or otherwise disturb any tree on public places;
B.	Trim, prune or remove any tree or portions thereof if such tree or portions thereof reasonably may be expected to fall on any public place; 
C.	Place on public place, either above or below ground level, a container or tree, or other plants; 
D.	Damage, cut, tap, carve or transplant any tree, shrub, or other plant located on any public place; 
E.	Attach any wire, nail, sign, poster, or any other manmade object to any tree, or other plant located on any public place; 
F.	Dig a tunnel or trench on any public place.
(Ord. 931 § 8, 1998)
11.20.090 - Interference with tree board. 
    It is unlawful for any person to prevent, delay or interfere with the beautification coordinator or his or her designee, the tree board, or any of its representatives or agents while engaging in the planting, cultivating, mulching, pruning, spraying and removing of any tree within the community forest. 
(Ord. 931 § 8, 1998)
11.20.100 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person violating or failing to comply with any of the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined a sum of no less than one dollar ($1.00) and no more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(Ord. 931 § 9, 1998)
Chapter 11.24 - MUNICIPAL AIRPORT 
Sections: 

11.24.010 - General regulations. 
    The following rules and regulations shall govern the conduct and operation of the Tucumcari Municipal Airport and shall be observed by all persons using, visiting or operating at the Tucumcari Municipal Airport: 
A.	No person shall use the Tucumcari Municipal Airport for the purpose of carrying on of any commercial activity, for the conduct of any phase of commercial aviation activity, for the sale of fuels, refreshments or for any other commercial purposes unless approved by the city commission or its agent. 
B.	The management and control of the Tucumcari Municipal Airport shall at all times be directly under the control of the city manager who shall appoint an airport manager, assistants and employees as may be required for the proper management of the airport. 
C.	The Federal Aviation Regulations promulgated by the Federal Aviation Administration presently or hereafter in effect are referred to, adopted and made a part hereof as though fully set forth and incorporated herein. 
D.	Any person, corporation or individual causing damage of any kind to the Tucumcari Municipal Airport whether through violation of any of these rules or regulations or through any act of omission or commission shall be liable therefore to the city and/or its agent. 
E.	Any person using the Tucumcari Municipal Airport shall hold the city and its agents free from any claim for damage caused by the acts of the user to the person or property of any third person. 
F.	The use of the airport or any of its facilities in any manner shall create an obligation on the part of the user thereof to obey all the regulations herein provided. 
(Ord. 632 § 1, 1976)
11.24.020 - Ground ramp and taxi rules. 
A.	Ramp and tie-down area shall be available to all users without any one user having an exclusive right to ramp space or tie-down position, except that the tie-down area immediately adjacent to the terminal ramp gate and fence area shall be kept clear for the loading and unloading of airline passengers and freight. 
B.	It shall be the responsibility of the pilot and/or owner to ascertain that his or her aircraft is properly parked, tied down and secured. 
C.	No engine run-up or checking will be permitted in the terminal or light aircraft parking areas. All engine run-ups shall be conducted on the asphalt surface of the taxiway. 
D.	No airline company is assigned exclusive use of any gate or parking position in the terminal ramp area. 
(Ord. 632 § 2, 1976)
11.24.030 - Traffic rules. 
    The traffic direction shall be as indicated by the Wind Tee. Runway 21 shall be designated as the Calm Wind Runway. All aircraft whose radio equipment allows, shall maintain communications with Tucumcari Flight Service Station for the purpose of exchanging traffic information and runway data. 
(Ord. 632 § 3, 1976)
11.24.040 - Hangars. 
    The city may build and maintain hangars for the use of the public generally upon the airport and the city manager may, with the approval of the city commission, establish a system of uniform charges for the use of the hangars. Any private party desiring to construct a hangar upon the airport shall make application for a permit therefor to the airport superintendent and upon the approval of the city commission which, if it deems it advisable, shall grant such permit, and the airport superintendent shall designate the exact place where such private hangar and hangars may be built and also the general plan of construction and material. Private parties having hangars upon any airport shall pay such rental for the space occupied which shall be determined at the time the permit therefor is granted; provided, that any lease agreement affecting the new airport shall be approved by the Federal Aviation Agency. Any private party having a hangar upon the airport may at any time remove the same; provided, that all ground rent and other charges are paid up in full and that such removal shall result in no damage to any airport or property thereon. All hangars hereafter built upon the airport shall be as nearly of uniform, fireproof construction as possible. 
(Ord. 943 § 17 (part), 1999; Ord. 632 § 4, 1976)
11.24.050 - Denial of use of airport. 
    The city commission may at any time deny the use of the airport or any part thereof to any person guilty of any violation of the laws of the United States, the state of New Mexico or the rules and regulations of the Department of Commerce pertaining to aviation, or who shall be guilty of any dangerous or improper conduct or practice thereon, and it is unlawful for any portion thereof, after the use thereof has been denied to them or their employer. 
(Ord. 943 § 17 (part), 1999; Ord. 632 § 5, 1976)
11.24.060 - Unauthorized structures. 
    It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to build, construct, move upon or maintain any hangar, building or other structure of any kind or nature whatsoever, upon the airport, without having first obtained a permit therefor from the board of commissioners. 
(Ord. 632 § 6, 1976)
11.24.070 - Removal of structures. 
    The city commission may at any time after the expiration of the term of any permit, contract or license therefor, order the immediate removal of any building or structure from said airports, and upon such order being made, a copy thereof shall be served upon the owner of the same. 
(Ord. 943 § 17 (part), 1999; Ord. 632 § 7, 1976)
11.24.080 - Aerial dusting or aerial chemical spraying. 
    Aircraft owners, be they private, corporation or trustees, will for the operation of their aircraft off the Tucumcari Municipal Airport landing field for aerial dusting or aerial chemical spraying as hereinabove defined shall pay every year, to the airport manager at the Tucumcari Municipal Airport a sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for use of one duster type aircraft per year. In the event, that more than one aircraft is used for dusting or spraying purposes during the year, the duster or sprayer will pay an additional fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) for the second, and all additional aircraft used in dusting or spraying activities per year. All commercial operators or users will comply with the rules and regulations promulgated by the Tucumcari city commission and will comply with the directions and wishes of the airport manager in all cases involving any aspects of the operation of aircraft on or above the airport. 
(Ord. 943 § 18 (part), 1999; Ord. 632 § 8, 1976)
11.24.090 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person convicted of violating the provisions of this chapter may be punished by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or by imprisonment for not more than ninety (90) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. 932 § 1(part), 1999; Ord. 632 § 9, 1976)
Chapter 11.28 - MUNICIPAL AIRPORT ADVISORY BOARD 
Sections: 

11.28.010 - Municipal airport advisory board, appointment and terms. 
    For the purpose of conserving the property and promoting the Tucumcari Municipal Airport, it is declared necessary that a municipal airport advisory board be created to advise and make recommendations in the operations of the Tucumcari Municipal Airport. The mayor of the city of Tucumcari, New Mexico, with the advice and consent of the city commission shall appoint the municipal airport advisory board. The board shall consist of five members, who shall reside in or within a three-mile radius of the city limits of the city of Tucumcari. Advisory board members shall be appointed for terms of one and two years respectively. When the terms of the original members expire, the mayor with the advice and consent of the city commission shall appoint a successor for each for a term of two years. 
(Ord. 1001 §§ 1, 2 (part), 2005)
11.28.020 - Municipal airport advisory board duties. 
    The municipal airport advisory board shall act in an advisory capacity and shall advise the city commission in every possible way to insure the efficient operation of the Tucumcari Municipal Airport. 
(Ord. 1001 §§ 1, 2 (part), 2005)
11.28.030 - Board meetings. 
    The municipal airport advisory board shall meet on a quarterly basis at a time and place to be selected by the advisory board. Special meetings of the airport advisory board may be called by the chairperson or a quorum of the board. All meetings shall be announced pursuant to the State of New Mexico Open Meetings Act. 
(Ord. 1001 §§ 1, 2 (part), 2005)
11.28.040 - Organization, quorum, records of proceedings. 
    The airport advisory board shall elect from among its members a chairperson, vice chairperson and secretary. The terms of the chairperson, vice chairperson and secretary shall be for a term of one year. The secretary shall keep minutes of the meetings of the board. The board, or its secretary, shall report by way of its minutes, all business matters with reference to the operation of the Tucumcari Municipal Airport to the city commission. A quorum of the board shall consist of three members. 
(Ord. 1001 §§ 1, 2 (part), 2005)
Chapter 11.30 - MUNICIPAL GOLF COURSE ADVISORY BOARD 
Sections: 

11.30.010 - Municipal golf course advisory board, appointment and terms. 
    For the purpose of conserving the property and promoting the Tucumcari municipal golf course, it is declared necessary that a municipal golf course advisory board be created to advise and make recommendations in the maintenance of the Tucumcari municipal golf course. All golf course advisory board members shall be appointed by the city commission, the governing body of the city of Tucumcari, New Mexico. The board shall consist of five members, who shall represent the following areas: 
A.	Golf course professional;
B.	Head of the City Water Department;
C.	Quay County agent or head of the New Mexico State University Tucumcari Agriculture Science Center; 
D.	Two golf members of the Mesa Country Club recommended by the club board of directors.
    The members from the country club shall be appointed for terms of one and two years respectively. When the terms of the original members expire, the city commission shall appoint a successor for a term of two years based on recommendation from the Mesa Country Club board of directors. 
(Ord. 1056 § 2 (part), 2007)
11.30.020 - Municipal golf course advisory board duties. 
    The municipal golf course advisory board shall act in an advisory capacity and shall advise the city commission in every possible way to insure the attraction of golfers to the course and maintenance of the grounds of the Tucumcari municipal golf course. 
(Ord. 1056 § 2 (part), 2007)
11.30.030 - Board meetings. 
    The municipal golf course advisory board shall meet on a monthly basis at a time and place to be selected by the advisory board. Special meetings of the golf course advisory board may be called by the chairman or a quorum of the board. All meetings shall be announced pursuant to the state of New Mexico Open Meetings Act. 
(Ord. 1056 § 2 (part), 2007)
11.30.040 - Organization, quorum, records of proceedings. 
    The golf course advisory board shall elect from among its members a chairman, vice-chairman and secretary. The terms of the chairman, vice chairman and secretary shall be for a term of one year. The secretary shall keep minutes of the meetings of the board. The board, or its secretary, shall report by way of its minutes, all business matters with reference to the operation of the Tucumcari golf course to the city commission. A quorum of the board shall consist of three members. 
(Ord. 1056 § 2 (part), 2007)
Title 13 - PUBLIC SERVICES 
Chapters: 
Chapter 13.04 - WATER AND SEWERS 
Sections: 

13.04.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
    "City" is the city of Tucumcari, New Mexico. 
    "Consumer" is the party using the service. 
    "Customer" is the party in whose or which name the account is carried. 
    "Department" is the water and sewer department. 
    "Manager" is the city manager or his or her duly authorized representative. 
    "Owner" means the legal or equitable owner of the real property receiving service. 
    "Service" means the sale or supply of water and sewer service by the city to customers or consumers. 
    "Service unit" means a unit in each service location that is under separate ownership, occupancy or lease including each owner, tenant or occupant utilizing a portion of a single building or location. 
    Words in the masculine or feminine form shall be deemed to include or relate to males and females and when appropriate to corporations; and words in the singular or plural number shall be deemed to include both the singular and the plural. 
(Ord. 774 § 1, 1987)
13.04.020 - Water and sewer department. 
    There is created for the operation of the water, sewer service of the city, a water and sewer department (herein "department"). The department shall be administered by the city manager, who shall appoint such officers and employees thereto as may be necessary for the proper operation of the department. All present employees of the water service system and all present employees of the sewer service system are transferred to and shall become the employees of the water and sewer department of the city. 
    The department is authorized to promulgate rules and regulations not in conflict with this chapter and the laws of the state of New Mexico. 
(Ord. 774 § 2, 1987)
13.04.030 - Water service installations-Application. 
A.	Before the department shall make any new installation to serve any premises with water, an application for connection shall be made in writing by the customer of the premises to be connected or by his or her authorized representative at the office of the city manager (herein "manager"). The application shall he made on forms provided by the department. The application shall state: 
1.	The name of the applicant customer and the property to be served with address and telephone number; 
2.	The name of owner if different from the application customer, with address and telephone number; 
3.	The location of the property to be served described by its street address, legal description or otherwise; 
4.	The type of service desired and the use for which service will be required.
    Note: If there is no water main to which a connection can be made, the requirements of Section 13.04.060 or 13.04.070 must be met before the application for the service will be accepted. 
B.	The application shall become binding and effective when accepted and approved on behalf of the city by the manager and upon the deposit of such amounts as security for the payment of bills for services rendered, as provided herein, has been made by the customer. The application and its acceptance: (1) shall constitute a contract between the applicant and the city for installation of the connection and provision of the service; and (2) shall constitute an agreement on the part of the applicant to abide by and be bound by all rules and regulations of the department now in force or hereafter relating to the supply and uses of service; and (3) shall constitute further agreement on the part of the applicant to pay the rate now or hereafter fixed by the city for such service until the same is disconnected or discontinued. 
C.	The city may require a reasonable deposit for service.
(Ord. 774 § 3, 1987)
13.04.040 - Sewer system-Application-Contract. 
A.	Before the city shall provide any new sewer service or make any new installation to any premises, an application for any such service or connection shall be made in writing by the customer of the premises to be served or by his or her authorized representative at the office of the manager. The application shall be made on forms provided by the department. The application shall state: 
1.	The name of the applicant customer and the property to be served with address and telephone number; 
2.	The name of owner if different from the applicant customer, with address and telephone number; 
3.	The location of the property to be served described by its street address, legal description or otherwise; 
4.	The type of service desired and the use for which service will be required.
    Note: If there is no sewer main to which a connection can be made, the requirements of Section 13.04.060 or 13.04.070 must be met before the application for the service connection will be accepted. 
B.	The application shall become binding and effective when accepted and approved on behalf of the city by the manager and upon the deposit of such amounts as security for the payment of bills for services rendered, as provided herein, has been made by the customer. The application and its acceptance: (1) shall constitute a contract between the applicant and the city for installation of the connection and provision of the service; and (2) shall constitute an agreement on the part of the applicant to abide by and be bound by all rules and regulations of the city now in force or hereafter relating to the supply and use of sewer service and refuse collection by such applicant; and (3) shall constitute further agreement on the part of the applicant to pay the rates now or hereafter fixed by the city for such service until the same is disconnected or discontinued. 
C.	The city may require a reasonable deposit for service.
(Ord. 774 § 4, 1987)
13.04.050 - Security deposits. 
A.	Cash deposits to secure payment of charges for service or charges due upon discontinuance of service shall be made by the applicant customer in such amounts as authorized. The department reserves the right to apply the deposit to payment of any or all charges for services provided upon failure by the customer to pay the charge when due or upon discontinuance of any or all classes of services. 
B.	For residential service, the deposit for each class of service shall be in an amount equal to utility service estimated to be used during a period of three months (see Section 13.04.200(A)(4)); provided, that no security deposit shall be less than fifty dollars ($50.00) for each residential service. 
C.	For commercial service, the deposit for each class of service shall be in an amount equal to three months usage at the maximum rate (see Section 13.04.200(A)(5)); provided, that no security deposit shall be less than one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
D.	In the event that no previous service has been rendered, the amount of the deposit may be an estimated based on three months estimated service. 
E.	In the event that a customer shall, for any reason, fail to pay any charge for service provided for and required by this chapter, it shall be the duty of the manager to apply the deposit to the payment of the charges due. Upon payment by the customer, any amounts remaining after payment of the delinquent charge shall be applied to the customer's security deposit. 
F.	The department may require additional cash deposits if the original deposit is insufficient.
(Ord. 774 § 5, 1987)
13.04.060 - Temporary service. 
A.	A consumer requesting water service where no permanent service is available, may receive such service upon the making of an application as provided in Section 13.04.070. When available, service shall be provided after payment of a deposit pursuant to Section 13.04.050 after the payment of charges pursuant to Section 13.04.100 for making the temporary connection. 
B.	When available, a meter shall be installed to measure such service, but the amount of any such charge for temporary service shall to be less than the minimum monthly bill for such service. 
(Ord. 774 § 6, 1987)
13.04.070 - Water and sanitary sewer service extension. 
A.	The applicant customer desiring extension of the city service, shall make application to the city engineering department in writing for the construction of all water and sewer service facilities. The engineering office shall provide an estimate of the work to be completed. 
B.	Upon application for service there shall be paid to the city the estimated cost for construction or the cost of an equivalent water or sewer line, such cost based on the current city-wide water and sewer extension program, whichever is greater. 
C.	Service lines abutting city property or benefiting city property shall obligate the city to pay a pro rata share of the cost. 
D.	Expansion costs shall be paid prior to commencement of construction.
E.	In special or unusual cases, upon written request by applicant, approval may be granted by the city manager to commence construction without payment of costs. Such approval must be evidenced in writing signed by the city manager. 
F.	Water lines extended beyond the corporate limits by rural water districts shall provide, in addition to other terms and conditions, a water meter for each customer/user (see Section 13.04.080) as part of the cost of construction. 
G.	Water and sewer service will, when practicable, be installed prior to paving. The city, at its option, may finance water and sewer extensions under the assessment and lien provisions of state law. 
(Ord. 774 § 7, 1987)
13.04.080 - Service lines outside city limits. 
A.	Water and sewer lines may be extended beyond the corporate limits of the city into the county pursuant to this section. The cost of the extension shall be paid by the applicant requesting the extension. The city may require evidence of financial capability. The payment of costs may not be waived. The extension of city-provided service shall be to potential growth areas only as those areas are defined in comprehensive city plan. 
B.	Service lines shall not be extended to any area outside the city's corporate limits until a plat with dedicated easements for the service lines as well as public access has been prepared, approved and filed in accordance with applicable law and regulations. 
C.	Meters for water lines extended beyond the corporate limits may be located and installed at the point where line departs or leaves the corporate limits. 
(Ord. 774 § 8, 1987)
13.04.090 - Additional service to existing service locations. 
    In the event any service location is subdivided or if additional service locations are requested to a location receiving service, the service installed for the original location shall be deemed to have been installed only to supply service to the specific service location. New service shall be installed and connected upon application as provided in Sections 13.04.030 and 13.04.040. Additional service connections will be made to subdivided tracts only when the subdivision complies with applicable law and regulations. 
(Ord. 774 § 9, 1987)
13.04.100 - Installation fees. 
    If, after a contract for the new service installation and connection has been entered into the necessary extension of city water or sewer mains or lines is required, the city shall make all street excavations and provide the water or sewer service lines from the main lines to the property line. The city shall furnish and install all necessary equipment to provide service at the expense of the property owner. All installations and connections shall be made under the immediate direction and supervision of the department. The charge for installation shall be the actual expense to the department for labor and materials. The installation fee shall be paid before water and sewer service shall commence. 
(Ord. 774 § 10, 1987)
13.04.110 - Service interruptions and failures. 
A.	The city is not and shall not be responsible for any loss or damage due to or occasioned by failure of service from any cause, including and not limited to, the breakage of any line or the failure of equipment, or to the failure or interruption of any service due to any act of violence or civil disobedience or due to any act of God, and including any failure in the consumer's lines, apparatus, connections or equipments. 
B.	If the department responds to a customer call to investigate a service interruption or failure and if the failure or interruption is determined to be due to the failure of the lines, equipment or attachments thereof which by this chapter are the responsibility of the consumer, the charge of the actual costs incurred by the city in making such service call, including the cost of equipment and personnel, may be added to the service bill of the customer for the next billing period. 
(Ord. 774 § 11, 1987)
13.04.120 - Disruption and discontinuance of water service. 
A.	The city reserves the right without notice to temporarily disrupt water service for the purpose of making repairs or extensions and for such other purposes as the city in its discretion determines necessary. Insofar as possible the department may give notice warning of such disruption of service and the duration thereof. 
B.	For nonpayment of charges, as set out in Section 13.04.220(B), the city reserves the right to discontinue water service. The city may also discontinue service upon the written request of the customer. Except to the extent set out by this section, the city is not and shall not be liable for any loss or damage resulting from a discontinuance of water service. 
C.	Should the city fail to discontinue service, the city's liability shall be limited to the forfeiture of the right to charge a customer for water received from a service line under the following circumstances: 
1.	If after ten (10) days after written notice to discontinue a water service, the city has failed to discontinue the service; 
2.	The city has attempted to discontinue service but such service has not been completely discontinued; or 
3.	The city has completely discontinued service and a leak develops so that water enters the customer's pipes or property from the city's main. 
    Except to the extent set out by this section, the city is not and shall not be liable for any loss or damage resulting from incomplete discontinuance of service. 
    Note: Should a customer wish to avoid possible damage from incomplete discontinuance, the customer shall rely exclusively on privately owned cut-offs and not on the city's cut-off. Also, the customer (and not the city) shall be responsible for ensuring that the customer's plumbing is properly maintained and the property is kept properly drained after water service has been discontinued. 
(Ord. 774 § 12, 1987)
13.04.130 - Closing service lines. 
    Any service line that is no longer in use for any reason shall be permanently closed off at the main line. The cost of the closing of the line shall be born by the owner of the premises. The closing of a line may be performed by a licensed plumber or authorized city employee. The closed line shall be reported to the department in writing by the owner of the premises. 
(Ord. 774 § 13, 1987)
13.04.140 - Metering devices-Use, ownership and repairs. 
    Water shall be supplied by the department through metering devices, when available. Metering devices shall be furnished by the department and shall remain the property of the city. The department shall keep the meter in good repair. Should the meter be damaged or injured through some cause other than natural wear and use, the customer shall be charged the amount of the repair (see Section 13.04.160). 
(Ord. 774 § 14, 1987)
13.04.150 - Metering devices-Location and installation. 
A.	Metering devices shall be installed by the department: (1) in a vertical position; (2) in a location protected from freezing; and (3) in a location readily accessible for reading. The department reserves the right to designate the location of all meters. The department reserves the right to provide or request protective covering for the meter. All meter boxes or vaults shall be installed by the city or in accordance with specifications approved by the department. 
B.	The department shall specify the fittings and equipment for installation of meters. The curb boxes shall be placed on public property and shall control the supply of water through only one meter. All pipes, cocks and boxes shall be installed in accordance with the regulations of the department. 
(Ord. 774 § 15, 1987)
13.04.160 - Meter testing and meter replacement. 
A.	Upon written request to the department and payment of deposit, the manager shall issue an order for a test to be made of the accuracy of any metering device. 
    The deposit required is as follows: 
Three-quarter inch to one inch meters$ 25.00One and one-half inch to two-inch meters100.00 
    The cost of the meter test and the cost of freight charges are additional. 
    If testing shows the meter is recording three percent or more in excess of actual usage, the deposit shall be refunded to the applicant. The refund shall be made in the manner provided by law for the payment of claims against the city. 
    If the testing shows the meter is recording less than three percent of the actual usage, the deposit shall be retained by the department and shall not be refunded. 
B.	Metering devices will be repaired or replaced upon written request to the department accompanied by payment of the deposit as provided in subsection A of this section. 
C.	If the metering device has been tampered with or damaged in any way other than through normal usage, the deposit shall be retained by the department to cover the cost of replacement. The customer shall also be charged and billed for cost of all repairs at the actual cost of the repair. 
(Ord. 1021 § 1, 2006; Ord. 774 § 16, 1987)
13.04.170 - Access to property-Inspection. 
    The city reserves the right of the department to inspect any premises, including buildings, to which the city provides service. Inspections shall be at reasonable hours. Access shall include the right of the department to enter upon premises to read the meters, examine the location or condition of metering devices, lines or pipes, fixtures and equipment used in connection with service. 
(Ord. 774 § 17, 1987)
13.04.180 - Discontinuance of water service for interference. 
    If any customer or owner of any property receiving service shall refuse entry or prevent or interfere with the inspection provided for in Section 13.04.170, the manager is empowered and authorized to discontinue the water service to such premises. The water service shall not be reconnected to such premises until: (1) the inspection is completed; and (2) the water discontinuance charge and water reconnection charge have been paid in accordance with Section 13.04.200(A)(6). 
(Ord. 774 § 18, 1987)
13.04.190 - Fire hydrants. 
A.	Permit Required. No person, individual, firm, partnership or corporation (hereinafter called "user") shall obtain water from any fire hydrant located within the city for any purpose other than public emergency use without obtaining a permit from the city as provided herein. A user may obtain such a permit upon application to the city in the form prescribed by the city manager and obtaining a meter from the city as provided in subsection B of this section. The permit shall designate the fire hydrants from which the user may obtain water. 
B.	Permit Revoked. A permit may be revoked at any time for cause, such as but not limited to: user's failure to pay for water at the specified time; user's interference with emergency use of designated fire hydrant; user obtaining water from other than designated fire hydrant; conviction of user for violation of this section; compelling need of the city. 
C.	Fire Protection Takes Precedence. The granting of a permit under this section does not grant any right or privilege to the user to interfere with the city's duty to the public. Emergency use for fire protection supercedes and takes precedence over all other uses. 
D.	Meter Required. User shall use a meter owned by the city in order to keep a record of the water used. User is required to deposit eight hundred fifty dollars ($850.00) for each meter. This deposit shall be reimbursed to user upon the return of the water meter in good condition and certification by the water and sewer department of the city that the fire hydrant concerned is in good condition. User is responsible for any damage incurred to fire hydrant or water meter. The deposit shall be applied toward the payment for any such damage and may be applied to any unpaid charges for water obtained pursuant to the provisions of this section. 
E.	Water Rates. Water rates for water obtained from fire hydrants pursuant to this section are five dollars ($5.00) per one thousand (1,000) gallons, with a minimum monthly charge of thirty dollars ($30.00). Such rate will be evaluated on an annual basis and subject to change. User shall report to the city, water used by date and location as required by the city manager or his or her designated representatives. 
F.	Penalties. Any person, individual, firm, partnership, or corporation violating any of the provisions of this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be guilty of a separate offense for each and every day or portion thereof during which any such violation is continued or permitted. Upon conviction of any such violation, any such person, individual, firm, partnership or corporation shall be punished by fine of not more than three hundred dollars ($300.00) or by imprisonment for not more than ninety (90) days, or both such fine and imprisonment. Any violation of this section shall be considered justifiable cause for revoking of permit. 
(Ord. 1021 § 2, 2006; Ord. 994 § 1, 2004; Ord. 633 §§ 1-6, 1976)
(Ord. No. 1068, § 1, 7-23-2009)
13.04.200 - Use charges. 
    Rate for services rendered by the system shall be reasonable and just, taking into account the cost and value of the system, operation and maintenance expenses, proper allowances for depreciation and the amounts necessary to retire all bonds payable from the revenues, and any reserves therefore. There shall be charged against all users, including the city, rates and amounts, which shall be increased from time to time if necessary, sufficient to produce revenues to pay the annual operation and maintenance expenses, and at a minimum one hundred thirty (130) percent of the annual principal of and interest on all outstanding bonds and other obligations payable from the revenues thereof. All of which revenues, including those received from the city, shall be subject to maintaining the system and the payment of principal of and interest on all obligations payable from the revenues of the system, including reasonable reserves therefore. No free services of the system shall be furnished by the city. The city may cause a lien on each property, for unpaid rates and charges, to be perfected and enforced in accordance with the provisions of Sections 3-23-6 and 3-36-1 through 3-36-7, NMSA 1978. 
(Ord. No. 1068, § 2, 7-23-2009)
13.04.205 - Water rates. 
    The monthly water rates charged by the department for water service are as follows: 
A.	Rates for individually metered service units inside the corporate limits of the city.
1.	Availability. Under this rate schedule water service is available within corporate limits of the city. 
2.	Applicability. This schedule is applicable to individually metered service units.
3.	Special Requirements. The department reserves the right to require special contracts in the case of unusual or increased water requirements. 
4.	Monthly Rates-Residential Customers. Availability for water service utilizing a water meter for domestic purposes in individual private dwellings measured through one meter and billed under the residential service rate. Churches also qualify for this rate.This schedule is not applicable to resale, breakdown or standby services. The monthly rate for residential water customers shall be increased annually, at the beginning of the fiscal year, at a rate of four percent. 
Monthly Rate Inside City. 
The first three thousand (3,000) gallons at a minimum charge of fifteen dollars ($15.00); 
Three thousand one (3,001) gallons to six thousand (6,000) gallons at three dollars and five cents ($3.05) per 1,000 gallons; 
Six thousand one (6,001) gallons to ten thousand (10,000) gallons at three dollars and twelve cents ($3.12) per 1,000 gallons; 
Ten thousand one (10,001) gallons to twenty thousand (20,000) gallons at three dollars and twenty cents ($3.20) per 1,000 gallons; 
Twenty thousand one (20,001) gallons to fifty thousand (50,000) gallons at three dollars and twenty-seven cents ($3.27) per 1,000 gallons; 
Fifty thousand one (50,001) gallons and above are three dollars and thirty-five cents ($3.35) per one thousand (1,000) gallons. 
5.	Monthly Rates-Commercial Customers. Availability for water service of a single character supplied at one point of delivery utilizing a water meter for commercial purposes, multiple unit dwellings and other consumers for whom no specific rate is provided. This schedule is not applicable to resale, breakdown or standby services. The monthly rate for commercial water customers shall be increased annually, at the beginning of the fiscal year, at a rate of four percent. 
Monthly Rate Inside City. 
The first three thousand (3,000) gallons at a minimum charge of twenty dollars and seventy-four cents ($20.74); 
Three thousand one (3,001) gallons to six thousand (6,000) gallons at three dollars and thirty-two cents ($3.32) per 1,000 gallons; 
Six thousand one (6,001) gallons to ten thousand (10,000) gallons at three dollars and thirty-nine cents ($3.39) per 1,000 gallons; 
Ten thousand one (10,001) gallons to twenty thousand (20,000) gallons at three dollars and forty-six cents ($3.46) per 1,000 gallons; 
Twenty thousand one (20,001) gallons to fifty thousand (50,000) gallons at three dollars and fifty-three cents ($3.53) per 1,000 gallons; 
Fifty thousand one (50,001) gallons and above are three dollars and sixty-one cents ($3.61) per one thousand (1,000) gallons. 
6.	Discontinuance and Reconnection Charge. Following discontinuance of service for nonpayment, a reconnection charge shall be paid to the city as follows: 
Forty dollars ($40.00) during regular business hours (eight a.m. to five p.m.); 
Seveny-five dollars ($75.00) on weekends, holidays and after five p.m. on weekdays. 
B.	Rates for individually metered units outside the corporate limits of the city.
1.	Availability. Under this rate schedule water service will be supplied only when water is available for use outside the corporate limits of the city. 
2.	Applicability. This schedule is applicable to individually metered service units.
3.	Special Requirements. The department reserves the right to require and negotiate special contracts for industrial and commercial users. 
4.	Monthly Rates Outside City. Availability for water service utilizing a water meter for domestic purposes in individual private dwellings measured through one meter and billed under the residential service rate. Churches also qualify for this rate. This schedule is not applicable to resale, breakdown or standby services. The monthly rate for commercial water customers shall be increased annually, at the beginning of the fiscal year, at a rate of four percent. 
Monthly Rate Residential Outside City. 
The first three thousand (3,000) gallons at a minimum charge of twenty-two dollars and forty-five cents ($22.45); 
Three thousand one (3,001) gallons to six thousand (6,000) gallons at four dollars and fifty-five cents ($4.55) per 1,000 gallons; 
Six thousand one (6,001) gallons to ten thousand (10,000) gallons at four dollars and fifty-nine cents ($4.59) per 1,000 gallons; 
Ten thousand one (10,001) gallons to twenty thousand (20,000) gallons at four dollars and sixty-two cents ($4.62) per 1,000 gallons; 
Twenty thousand one (20,001) gallons to fifty thousand (50,000) gallons at four dollars and sixty-six cents ($4.66) per 1,000 gallons; 
Fifty thousand one (50,001) gallons and above are four dollars and seventy cents ($4.70) per one thousand (1,000) gallons. 
Monthly Rates-Commercial Outside City. Availability for water service of a single character supplied at one point of delivery utilizing a water meter for commercial purposes, multiple unit dwellings and other consumers for whom no specific rate is provided. This schedule is not applicable to resale, breakdown or standby services. The monthly rate for commercial water customers shall be increased annually, at the beginning of the fiscal year, at a rate of four percent. 
Monthly Rate Commercial Outside City. 
The first three thousand (3,000) gallons at a minimum charge of thirty-one dollars and ten cents ($31.10); 
Three thousand one (3,001) gallons to six thousand (6,000) gallons at four dollars and ninety-eight cents ($4.98) per 1,000 gallons; 
Six thousand one (6,001) gallons to ten thousand (10,000) gallons at five dollars and nine cents ($5.09) per 1,000 gallons;

5.	Persons desiring water and sewer extensions outside the corporate limits shall comply with the requirements of Section 13.04.220. 
6.	Discontinuance and Reconnection Charge. Reconnection charges for outside city services shall be as stated in subsection (A)(6) of this section. 
(Ord. 1058 §§ 1-4, 2008; Ord. 1021 § 3, 2006; Ord. 1020 §§ A, B, 2006; Ord. 1013 § A, 2005; Ord. 994 §§ 2, 3, 2004; Ord. 952 §§ 1-6, 2000; Ord. 887 (part), 1994; Ord. 870 (part), 1993; Ord. 849 (part), 1992; Ord. 774 § 19, 1987) 
(Ord. No. 1068, §§ 3, 4, 7-23-2009; Ord. No. 1093, §§ 1, 2, 8-11-2011; Ord. No. 1099, §§ 1, 2, 12-29-2011) 
13.04.210 - Sewer rates. 
A.	Residential Rates. The monthly rate on sewers shall be increased annually, at the beginning of the fiscal year, at a rate of two percent. The monthly sewer rates charged by the department for residential sewer service are as follows: 
1.	The first two thousand (2,000) gallons at a minimum charge of twenty dollars ($20.00); two thousand and one (2,001) gallons and above are three dollars ($3.00) per one thousand (1,000) gallons. 
2.	The volume for each user shall be based on an average monthly water use for the billing period of November through January (herein "computation period"). The volume shall be computed annually. The volume computed will be used to compute rates for each user for the year beginning July first (1st) following the computation period. 
3.	Irregularities in the figures obtained during the computation period may be equitably adjusted by the manager in his or her discretion. 
B.	Commercial Rates. The monthly rate on sewers shall be increased annually, at the beginning of the fiscal year, at a rate of two percent. The monthly sewer rates charged by the department for commercial sewer service within the corporate limits of the city are as follows: 
1.	The first two thousand (2,000) gallons at a minimum charge of twenty-two dollars ($22.00); two thousand and one (2,001) gallons to ten thousand (10,000) gallons are three dollars and fifty cents ($3.50) per one thousand (1,000) gallons, ten thousand and one (10,001) gallons and above are three dollars and seventy-five cents ($3.75) per one thousand (1,000) gallons. 
2.	The volume for each commercial user shall be based on the monthly water usage.
C.	Monthly Residential Rates Outside City. The monthly rate on sewers shall be increased annually, at the beginning of the fiscal year, at a rate of two percent. The monthly sewer rates charged by the department for residential sewer service outside the corporate limits of the city are as follows: 
1.	The first two thousand (2,000) gallons at a minimum charge of twenty-four dollars ($24.00); two thousand and one (2,001) gallons and above are three dollars and seventy-five cents ($3.75) per one thousand (1,000) gallons. 
2.	The volume for each commercial user shall be based on the monthly water usage.
D.	Monthly Commercial Rates Outside City. The monthly rate on sewers shall be increased annually, at the beginning of the fiscal year, at a rate of two percent. The monthly sewer rates charged by the department for commercial sewer service outside the corporate limits of the city are as follows: 
1.	The first two thousand (2,000) gallons at a minimum charge of twenty-four dollars ($24.00); two thousand and one (2,001) gallons to one million (1,000,000) gallons are three dollars and seventy-five cents ($3.75) per one thousand (1,000) gallons; over one million (1,000,000) gallons is four dollars ($4.00) per one thousand (1,000) gallons. 
2.	The volume for each commercial user shall be based on the monthly water usage.
(Ord. 1021 § 4, 2006; Ord. 994 § 4, 2004; Ord. 887 (part), 1994; Ord. 870 (part), 1993; Ord. 849 (part), 1992; Ord. 819 § 1, 1990; Ord. 774 § 20, 1987) 
(Ord. No. 1077, § 1, 7-8-2010; Ord. No. 1093, §§ 1, 2, 8-11-2011)
13.04.220 - Billing procedure. 
A.	All charges for service shall be billed to the customer monthly. The billing shall be on a regularly established day of each and every month and shall be billed for services provided in the prior month. 
B.	Billing charges shall be mailed once each month on or about the twenty-first day of the month, and shall be due and payable by the first day of the following month. All charges ten dollars ($10.00) or more not paid by the twenty-first day of the month that the bill is due will be considered delinquent and shall be subject to a ten dollar ($10.00) penalty. Water service to these customers will then be disconnected, and water shall not again be supplied to the customer until the arrears and discontinuance and reconnection charges have been paid in full. 
C.	Water, sewer service and refuse collection charges shall be billed jointly. The bill shall show the separate charges for each service. 
(Ord. 1020 § C, 2006; Ord. 1013 § B, 2005; Ord. 994 § 5, 2004; Ord. 819 § 2, 1990; Ord. 774 § 21, 1987) 
13.04.230 - Disputed charges. 
A.	If a consumer disputes the charges billed and it is shown that the metering device is registering usage incorrectly, charges may be adjusted on the basis of estimated usage shown by an average of previous charges for a like seasonable period of at least three months determined for a period when the meter registered properly. 
B.	In the case of disputed charges in the prior month's billing, the customer may request a meter test pursuant to Section 13.04.160. Upon completion of the meter test, adjustment may be made pursuant to subsection A of this section. 
(Ord. 774 § 22, 1987)
13.04.240 - Water and sewer fund. 
    All revenue collected from the operation of the water and sewer service system, including moneys from the collection of charges for water service and for the use of the sewer disposal system and including moneys from the sale of any property or material connected with the department, shall be placed to the credit of the water and sewer fund for the use of the department as provided by law. 
(Ord. 774 § 23, 1987)
13.04.250 - Consumer not to supply other parties. 
    Without prior approval of the city, no water or sewer service consumer shall provide service in any way, by sale, gift or otherwise, to any other person, nor shall any such consumer permit another to attach to or utilize service connections or equipment for any purpose. 
(Ord. 774 § 24, 1987)
13.04.260 - Taking service without authority. 
    Except as now or as may hereafter be authorized and approved by this chapter and regulations of the department, it is unlawful for any person, by any means or in any manner, to receive, consume, utilize or in any manner divert or appropriate to his or her own use or to use of another without payment therefor any service belonging to and made available by the city. All service shall be supplied and furnished by the department in accordance with this chapter and the rules and regulations of the department. 
(Ord. 774 § 25, 1987)
13.04.270 - Taking service after discontinuance. 
    It is unlawful for any person by any means or in any manner to break or remove any seal or device used in discontinuing water service. It is further unlawful for any person for any reason or by any means or manner to reconnect to any service after the service has been discontinued. 
(Ord. 774 § 26, 1987)
13.04.280 - Tampering-Unauthorized connections. 
A.	It is unlawful for any person, by any means or in any manner, to cause a water meter to incorrectly register water service. It is further unlawful for any person to tamper with or in any manner damage or destroy such meters or registering devices. 
B.	It is unlawful for any person to tamper with any water main, fire hydrant, water meter, or sewer line or to make any connection to the water and sewer system of the city without written permission from the city. It is unlawful for any person to reconnect service when it has been discontinued pursuant to this chapter. 
(Ord. 774 § 27, 1987)
13.04.290 - Damaging and stealing property-Unlawful use of water. 
A.	It is unlawful for any person to remove, destroy, injure, deface, or in any way harm any water pipe, hydrant, faucet, valve meter or meter box, installed in and by the city for its use or the use of the public. 
B.	It is unlawful for any person to take water from any hydrant, faucet or pipe without the proper authority to do so. 
C.	It is unlawful for any person to carry off any tool, apparatus or any property or equipment belonging to the city. 
D.	Without lawful authority to do so, it is unlawful for any person to open any fire plug or water hydrant or other water pipe belonging to the city and permit or allow water to be turned out of or run out upon the ground. 
(Ord. 774 § 28, 1987)
13.04.300 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person convicted of any offense specified in Sections 13.04.250 through 13.04.290 shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. 774 § 29, 1987)
13.04.310 - Rights reserved. 
    The city reserves the right at any time to revise or amend this chapter or the department rules or regulations pertaining to the supply of water service. The city further reserves the right to disconnect or refuse service to any applicant, customer or consumer who shall be found by the department to have violated any provision of this chapter or rules and regulations of the department. 
(Ord. 774 § 30, 1987)
Chapter 13.06 - WATER CONSERVATION 
Sections: 

13.06.010 - Title, purpose. 
    This chapter shall be known as the water conservation ordinance. This chapter shall both require and encourage all users of water within the city limits to reduce water consumption and waste. 
(Ord. 1012 §§ 1, 2 (part), 2005)
13.06.020 - Water conservation compliance. 
    No person, firm, corporation, water association, or government facility or operation using water from the city of Tucumcari water system shall make, cause, use or permit the use of water in a manner contrary to provisions of this chapter. All users of domestic wells and users of irrigation water provided by Arch Hurley Conservancy District within the jurisdiction of the city shall be exempted from the requirements of this chapter to the extent of such well use provided as authorized by Sections 3-53-1 and 3-53-2 NMSA 1978, and with the exception of Section 13.06.030 of this chapter on prohibition of water waste. 
(Ord. 1012 §§ 1, 2 (part), 2005)
13.06.030 - Water waste prohibited. 
A.	No person, firm, corporation, or government facility or operation shall waste, cause or permit to be wasted any water from the city water system. "Water waste" is defined as the nonbeneficial use of water. Nonbeneficial use includes, but is not restricted to, the excessive application of water such that it overflows the landscaped area being watered or other area of water use and runs onto adjacent property or public right-of-way. 
B.	Restrictions in this chapter do not apply to water flows resulting from fire fighting, hydrant flushing or fire training activities; water applied to prevent or abate health, safety or accident hazards, or water flows from routine maintenance of the municipal water system or from temporary water system failures or malfunctions. Restrictions on landscape irrigation do not apply to reuse of grey water, effluent (treated wastewater) or nonpotable water. 
(Ord. 1012 §§ 1, 2 (part), 2005)
13.06.040 - Declaration of water conservation levels. 
A.	The city manager, upon the recommendation of the water department superintendent, is authorized to declare water conservation levels through public notice. The conservation levels shall be initiated based upon the relationship between water demand and municipal safe production and delivery capability. 
1.	"Safe production capability" is eighty (80) percent of the total water resources available, based upon well production capacities, booster station capacities, distribution components, storage reserves, aquifer levels, water rights, weather conditions, and historic data. 
2.	"Total production capability" is one hundred (100) percent of the total water resources available. The water department superintendent shall determine total production capability and update it as water resource conditions change. 
B.	Declarations by public notice shall be made by public service announcements through electronic media, and shall be published a minimum of one time in a local newspaper(s) of general circulation. The water conservation level declared shall become effective immediately upon the first announcement. 
C.	The following water conservation levels shall govern the use of water by customers using water from the city water system, as prescribed below: 
1.	Water Conservation Level I - Voluntary Water Conservation.
a.	Level I shall be initiated when annual precipitation for each of the previous two years is equal to or less than eighty (80) percent of the long-term annual average. This determination will be based on annual precipitation figures for the period of May 1st through April 30th, as measured at the long-term Tucumcari 4 NE gage. 
b.	Water users are encouraged to minimize use of water for landscape irrigation, vehicle and pavement washing, construction, and other water consuming activities. Voluntary compliance with Level II restrictions is encouraged. 
2.	Water Conservation Level II - Water Restrictions. Level II shall be initiated when demand is greater than safe production capability for two consecutive weeks. No person or entity using water from the city's water system shall: 
a.	Use water outdoors for landscape watering or refilling of ponds or pools, except as provided: 
i.	Water use is restricted to the following days of the week:
(A)	Properties with even-numbered addresses are restricted to such uses on Monday, Wednesday, Friday, and Sunday, and 
(B)	Properties with odd-numbered addresses are restricted to such uses on Tuesday, Thursday, Saturday, and Sunday. 
ii.	Landscape irrigation is restricted to the time period before 10 a.m. and after 6 p.m. on the applicable day; however, outdoor irrigation under manual control (e.g., watering from a hose with a shut-off nozzle or from a bucket or watering can) is permissible at any time on the applicable day. 
b.	Wash vehicles unless a bucket and hose with a positive cut-off nozzle is used; however these restrictions do not apply to vehicles that must be washed for public health, safety, or welfare, or to commercial car washes. 
c.	Wash paved areas, such as driveways, sidewalks, parking lots, and tennis courts, except for health or safety. 
3.	Water Conservation Level III - Water Crisis. Level III shall be initiated when water demand equals or exceeds total production or delivery capability at any time. This level constitutes an emergency situation, and can be declared immediately by the city manager. At this level, no person or entity using water from the city's water system shall use any water outdoors for any purpose, unless required for public health, safety, and welfare. 
D.	In addition to the restrictions listed in this section, the city manager may impose specific restrictions on large water users if deemed necessary to protect the city's water resources and health and safety of its citizens. The city manager may also consider alternatives to the specified outdoor watering schedules for water users with large turf areas (e.g., half one day, half the next day). 
E.	The water department superintendent may make recommendations at any time with regard to moratoriums on the extension of water mains, consistent with city policy. 
(Ord. 1012 §§ 1, 2 (part), 2005)
13.06.050 - Penalties and enforcement. 
A.	Assessment of fees for violations of the provisions of Sections 13.06.010 through 13.06.040 of this chapter will be through the city utilities billing department for the responsible party's billing account. Fees and service cutoff may be suspended pending the outcome of an appeal. The schedule for assessment of fees and cutoff of service shall be as follows: 
1.	Water Conservation Level I - Compliance Is Voluntary. Warnings will be issued for water waste. 
2.	Water Conservation Level II:
a.	First observed violation: issuance of notice of violation.
b.	Second observed violation: twenty dollar ($20.00) fee.
c.	Third observed violation: fifty dollar ($50.00) fee.
d.	Fourth observed violation: one hundred dollar ($100.00) fee.
e.	Fifth observed violation: one hundred dollar ($100.00) fee plus cutoff of service.
3.	Water Conservation Level III:
a.	First observed violation: issuance of notice of violation.
b.	Second observed violation: a fee equal to twenty-five (25) percent of the previous month's water bill, but not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) or greater than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
c.	Third observed violation: a fee equal to fifty (50) percent of the previous month's water bill, but not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or greater than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
d.	Fourth observed violation: a fee equal to fifty (50) percent of the previous month's water bill, but not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or greater than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), and cutoff of service. 
B.	Procedure for Assessment of Fees. All assessments of fees for violations of the provisions of Sections 13.06.010 through 13.06.040 of this chapter shall be upon the issuance of a notice of violation. Within five business days of the issuance of a notice of violation, the responsible party shall be sent by certified mail a copy of the notice of violation, along with a statement of the fee to be assessed. The notice to the responsible party also shall include a notice of the party's right to appeal the assessment pursuant to the provisions of subsection C of this section. Fees shall be assessed to the responsible party's billing account, listed as a separate line item on the utility bill, and cutoff of service shall be effected on the sixteenth day following the expiration of the appeal period, the date of issuance of the determination of any appeal, or the date of the city commission's action upon a review hearing, whichever applicable date is later. The fees must be paid within the normal payment period allowed by the city utility billing system. 
C.	Appeal of Assessment of Fees. A responsible party may appeal an assessment of fees or notice of cutoff of service for violations of the provisions of Sections 13.06.010 through 13.06.040 of this chapter by delivering to the city manager, within ten (10) days after the date the notice of violation was mailed, a written notice of appeal of the imposition of the fee or cutoff of service. The notice of appeal shall identify the property and state the grounds of appeal together with all material facts in support thereof. Upon receipt of the notice of appeal, the city manager shall be provided with copies of the notice of violation appealed from and any documents and photographs supporting the notice of violation. Within seven working days of the date he or she receives copies of the notice of violation and supporting documents, the city manager shall issue a written decision on the appeal either upholding the assessment of fees or cutoff of service, modifying the assessment or cutoff, or overruling the assessment or cutoff. Copies of the city manager's written decision shall be mailed by certified mail to the appealing responsible party, and sent to the city utility billing department, along with a notice of the responsible party's right to request a review hearing before the city commission pursuant to the provisions of subsection D hereof. 
D.	Review of Appeal Decision. If a responsible party does not agree with the city manager's written appeal decision, the party shall, within ten (10) days after the date of mailing of the decision, file with the city clerk a written request for a hearing before the city commission. The request for hearing shall identify the property, attach a copy of the city manager's decision, and state the grounds of appeal to the city commission together with all material facts in support thereof. The city clerk shall schedule the hearing for the next regular meeting according to the adopted schedule of the city commission, providing adequate time to ensure that the public notice requirements can be satisfied, or such later time as is mutually agreed upon by the responsible party and the city manager. The city clerk shall send written notice by certified mail to the responsible party of the time and place of the hearing before the city commission. At the hearing testimony and evidence shall be taken under oath or affirmation, and the responsible party shall have the right to present evidence and ask questions of persons who testify as to the alleged facts upon which the assessment of fee or cutoff of service was based and any other relevant and material facts which may aid the city commission in determining whether the violation of the provisions of Sections 13.06.010 through 13.06.040 of this chapter occurred. If, upon such hearing, a majority of those present and voting of the city commission are of the opinion the city manager's decision was correct, then such decision shall be affirmed; otherwise the commission shall have the power to revise the city manager's decision. 
E.	Any person who violates the provisions of Sections 13.06.010 through 13.06.040 of this chapter, for which no other penalty is set forth, shall be subject to the general penalty provision of this code as set forth in subsection A of Section 13.06.050. 
F.	Authority to enforce the provisions of this chapter shall be assigned to, but not limited to, all police officers and code enforcement officers of the city. Other city employees may be assigned enforcement authority as deemed necessary by the city manager. 
(Ord. 1012 §§ 1, 2 (part), 2005)
Chapter 13.08 - SEWER USE[1] 
Sections: 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note-Ord. No. 1123, adopted July 23, 2015, amended Ch. 13.08 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Ch. 13.08, §§ 13.08.010-13.08.130, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. 707, §§ 1-4, 6-13, adopted 1983; Ord. 991, adopted 2003; and Ord. 1058, §§ 5-7, adopted 2008.

13.08.010 - Short title. 
    This chapter shall be known as the "sewer use ordinance of Tucumcari, New Mexico." 
(Ord. No. 1123, 7-23-2015)
13.08.020 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
    "A.S.T.M." means the American Society for Testing Materials. 
    "B.O.D. (biochemical oxygen demand)" means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter by Standard Methods Procedure in five days at twenty (20) degrees centigrade expressed in milligrams per liter (mg/l). 
    "Building drain" means that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system which receives the discharge from soil, waste and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the building sewer, beginning five feet outside the inner face of the building wall. 
    "Building sewer" means the extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal. 
    "City" means the city of Tucumcari, New Mexico. 
    "COD (chemical oxygen demand)" means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the chemical oxidation of organic and inorganic matter under standard laboratory procedure by the dichromate reflux method expressed in milligrams per liter. 
    "Combined sewer" means a sewer receiving both surface runoff and sewage. 
    "Garbage" means solid wastes from the domestic and commercial preparation, cooking and dispensing of food and from the handling, storage, and sale of produce. 
    "Health officer" means any person or his or her authorized representative appointed by the city or any New Mexico Environmental Improvement Agency Representative charged with approval or inspection of public or private wastewater facilities. 
    "Industrial liquid wastes" mean all waterborne solids, liquids or gaseous wastes resulting from any industrial manufacturing or food processing operation or process, or from the development of any natural resource or any mixture of these with water or domestic sewage as distinct from normal domestic sewage. 
    "Interference with any wastewater facility" means any condition or combination of conditions which cause degradation of the operational efficiency of a wastewater facility. 
    "Natural outlet" means any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other body of surface or groundwater. 
    "Normal domestic wastewater" means waterborne wastes normally discharging from the sanitary conveniences of buildings, including apartment houses and hotels, office buildings, factories and institutions, free from storm surface water and industrial wastes. Normal domestic wastewater shall mean "normal" for the city of Tucumcari, New Mexico. 
    "Person" means any individual, firm, company, political or governmental subdivision, association, society, corporation or group. 
    "pH" means the logarithm, to the base ten, of the reciprocal of the weight of hydrogen ions in grams per liter of solution. 
    "Properly shredded garbage" means the wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food that have been shredded to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half inch in any dimension. 
    "Public sewer" means a sewer in which all owners of abutting properties shall have equal rights and is controlled by public authority. 
    "Sanitary sewer" means the public sewer portion of a wastewater facility which transports wastewater and to which storm, surface and groundwater are not intentionally admitted. 
    "Settleable solids" means those solids which settle during a preselected period of time expressed as milliliters per liter of sample. 
    "Sewer" means a pipe or conduit for carrying sewage. 
    "Shall; May." The word "shall" is mandatory; the word "may" is permissive. 
    "Slug" means any discharge of water, sewage or industrial waste which in concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flow exceeds for any period of duration longer than fifteen (15) minutes more than five times the average twenty-four-hour concentration or flows during normal operation. 
    "Standard methods" means the laboratory procedures set forth in the latest edition, at the time of analysis, of "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater" as prepared, approved and published jointly by the American Public Health Association and the Water Pollution Control Federation. 
    "Storm sewer" means a sewer which carries storm and surface waters and drainage, but excludes wastewater and polluted industrial wastes. 
    "Superintendent" means the director of the wastewater department of the city of Tucumcari, New Mexico or his or her authorized deputy, agent or representative. 
    "Suspended solids" means solids that either float on the surface of, or are in water. 
    "Trap" means a device for retaining sand, silt, grit, mineral material, petroleum solvent, grease or oil by gravity-differential separation from wastewater and of a design and capacity approved by the city. 
    "Unpolluted process water" means any water or waste containing none of the following: free of emulsified grease or oil; acid or alkali, phenols or other substances imparting taste and odor to receiving water; toxic substances in suspension, colloidal state or solution; and noxious or odorous gases. 
    "Wastewater" means the used water of a community. Such used water may be a combination of the liquid and waterborne wastes from residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants and institutions. 
    "Wastewater facilities" means the structures, equipment and processes required to collect, transport and treat wastewater liquid and dispose of the effluent. 
    "Wastewater treatment facilities" means an arrangement of devices and structures for treating wastewater and sludge. Sometimes used as synonymous with waste treatment plant or wastewater treatment plant. 
    "Watercourse" means a channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously or intermittently. 
    "W.P.C.F." means the Water Pollution Control Federation. 
(Ord. No. 1123, 7-23-2015)
13.08.030 - Unpolluted discharges to sewers prohibited. 
    No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any stormwater surface water, groundwater, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, uncontaminated cooling water, or unpolluted industrial process waters to any sanitary sewer. 
(Ord. No. 1123, 7-23-2015)
13.08.040 - Drainage discharge. 
    Stormwater and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to such sewers as are specifically designated as storm sewers, or to a natural outlet approved by the superintendent. Industrial cooling water or unpolluted process waters may be discharged on approval of the superintendent, to a storm sewer or natural outlet. 
(Ord. No. 1123, 7-23-2015)
13.08.050 - Permitting the use of gray water. 
A.	Gray Water Defined. Untreated household wastewater that has not come in contact with toilet waste and includes wastewater from bathtubs, showers, washbasins, clothes washing machines and laundry tubs, and does not include wastewater from kitchen sinks or dishwashers or laundry water from the washing of material soiled with human excreta, such as diapers. 
B.	Gray Water Discharge Requirements. The city of Tucumcari shall not require a permit for the application if less than two hundred fifty (250) gallons per day of private residential gray water originating from a residence for the resident's household gardening, composting or landscape irrigation if: 
1.	A constructed gray water distribution system provides for overflow into the sewer system or on-site wastewater treatment and disposal system; 
2.	A gray water storage tank is covered to restrict access and to eliminate habitat for mosquito's or other vectors; 
3.	A gray water system is sited outside of a floodway;
4.	Gray water is vertically separate at least five feet above the ground water table;
5.	Gray water pressure piping is clearly identified as a nonpotable water conduit;
6.	Gray water is used on the site where it is generated and does not run off the property lines; 
7.	Gray water is applied in a manner that minimizes the potential for contact with people or domestic pets; 
8.	Ponding is prohibited, application of gray water is managed to minimize standing water on the surface and to ensure that the hydraulic capacity of the soil is not exceeded; 
9.	Gray water is not sprayed; and
10.	Gray water is not discharged to a watercourse.
C.	Permitting Requirements. Persons wishing to discharge gray water as hereinabove stated shall be required to conform to the requirements of the Uniform Plumbing Code Appendix (G) or other applicable rules and regulations of the state of New Mexico and the city of Tucumcari. Persons discharging two hundred fifty (250) gallons or more per day are required to obtain a liquid waste permit from the New Mexico environment department. 
D.	Penalties. Every person convicted of a violation of this section shall be punished by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment not to exceed ninety (90) days, or both. 
(Ord. No. 1123, 7-23-2015)
13.08.060 - Unauthorized disposal. 
    Except as hereinafter provided it is unlawful to construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool or other facility intended or used for the disposal of sewage. 
(Ord. No. 1123, 7-23-2015)
13.08.070 - Installation and connection of toilet facilities. 
    The owner of all houses, building or properties used for human occupancy, employment, recreation or other similar purposes situated within the city and abutting on any street, alley or right-of-way in which there is now located or may in the future be located, a public sanitary sewer of the city, is required at his or her expense to install suitable toilet facilities therein, and to connect such facilities directly with the proper public sewer in accordance with provisions of this chapter, within ninety (90) days after date of official notice to do so, provided, that such public sewer is within one hundred (100) feet of the property line. 
(Ord. No. 1123, 7-23-2015)
13.08.080 - Extra-territorial hookups. 
    Residential, commercial and industrial properties adjacent to the city limits where there is potential growth may be connected via building sewers to available sewers or future sewers upon application and agreement to abide by the provisions of this chapter and in conformance to the city's utility extension policy as outlined in the Comprehensive City Plan, November, 1980 and upon approval of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1123, 7-23-2015)
13.08.090 - Private sewage disposal. 
A.	When Permitted. Where a public sanitary sewer is not available under the provisions of this chapter, the building sewer shall be connected to a private sewage disposal system complying with the provisions of this chapter. 
B.	Permit. Before commencement of construction of a private sewage disposal system, the owner shall first obtain a written permit signed by the superintendent. The application for such permit shall be made on a form furnished by the city which the applicant shall supplement by any plans, specifications and other information as are deemed necessary by the superintendent. A permit and inspection fee shall be paid to the city at the time the application is filed. 
C.	Inspection. A permit for a private sewage disposal system shall not become effective until the installation is completed to the satisfaction of the superintendent. He or she shall be allowed to inspect the work at any stage of construction and in any event, the applicant for the permit shall notify the superintendent when the work is ready for final inspection and before any underground portions are covered.
